I nanny across the street from handlebar and call in for pick up at least 3 or 4 times a week. I called in tonight and was told they couldn't take my order because they were "busy", so I asked if I could walk in and order for take out and was told no as well. Idk if it's just me or that's the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard. To make matters worse, I stepped out into the balcony and could see empty tables through the window!! Lol give me a break guys

So, Handlebar is pretty great. I went with a friend who said it a vegetarian/vegan restaurant, I am currently neither, but I'm always trying out different diets and foods, so I was excited. To my surprise, I realized, after being seated and having a look at the menu, that it is actually a pescetarian restaurant! My very first. I ordered the blackened catfish with broccoli and one other side that i'm having trouble remembering... My friend got some sort of chili and the mac and cheese. I completely devoured everything in front of me, which I usually don't do, being such a lady and all.  But, it was that damn good! We also got dessert: brownie and ice cream. Yum, although, dessert REALLY hard to screw up. I would definitely revisit Handlebar. Minus one star because my Jack & coke tasted like just coke AND my beer wasn't quite chilled.

Ever have that friend who wears unique thrift store clothes and seems really cool, but once you get to know them they seem really boring and not worth your time? I kinda feel that way about Handlebar.  They get things right on the surface:  - Great patio seating - Many hearty vegan options - Decent drink/food combo specials almost every night But... I find myself, every time, looking over the menu, and wishing something really interesting stood out, and wishing the prices made a bit more sense.  Example: Last time I was there, I wanted to get the po'boy and mac'n'cheese. Well, the Po Boy was $13 to start, and to get the mac 'n cheese would be another $1.75. So after a non-alcoholic drink, tax, n tip I'm looking at a $22 bill for, let's face it, a sandwich and a side that's not that exciting, and the wife hasn't even eaten yet! So let's say we both get the same thing and both get 1 of the cheapest beers. You're looking at a $55 bill for 2 sandwiches, 2 sides and 2 cheap beers. I don't know about you, but that doesn't sit right with me. I also don't like that they have the boring sides for 'free' like french fries or collards, or you can get the "Premium" sides for additional fees on top of your expensive sandwich. Just kind-of bullshit if you ask me. Breakfast is the same way. It was decent, but not exactly the inspiring creations expected for the price. I mean it's so close, but somehow, far far away. You just have to know going in you're gonna drop a ton of cash for comfort food and sandwiches that aren't *that* interesting.  But the place has a good vibe overall and I think they give it an honest effort.

It's been way too long since my last visit here. I love this place. Excellent food and great drink selection. Get the avocado tacos if you're coming in for lunch or dinner! The brunch is also great. So many veg options!

I came here for dinner and it was so chill. Like I was seriously impressed. They have the low lighting on LOCK.  I have been here multiple times outside, in the summer, but nothing was like dining in on a Saturday eve.  Oh, right, they serve food and alcohol too. It's always good, I had the Mac and Chili attack. I have my eye on that BBQ seitan burger though ...

I fully intended to take a picture of my awesome poblano pepper breakfast sammy, but it disappeared before I remembered to do so. I don't know how it happened. Our server, who looked like a young Cate Blanchett, was also very helpful and friendly.  We loved everything about this place, from decor to service to the very last bite of food, and will definitely be back.

Holy cow, I love you Handlebar. This place was suggested to me by a friend as I have recently made the switch from long time vegetarian to vegan. So I checked it out on my own time one night and I am so infatuated with their food/drinks/pricing. I usually get the buffalo chicken wrap but I've deviated from that a few time with appetizers. Samosas, chips & guac...so delicious. Seriously though, do yourself a favor and get that buffalo chicken wrap if you need a suggestion. The restaurant is small but usually isn't too terribly crowded, even during peak times. Wait staff is attentive enough- exactly what you want. Drinks are sooo cheap. Two of us got reaaally happy here for $40. I dream of the moment where i can be reunited with Handlebar again!!!

This place has great food. Black bean tostadas are my favorite here but I have tried pretty much everything vegetarian on the menu and its all yummy. Just depends what you are in mood for. The smoked gouda mac and cheese is delicious too! I miss all the good food Chicago has to offer.
Great hangout spot. Fish tacos  and fried pickles were very good! Reasonably priced. Would come here again.
Fabulous food, vegan friendly & have a gluten free menu! Don't drink the wine though they serve it in tumblers.

Really great spot for vegans, vegetarians and pescatarians alike. Even meat eaters can enjoy this spot but don't look for steak on this menu.  Lots of Latin inspired dishes, nachos, tacos, and spices. Love the Black Bean Maduro which is a bean medley in a spicy sauce served with avacado on a plantain and it's my fav from here! Not too fond of their sandwich's but to each their own. Their catfish tacos are also really yummy! I also always leave with a slice of their chocolate cake from CRUMB Bake Shop. I'm always too full to finish it there but it's too good to pass up so my boyfriend and I share a slice at home.  Cool atmosphere, posters everywhere which is a graphic designer and illustrators dream. Waiters are always laid back and cool.

First time dining here on a wintery Sunday night after ditching the 45 min wait times in the West Loop. We were looking for a quick veg bite and saw great Yelp reviews so decided to give it a shot.  Looks unassuming from the exterior, kinda dive-ish, but has an outdoor patio which I'm sure brightens up the place in the summer.  Step inside and instantly greeted by welcoming wait staff. Chill relaxed interior, music not overwhelming or distracting, I think Joy Division was playing, set the vibe just right. Definitely more comfortable than it looks from the outside.  Menu is a veg treat! I was torn between at least 4 different items and settled for the Chili Mac and Cheese. So delish, a perfect dish to warm up my winter chill, and portioned enough that I was able to bring some home as a snack for later. Also got the Hat and Gloves cocktail, a perfect complement to my savory winter dish. The bf's dinner and cocktail was just as delicious.  Price here is great, 2 cocktails and 2 entrees  for less than $40. Great daily specials, too. So glad we found this place. Will def be back!

Handlebar is an exceptional location in the summer on their patio, and only a notch lower in the winter without it. The staff tends to lean towards the side of rude and/or standoffish, but the food is really good and I can overlook a lot of that when I'm hungry... the black bean tostadas and the chili mac are especially helpful.  So, overall, stars off for the staff but still worth a visit!
Portland in Chicago? Yes. Bike themed and veggie/vegan dominant. Fries avocado tacos, buffalo chicken(seitan) wrap, tempeh po boy, greens. Good beer selection as well

I want to live here.   If I could only eat at one restaurant for the rest of my life, I would pick Handlebar.  This is the best place to go with friends or on awkward first dates (or terrible third dates), and no matter the circumstance (like on that terrible third date I almost flipped a table and punched the dude, he was the worst!), you'll want to keep coming back. The atmosphere is so comfortable and welcoming.  People say that the music is loud but I've never found it to be as such.  I find it to be music that I really like so maybe that's part of why it doesn't bother me. The drinks are amazing and plentiful.  They're reasonably priced, and the drink specials are things you will actually want to drink. The food is just perfect.  I don't think I've had anything there that I didn't like.  It's veggie comfort food, but you can still find something even a carnivore will like.  I highly recommend the nachos.  I dream about them.  I am not ashamed. I want so badly to come here for breakfast/brunch.  This is the perfect place to go when you're indecisive about what you want to eat or drink, or where you want to go.  It's like going home, but with better food and drink.

dropped by for breakfast and there a short wait for a table which wasn't bad. food was great and flavor of the food was awesome. i recommend the shrimp and grits or the biscuits and gravy. portions were great at 7-8 bucks an entree and the coffee tasted good. wait staff was pleasant and attentive. i'll be back.

Probably my favorite brunch places in Chicago.  So many good vegan options. The vegan diablos (seitan chorizo & tofu, hand-pressed corn tostadas, chipotle sauce, black beans, brown rice) is amazing!  The tostadas and chipotle sauce are worth the trip and a beer-mosa on a hungover sunday morning is always nice!

This is my first visit and I was pleasantly surprised. I didn't expect such a unique menu. The pepito omelet was delicious. The French toast was ok for me but my bf really enjoyed it. Service is easy going. We'll be back to try some lunch and dinner soon :)
This place is great!!! Had the fried avacado tacos and now I am craving them! everything was very well seasoned. And the oatmeal cream pie cookie is soooooooo good. I can't wait to go back!

This place is great! I've eaten here a few times. Hands down have the best fried pickles I have ever eaten. For my meal I just ordered the vegetarian chili cheese fries. Reasonably priced and I enjoyed the food as well as the atmosphere. It was nice out when I last went so my friends and I got seated in the patio area. Which was really cozy, and I loved the lighting. Definitely a restaurant all food lovers should try.

Sooooo good! We've been here 3 times within the span of 2 months, if that says anything about how much we like this place. The wilted kale salad is amazing, as are the fried avocado tacos. To be honest, those are the only things I've tried because they are both amazing! I'm dying to try some other things on the menu that sound delish, but I can't seem to tear myself aware from those standards. The plantains foster is probably the most delicious dessert I've ever tasted. Make sure to save room for it!  The restaurant itself is dimly lit and full of hipsters--my husband and I were definitely the dorkiest ones there. Because of the ambience, we were a bit nervous about bringing our two young kids with us, but nobody seemed to bat an eyelash (granted, we eat dinner at 5 pm, so there weren't many eyelashes to be found at that time). In fact, it is surprisingly kid friendly--they have high chairs and a changing table in the bathroom, which surprised me! Parking is super easy since there are not a ton of businesses on this stretch of North Ave. Prices are reasonable. All in all, quickly becoming one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago!

The food: Amazing vegetarian and vegan food.  Heavy on the meat substitutes but not  typical diner food either.  Have been here for dinner and brunch and it is consistently delicious.  I bring plenty of meat eaters here and have never heard a complaint.  Recommend the fried pickles, gouda mac and cheese, handlebar salad and the fried Avacado tacos. The biscuits and gravy, egg and sausage sandwich and diablos eggs are also tasty.  Good beer menu, rotates pretty frequently and they make a mean bloody mary - i always ask for spicy version :p Service:  friendly staff, relaxed and efficient Atmosphere: love the posters and the cycle centric decor. we bike everywhere so the rail out front by the window is handy to tie your bike up.  Patio is nice when it's warm.

Handlebar, you are AWESOME. The art on your walls is fantastic, your atmosphere is cozy and fun, and your food is wonderful. Which brings me to my question of the day: Why do so many vegetarian spots try to imitate meat with weird tempeh dishes when all they have to do is fry some pickles, put gouda on mac and cheese, and make a delicious black bean maduros?  Having grown up a vegetarian, I really hate vegetarian spots that come up with unnatural and overly-"healthy" dishes. No, I don't want quinoa with my tempeh on flax seed bread, thank you very much! Handlebar is definitely a different breed of vegetarian restaurant. First of all, Handlbar still serves fish, which I really appreciate. I know fish is not a sustainable food, but it IS a yummy food! And many vegetarians eat fish. Secondly, Handlebar doesn't try to compensate for the lack of meat by adding soy (and other such products) to every dish. They do have quite a few seitan, tempeh, and tofu options, but for the most part Handlebar is happy to serve straight up avocado tacos and veggie chili. I definitely recommend the black bean maduros and fried pickles.  Handlebar also has a pretty good beer and cocktail selection. And for those of you, like me, who are freezing from the evil Chicago winter, check out the spiked cider. It's not particularly strong, but it'll warm you up in no time!  I'll be back, Handlebar!

Excellent Vegetarian/Vegan Choices...I had the Tuna Steak Sandwich, and upgraded my side  to the Smoked Gouda Mac & Cheese.  Huge portions, very fresh ingredients and friendly service.  Next time I will try the Fried Avocado Tacos (Mmmmm)  :)

We were psyched to go to our favorite vegan spot for my 16yr old daughter's belated birthday dinner.  We arrived before rush hour since there were six of us, my husband and four kids, ages 9,10,14,16.  The host said he could not accommodate us immediately because we were too big a group, but I suggested and pointed to the 3, 2 seaters on the banquette.  He said no, manager won't allow it, we would have to wait.  I said, it's ok, you do not have to move any chairs around for us, let us just sit at those empty 3-2seaters.   He would not cave.  My husband pointed to two people taking up the back table reserved for larger parties, suggesting rules can be broken.  Still nothing.  Then he offered a 4 seater for the kids and placed my husband and I at one of the available 2 seaters on the banquette.  As I sat there, looking around, seeing my kids at a distant table, totally irritated because it occurred to me that we were not the right age of folk for the hipster crowd handle bar desired(although I would argue that as well: we are hipster enough, band playing, long or napoleon dynamited hair family).  I implored the host to just let the kids sit next to us and he basically dropped the ball and had another waiter come.  I nearly asked our family to leave but the dinner meant a lot to my kid.  Then, a jerk seated adjacent to us and next to the window (with an obviously exposed blurry tattoo) and his "hot" eurasian girlfriend told me that I was rude to the host who obviously was probably not even earning minimum wage.  We will never return and will instead go to the Chicago Diner, where the food and waitstaff is way better anyway.

This place was honestly so bland!  Had the fish tacos, guacamole & chips, & also we ordered the Po' Boy. 1st- the fish tacos had absolutely no flavor, the tortilla was a bit cold, they were just boring. It came with brown rice on the side, I barely took 3 spoonfuls because it was so grainy and flavorless.  2nd- the chips and guacamole... The chips were obviously store brought chips & the guacamole was alright 3rd- Po' Boy was not terrible, it was a bit too spicy, & that says a lot since I like spicy. The bread could of seriously used some toasting (it tasted like it was a bit old) The french fries were not bad.  But overall the food seriously could have used a kick of flavor, the lighting could have been turned up a little brighter (felt like we were eating in some cave), & the music was extremely weird.

I was here with three other people. Everybody had something different and we were all pleased. The beer selection is good. Inside the music can be loud, but we sat outside in the back and were comfortable. I ordered the blackened catfish, which was great.  I will certainly be back to Handlebar when I am in the neighborhood.

oh WHAT a disappointment! My friend & I walked in to have brunch this past  weekend, and were pleasantly surprised to be seated rather quickly, considering it is usually packed for brunch service. There was a bit of a delay with our server showing up, but after waving someone down, she arrived. We ordered & had more than an hour to spend, before we had to leave for an appointment. Our order was a simple no-brainer. 2x eggs, toast & potatoes. Our coffee came first & was tasty - what one would expect. Then my breakfast came, poached eggs, toast, and I had asked to sub broccoli for the potatoes. No problem. I started eating, so my food wouldn't get cold, and shared some with my friend while she waited for hers to come. It didn't come. Ever. After a good 20 minute wait, I again had to wave down the server, who was not very available - and ask where the other order was (WE ORDERED THE SAME THING!!!) - she said 'the kitchen messed up the order', and they'll fix it right away........... finally, after another 20-30 minutes, I had to wave down a different server all together, and asked for a manager - there apparently wasn't one available. REALLY?! too hipster for management, I guess. Which is too bad, because this place desperately needs some! We waited.....and waited.....and I finished my meal, and we still waited.....and the server just never bothered to come back. So ONCE again, we waved her down, and she came to say she was checking on the order. We saw table after table get their food - and they were a lot more complicated orders than EGGS, TOAST, & POTATOES. WTH, Handlebar?! How on earth do you deal with a full house, dozens of orders, one on top of the next, when you can't even get a simple order out on time - with another one that's identical???!!! Needless to say, we were livid at this point. And if your point was to make sure that we don't come back - consider yourself 'mission accomplished'! And if you chose (which really you did) - to make sure our order was f*ed up, so we wouldn't come back because we weren't obvious hipsters with multiple tattoos, a ratty sock hat, military jacket, doc martin boots, and a full beard - well....you made your choice - a shitty, judgmental, biased choice - and for that you got no tip. And now you'll have this review to deal with, and we'll make sure all our friends never come back. Too bad you choose to learn the hard way, that you are the business that should treat ALL the paying customers with equal respect, and see that any problem at any time gets solved - or at LEAST apologized for....but no. FAIL.

I know this place has been around for a while, but I was new to the neighborhood and tried for the first time.  Great vegetarian find!  Food was amazing and the scene was a great eclectic mix of people.  The ONLY reason for 4 vs 5 stars was the volume of the music!  I know I am officially an old fart since I have complained about the loud music but we went for brunch on Sunday and the hard rock was just a little over the top.  That being said, do not let it stop you from checking out the great neighborhood gem!!!

hipster grundge. pretty much all the words needed to describe this place. there's a much larger seating area for food (it's a vegan restaurant) and a smaller space for drinking by the bar, but we came here just for drinks.  whiskey is a bit pricey relative to other bars around chicago, but i guess hipsters like to pay a lot for things.  they have great ciders on rotation, and the one we tried was perfect! like UK-grade cider! except we were told it's from Michigan. i will probably track that cider down at some point!  all in all, it's a relatively small space and is pretty chill, i can see it being great for conversation for small groups or a hipster couple, but for some reason it feels really grimy like i need to wash all my clothes afterwards if i feel like sitting down. i can definitely see this bar in NY, but it seems kind of out of place in Chicago. like vegans would get beat up in this city all the time. or they would just be really sad because they could never eat all the good pizza around, so they decide to congregate here instead in this dark, small bar. i would give it 4 starts but i feel like standard drinks and alcohol here for some reason are priced slightly higher.  maybe i need to give it another chance.
It is more of a restaurant than bar. The food is ok as is the drink selection. There is nothing bad with the place, there is just nothing to get excited about.

I cannot think of enough positive things to say about this vegetarian spot. The food is incredible, seriously, the best of anything I've ever had.  Recommendations Avocado Tacos (possibly the best thing on the planet) Bloody Hammer (with gin, this is absolutely imperative) Atmosphere is grand, and the servers are pretty hilarious folks. If you like good times, this might be the only spot for you.

I'd write a review of their food, but I'm not a vegetarian, and I don't care for meat substitutes. I personally feel it's a little pretentious to offer a "vegan and vegetarian" only menu, as I have yet to see a restaurant make it a point to put meat in everything just to make sure there wasn't a vegetarian item on the menu. The mixed drinks are kind of weak and also on the pricey side. The decor is nice though and the back patio is nice and relaxing, even though they close it long before they close the rest of the bar does.

Loved it! I haven't spent much time in the Wicker Park neighborhood, but we went as a group on the recommendation of friends and I'm glad we did. The most veggie friendly menu I've seen in a long time. It's vegetarian + Southern comfort + hipster all rolled into one. Awesomeness. We sat out back on the patio and enjoyed one of the last warm evenings of the fall and I can't recommend it enough.  Street parking was easy enough. Full bar. Good service. Clean bathrooms. All the basics.

Don't order the Old Fashioned. It tastes good, but it is $9 for only 3 to 4 sips. When we brought it up to the waiters, they got all tense and told us how it's made. They said it's an ounce and a half drink. Ohkaaaayyyyy! I thought an ounce and a half was a shot. Why not charge shot prices or make it bigger like every other bar? If you want a great Old Fashioned, go to the Matchbox.  So, because of their lack of receptivity to criticism, I decided not to remark on anything else. Unfortunately, the tone was set for the night, right out of the gates. Many times, the food can speak for itself and sort of make up for weird service, but it didn't on this occasion.  Here is my take on the food.  Nachos- chips were really stale. I guess that queso means cheez whiz. Also, I shouldn't have assumed that vegan/vegetarian means healthy.  Beet salad- that was decent. The horseradish dressing becomes too overpowering to finish the dish, though. (Lady Gregory's in Andersonville makes the best beet salad!!!)  Gouda mac and cheese- Excellent!!! Oatmeal cream pie with a side of ice cream- I could taste the salt in the oatmeal cookie. The cream in the middle tasted like butter. Why not leave the salt out of the cookie and make a vegan butter cream frosting? The $2 side of ice cream looked like it was scooped with a tablespoon and maybe measured 2 tablespoons. The waiter who was unreceptive to the drink issue, asked me how the dessert was, while looking into the ice cream dish. I lied and said it was great. Why? Because when you give honest feedback to a restaurant and they put it back on you, you don't want them to think you're all critical about everything. It's a small kitchen and I'd hate to think that they'd do anything to my food. I'm not saying they'd do that, but their reaction to the drink made me feel that they wouldn't care about what happened to my food.

To paraphrase Dr. Phil, you can be right - that an Old Fashioned is *technically* only an ounce and a half; or you can have a happy customer and actually fill the tiny little glass it came in. My Old Fashioned was three sips, not even kidding.  The glass they brought it in was only 2/3 full, and it was a tiny little glass.  At this point, I question if it even was an ounce and a half.  You chose to be right (although you weren't - see below).  You clearly don't want me as a returning customer, no need to worry about that. The fact that *two* waitstaff had a response to my complaint on the tip of their tongue leads me to believe that I'm not the only person who's complained, and they have their response at the ready.  Just a suggestion, if you have to have a response to customer complaints pre-prepared, maybe, just maybe, you should actually listen instead of trying to be right.  Also, since it's only an ounce and a half and some sugar (not how you make an Old Fashioned, BTW) why are you charging me cocktail prices - $9 - instead of shot prices? More I think about it, more I think you guys suck.  Food was okay, but the drink and the cheese whiz on the nachos sort of set the tone. P.s.:  a quick Internet search of Old Fashioned recipes averages 2 or 3 ounces, or 2 or three shots.  Just saying.

I was there with a group, we sat outside...nice patio area, and the fried pickles were fantastic. The service was horrible, the waitstaff hardly came to our table, and seemed uninterested in doing their job. I had the shrimp po'boy ....$12 for 3 shrimp on stale bread
amazing chili cheese fries! great draft beer selection, and friendly staff.

I'm not a vegetarian and I really LOVE meat like Ron Swanson. But this resto is OK. Came here looooong time ago because the hipster friends of my ex wanted to come here. The curry burger was good, but it will never be as good as the real thing. Again, suuuuper hipster place. I felt out of place there (maybe because I was also wearing non-vintage stuff). Try to avoid it if you can't stand them.

I loved the laid-back atmosphere. The vibe is relaxing. The wait staff is friendly. The service was just okay and the food was satisfying. I had the Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap and the Gouda Mac n Cheese. The wrap was really tasty but also really salty. The Mac was creamy and comforting but also salty.

This place is fantastic. They have so many yummy vegan options! I've only tried their breakfast options, like their biscuits and gravy, scramble, and french toast! They also have some great sounding lunch items. They have a really beautiful outside eating area that I would for sure take advantage of before old man winter hits! The price is reasonable and the servers are super helpful and nice!

Super hipster, I may have seen the incarnation of John Lennon there. They have PBR on tap....because of course they do and the avocado tacos are delicious. I would definitely come back!! By the way, always go with corn tortillas. Always.

A vegan/vegetarian bar?  I love it!  My boyfriend and I always have a hard time finding a good bar to go to because I'm a vegetarian and he isn't.  He always wants a burger and I get so tired of veggie burgers.  Don't get me wrong....I love a good black bean burger, but it gets old.  He found this place after some research but wouldn't tell me where we were going.  We came in and I was so excited when I looked at the menu!  Plenty of yummy vegetarian options for me.....and even some non-vegetarian options for him.  We started with the fried pickles and vegan ranch.  They were amazing.  I had the buffalo "chicken" wrap with a side of sesame broccoli.  My boyfriend had the fish tacos with a side of vegetarian chili.  Everything we had was fresh and full of flavor.  It was a cool summer night, so we sat on the back patio at the bar.  I recommend sitting on the patio on a nice night, because it's quiet and has a relaxing ambiance.  Great service, great food......definitely recommend this place for anyone looking for a bar with a cool atmosphere and healthy eats.

If you're skeptical about the quality of vegetarian and/or vegan food, come to Handlebar. There will be something for you.  Favorite items: Fried Pickles w/ Vegan Ranch - The cornmeal breading was crisp and not at all mushy like many fried pickles and the vegan ranch was honestly better than any regular ranch I've had. Very zesty and garlic-y. Ground Nut Stew - This is great in the winter. A GIGANTIC bowl of a delicious sweet, spicy (healthy) stew. Add just a little salt and you're good to go. Tuna Sandwich - simply tasty. They have great options for sides, too. The fried plantains are pretty good. I come here for brunch mainly - can't go wrong with eggs. The Diablo dish is very tasty with corn cakes that are like sopes. Drinks - all kinds of tasty drinks. Splurge for the Trifecta - It's a glass of guinness with a shot of espresso and a shot of Jameson. Delicious. It is perfect for brunch, and the Jameson sort of fades into the background leaving you with a nutty, coffee/beer combo that just wins.  The sloppy joe's are a little too sweet for my taste, but the overall menu is great. Fun outdoor area in the back.

Came here with friends it was our first for all of us.  We were visiting from out of town and it rocked!! From the ambiance to the staff, the music, the beer choices, the food. When I move to Chicago it will definitely be a place I frequent!!

I'm not a vegetarian but I play one on TV - by that I mean I eat meat, happily, but infrequently.  Vegetarian is my preference, fish to follow, meat coming in third.  So veggie friendly places knocking out fun food and booze are my type of joint.  I sound like Guy Fieri.  Guy Fieri would love this place though, because it does have a little bit of an "edge" in terms of decor/atmosphere.  Let's move on. It took me an eternity to decide what I wanted because I literally wanted everything, but finally got the Chili Mac Attack.  I think it was on speical that night, so could not refuse.  It didn't disappoint!  Veggie chili with smoked gouda - I mean impossible to go wrong right there.  The chili was great but didn't feel full of veggies (difference between something being "vegetarian" and loaded with vegetables!) so I ordered a side of sesame broccoli.  I believe it was steamed, the florets coated lightly with delicate sesame flavor. They have a fantastic patio out back, you can't see the street and you can pretend you're far away from the hustle and bustle.  Fortunately Handlebar is far enough down North Ave that it isn't really noisy anyway - I worried we'd walked past it several times!  I was just admiring the "House Rules" on their website - "If there is a line of hungry people out the door, we will ask for your table after you are finished" and "When the patio is open, our seating capacity doubles.  Our kitchen capacity doesn't."  I love that!  I love that they are just putting it right out there - they're a small restaurant/bar doing their best to make fresh, good stuff, and they don't like rude patrons.  I can get behind that attitude. I'd come back anytime for more veggie goodness!

I came here with a bunch of veggie friends. and in a way i feel bad that this place is now known to be a veggie place, since it has great food in general, not just for veggies. cos really, i love my meat and I could eat here constantly.  Yes you are looking at hipsters serving you, and yes, the place is a little random. I came here in feb and they had halloween stuff stull up. Additionally we were nformed that there was no resverations, that there was no list, we just had to 'wait till you see a table and then grab it". with 6 people, I can bet you that isnt easy. We had to stare down a table and grabbed 2 little seats near it, so by luck we had seating. Whew. On to the food.  We tried the Diablos and the Country fried portabella. I have to say that the Portabella won me over completely, but had really stiff competiton form the Diablos. I would get both anytime I go there, it just depends on your sauce and egg preferences. The tomato sauce on the diablos was incredible, but the portabella comes breaded and with a cream sauce too so it really is up for either to win.  I'll be back to try the rest though!
heaven for a vegan! fried pickles with vegan ranch dressing? yes please! a bit crowded but no wonder given the service and foods. how to convince them to open a satellite spot in the háve?

I've lived around the corner from here for years and loved it every time I've gone any time of day. Great Old Fashioned's, $2 draft Pabst and $1 pabst on Mondays.  Awesome staff/service and a really cozy back patio.  I will, however, forever miss $1 Malört Mondays.
I have been here several times and it is consistently impressive!  There are plenty of vegan options too!
Pretty good mmm... food. Mac attack.
Worst food in Chicago,never going back there.Terrible place,staff is nice but food is a nightmare.

After reading about Handlebar in VegNews I had to try it. They have some great fried vegan foods. Not healthy but wonderfully delicious.  Fried pickles- Must order. They bread them in cornmeal then deep fry. Perfect.  Fried avocado tacos- Perfect taco. Fried avocado is awesome. They nail the salsa and dressing on this. The only drawback is that you can not order it before 3PM. Fried blueberry pie - Fantastic dessert. Takes you right to the boardwalk or the fair.  Handlebar is the place to get something to eat if you are in Wicker Park.
Samosas, maduro, and fried avocado tacos were all amazing! Favorite vegetarian spot in the city! Great drink specials and awesome outdoor patio.

I was pleasantly surprised with this place. I'm not a vegan nor a vegetarian, but I felt like the meals had great flavor, and I didn't miss the meat. My friend and I had the Green Meanie sandwich and the Avocado Tacos... both were delicious, and I would definitely recommend getting the Gouda Mac as your side.  Fabulous! DO sit on the patio if you can. It's so nice and shaded, and I really felt like we were eating at a friend's house on the patio. DON'T get the Bloody Mary though. They make their own mix, but I thought it was a bit bland. I added a ton of hot sauce to it, and it still wasn't the greatest.

Handlebar is probably my favorite restaurant in Chicago.  Their food is always amazing, it's a low-key environment, and seriously, order the Bloody Hammer with a miller high life pony.  I could have one anytime, anyday.

This is a really solid place.  The outdoor seating area out back is great and the food s tasty too.  Last time I went, my friend and I went for the Sunday special -- a shot of tequila, a Tecate, and two veggie tacos for $10.  Sweet deal and yummy to boot. Despite what it seems like, there is no 3 tattoo minimum to enter the establishment, though hipster cred is a definite plus.

One of the better vegetarian and vegan restaurants in the city. (I tend to compare Chicago DIner, Native Foods, and Karyn's when thinking of vegan and vegetarian.)  The Pepito Scramble was delicious and they sure don't skimp on the vegetables. I also appreciate that they don't charge you an arm and a leg when asking for the fruit vs potato substitution. A very laid back atmosphere with an equally laid-back wait staff. Everyone working there is what you would expect to see in the Wicker Park neighborhoods with piercings, long hair, and tattoos. The music is loud, but not obnoxious. Although they serve a variety of liquor like a normal bar, the food is mainly vegetarian and vegan with a couple of seafood choices thrown in.   (Channeling Terminator) "I will be back"

Diverse vegetarian and vegan friendly menu including breakfast items (til 3 pm), sandwiches, salads, and entrees. Sandwich and scramble we tried were good, well seasoned. Relatively cheap: prices are somewhat less than Native Foods. Basic furnishings, art on the wall, tattoed and pierced staff give this place a hipster vibe.

Another wonderful night at the Handlebar! Seven of us stopped by tonight for dinner. While waiting for our stragglers to arrive we sat at the bar. Great service & delicious drinks. We later moved to a table in the adorable outdoor area, which I had never eaten in before. It was a rare (at least this year) perfect summer night and the patio was wonderful. Service was prompt and the food was excellent. I had the Chicago style tofu, as did another member of my party, and though neither of us could figure out what was Chicago style about it, it was very good. My husband loved the fish tacos, too. Everyone was pretty happy with their food, and I'm left a little saddened by the fact this is so far from my current hood. I love Lincoln Square, but I don't make it down here enough!

Worst old-fashioned I've ever had. The bartender went overkill on the garnish by added 3 orange slices, and two were disgustingly old. Ridiculously slow service. Bland fish tacos. Bland and dry brown rice. At least it was cheap.

Handlebar doesn't rely on the seitan gimmicks most other veggie friendly places overuse. Try the fun, cool salmon cakes on special. Beware of the bartender who professes a knowledge of villainry...He's plotting something big, something that could destroy the douchiest aspects of Wicker Park. Jose Canseco was right.
Was surprised with this place, walked in with no expectation and became a fan instantly with my first bite....

Favorite vegetarian dish on the planet - Black Bean Maduro w/Avocado! Every time I go there I want to try something else but the dish is so tasty, I can't resist.                 My Non-Veg. Friends live 4 the dish!

My friend and I met here after work (around 6pm) on a Friday. It wasn't busy. we ordered drinks from the bar, after the bar tender ignored us for a while and seemed more interested in chatting up his coworker than serving customers. Then we asked one of the employees if we could sit at an empty table (there were many empty tables at this time). He said we could not sit there because it was for 4 people. Ok, no problem, makes sense,  so we sat at a 2 top, high top table. We were then basically harassed for the next 20 minutes while we drank out drinks by 2 employees that were telling us we couldn't stay there. We said, "We can move if you need the table". We were going to order appetizers and we decided not to spend any more money at this crappy place. Very disappointed. They need to train their employees much better. I wont be back!

A much sought-after vegetarian favorite in Chi-Town! We ended up getting here for a late lunch while starved on a Saturday and were pleased to be seated immediately without having to wait. Street parking was a piece of cake too, as there were plenty of open spots within a block. Between the two of us, we ordered the biscuits and gravy and the vegan breakfast burrito. I have to say, the biscuits and gravy just blew. my. mind. Each spoonful made my little gustatory receptors tingle with joy, craving for more... and more.... and more!  I specifically ordered the VEGAN breakfast burrito in anticipation of the delightfully flavored mock-chorizo - and it did not disappoint in the least! Also since I will eat anything that has cilantro in it, I gobbled up the burrito in a few bites (annoying my closely situated neighbors, no doubt). I will have to go here again, so I can try every item on the menu.

This is one of the 4 places that i have heard are the places every veggie should go to in chicago for their options and taste. I definitely think that this place does not disappoint in taste but does let you down in options and pricing. I went here on a saturday afternoon for brunch and this place was bustling and felt like a stadium. I ordered a beer and vegan sausage and wheat biscuit. my wife ordered the vegan chorizo burrito. we decided on these two items because everything else seemed pretty standard veggie fare which you can get at other places as well. I was not disappointed with my choices and i loved my order and would recommend it to anyone. after having finished my meal i felt like i had swallowed a brick of concrete and i really felt satisfied and full. My wife's order was also good and the spiciness is what i expected chorizo to taste like. It too was a large portion and she felt like she could not take another sip of water after finishing her food. I have to say from their website i was expecting a few more beer options and felt let down.  Their prices for after 3PM seemed on the pricey side and unreasonable. The place itself is small and seating can be at a premium at the peak of brunch. The service was nothing special but nothing to complain about. I would really like to rate this place higher as what i had was tasty, but the lack of options in brunch and the prices after brunch will probably keep me away from this place.

Handlebar was probably the last place I'd ever eat, if I had a choice. But one day, I decided to try it with a friend of mine who would not shut up about it. I ended up enjoying it and have gone back numerous times always trying a different item on the menu. Handlebar is a very good place to eat. The prices are reasonable and the menu isn't too crazy. The menu is easy to read and everything has a description. It's not too large of a restaurant but it isn't loud either, given you go on a Monday afternoon versus a Friday evening. But that's a given. Even so, I didn't feel like other tables were a part of my friend and my conversation.  Some negatives. Unfortunately, yes, there are some negatives. I have never had prompt service at Handlebar. The first time I went, the waiter was fantastic. Very attentive and on top of everything. After that though, the downfall. They'll take your order, bring you your food, and then your check. That's about it. I'm all for being left alone while I eat and I can thank a server greatly for that, but when I am obviously looking for my waiter because I need something, that reflects poorly. This has happened twice now with the staff and it's funny because the two negative occurrences have happened when it's not busy and my great experience happened when it was packed. Weird. The important thing is that the food is phenomenal. The service could use some work, and I don't put that lightly. I guess just save Handlebar for a day you aren't in the greatest mood and want something awesome to eat. You'll be left alone and enjoy what you ordered all in one sitting.

Even before I lived in Chicago, Handlebar was one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  With a solid menu, cool atmosphere (unless you hate hipsters), and a sweet patio, this place never fails to make me happy.   Their pescetarian menu is big and wonderful (although you can't get some items at certain times of day).  Heavy on the comfort food (shrimp and grits!), but still offering some lighter options (try the Everything Green salad!!!), it is sure to please everyone, from vegan to carnivore. The service can be a little off when this place gets busy, but everything else more than makes up for it.

Positives:  My favorite french fries out of all the vegan restaurant's I go to, nice bike theme, good music selection, oatmeal cookie sandwich!!!, vegan junk food :-)  and healthy food, too, dimly lit, friendly service, reasonably priced! Negatives:  dimly lit, slow service, usually there is a long wait to be seated, the music is too loud (I personally don't dig sports bar, clubby so ridiculously loud music I can't have a conversation to the person next to me), hipster territory. Bottom-line:  I can't wait to try there breakfast sometime and I think almost anyone who tries it once would want to turn repeat customer.

I went on a Saturday and was meeting up with a group (6 plus a baby) and unfortunately the rest of my party was 45 minutes late. So they told me I could sit at the bar and wait which was fine...I obviously wouldn't have sat one person in a party of six either. They offered me a drink menu but I had to work later so I wasn't drinking and I felt like one of the guys who was there immediately wrote me off (a non-drinker, waiting for a party of maybe 6). But another guy was pretty cool. I got a hibiscus iced tea and waited. My friends eventually showed up and as they arrived another party of 5 started getting there. I was a little annoyed because I had previously been told that there was a table that was available outside and even though they were late, my party was completed before their party was, but somehow they got the outside table.  So that's why I'm taking the star. But otherwise, it was good. I really appreciated the pescetarian menu. I'm a full on meat eater, as were the rest of my part other than the vegetarian birthday girl so between fried pickles, shrimp and grits, eggs and toast and an omelet, and biscuits and gravy all the meat eaters were very satisfied.  The place is filled with hipsters and I would definitely go back again. I'm not really a fan of fake meat-since I eat real mean, I don't really need to have an imitation. So I'm glad that there are several things that I would really be interested to try!

Service is slow, music is too loud, interior lighting too dark, food is decent. Similar to Native Foods, this place creates a vegetarian (and perhaps vegan)-friendly menu, but I think does a better job than NF.  Native Foods has overpowering flavors and is heavy in the sodium department.  Handlebar has more "ethnic" food options (tofu sambal, fish tacos, etc) -- and overall has more tofu options, than just tempeh and fake meat.  In general, the food is pretty decent, nothing to write home about, but it's definitely a safe option for vegetarians. The main point deductions were the things I mentioned at the beginning of this review.  We had dinner there, and it was simply too dark to see anyone at the table.  Either turn up the lights or add candles or something.  Next, music is just too loud for any productive conversation.  There is a bar in the restaurant, but 80% of the place is, in fact, a restaurant.  I personally don't like to yell over dinner.  The waitress was quick and anxious to take our order, but I don't understand how it took so long for our food to come out.  We were literally twiddling our thumbs and drinking water for quite some time.

To be honest, I was a bit wary of eating in a vegetarian friendly / vegan restaurant. However, Handlebar made my stay quite pleasant and yummy. I had the Chicago style Tofu sandwich. Can I just say....delicious. Pesto and aioli slathered tofu, pickled cauliflower (it tastes amazing, don't judge), and crispy yet fluffy bread. Get this with a side of crisp green beans...you are GOLDEN. It also comes with a pickle, but the sandwich was so flavorful, I didn't touch it.  The only downside? We had to get seating outdoors when the weather was a bit nippy, since people had reservations at the bar. Otherwise, pleasant stay with a great selection of brew specials.  I want to come back for the breakfast til 3pm. Their breakfast menu takes up the entire back page of the menu. Fantastic baby.
The bike rack by the sidewalk has been repaired and looks very hip. =)

Bad-ass vegetarian food, BAD-ASS.  I love the taste of most things on the menu, but especially the bbq seitan sandwich, I dream about that. The only downside of this place is that it's kinda crowded ALL the time, so a wait is common here.

Handlebar really is some of the best vegetarian food in the city, and the Chicago Style Tofu is outstanding. My concern here is about the Sesame Broccoli. For years, it was wonderful and salty in the best way, but in two recent visits it's become bland and undercooked. If you revised the recipe to make it healthier and actually taste like a vegetable your mom had to force you to eat - it's working.

This was my first time checking out a vegetarian/vegan joint and loved it.  They have some seafood items, but it's mostly all about the veggies and seitan.  I was on a quest to finally try some seitan, but other stuff just sounded too good so I'll pig out on seitan sausages next time... well if I like it. Inside it can get a bit noisey with all the chatter and music, but they also have a sweet back patio if you prefer something quieter.  I'll prob check that out next time. They have a nice beer list filled with a lot of unique brews and a handful of beers on tap, like 3F Pride & Joy.  We started with some Samosas, which were tasty with that kickass tamarind chutney and some spicy cilantro yogurt.  The Smoke Gouda Mac was a bit dissapointing.  I could tasty the smokiness, but it was nowhere near cheesy enough.  I also tried the Chili Mac Attack, which was just okay. My favorite of the night for sure were the Fried Avocado Tacos - woah tasty.  The creamy & crunchy fried avocados and the zesty salsa verde made the perfect combo.  Good stuff. I'll be back for sure, especially since my buddy is a vegetarian.  I have to try that seitan!

This is our go-to spot on (usually) Sunday morning. My husband and I love the food and don't have to worry about my food restrictions (I can't eat eggs for allergy reasons and I've stopped eating meat). We usually split the breakfast special and maybe add a side or two. The fried pickles are also awesome, and I have my husband order the bloddy hammer so I can have the fried pickle that comes with it. I took my mom here for a late lunch and she really liked her green meanie sandwich (spicy mustard omitted) and also loved the fried pickles.  The reason I give it 4 stars is they don't always seat appropriately during busy times. We brought 2 visiting friends and it took 45 minutes to seat us on a Sunday when they said 20 minutes. They kept seating 2-person parties instead of putting 2 of the 2-tops together. I've seen this since, but I'm always sitting from the comfort of a full belly. So be prepared to wait a long while if you're over 2 people. The other reason is that sometimes the tofu scrambles don't have enough greens for me and are a little too salty. But seriously, a favorite restaurant of mine!

I was really excited to come to Handlebar because I was told on multiple occasions by different people that it is a "great vegetarian or vegan option". Though it is vegetarian/vegan, I found everything to be standard in quality and flavor and very expensive.  We had the shrimp and grits - $14 for 5 small pieces of shrimp and a ton of buttery grits. The fish tacos were the best option - at $12 - but also just catfish. We also got the loaded mac and cheese, which was tasty but the gouda cheese was overpowered by everything else.  Overall, I get the idea of vegetarian comfort food; I just don't think it is worth the dollar to come here.

I don't know what took me so long to get here, but I'm glad I finally did.  We came in at 2:00 on a Saturday afternoon and there was no wait.  Free street parking right outside too.  Good service and a great beer list.  I ordered the Green Meanie sandwich and it was delicious!  The fries were a touch on the room temp side, but whatever.  I love the laid back vibe here and look forward to checking out their patio this summer.  Also, I hear they have the best Bloody Mary around.  They serve brunch/breakfast until 3:00 p.m. which is another plus.

Hey, I liked it!  I went there last night with a couple of friends.  One is a vegetarian, the other isn't.  They had both been there several times before and thought enough of it to keep coming back.  I started off with the hibiscus tea and vodka.  It was light and refreshing, and one was enough to prevent going into sloppy territory.  I got the Chicago style tofu.  I know tofu in its natural state is rubbery and bland, but between the pesto, the Dijon mustard, and the giardinera, the sandwich was bright and flavorful.  There were also shredded carrots, greens and tomatoes on it.  The bread was also a tasty foccacia.  My mouth liked it and my tummy left happy.  I'd go back!

I SO was not expecting such deliciousness. Food was great. Very flavorful and the right portion. I had the bbq seitan wrap. Not your typica wrap, waaaay better. The sauce was so good that I didn't want my eating experience to end. Service was good, which made the the meal even better. Waitress was not pushy and showed up when you needed her. Will definitely be back and cant wait! You gotta try this place.

Wish I loved it more!  I think Handlebar must get great reviews because of its bar scene- the food is just OK (though I want to rate it higher because it's vegetarian/vegan friendly, but I won't.  More and more veggie places are coming out; we don't have to handicap them any longer!  Hurrah!). Grabbed brunch here last weekend with a friend.  It's always wait to be seated so far as I can tell, but the place is small enough that everything is visible (except the back patio).  Host told us there was a chance of rain so we opted to stay inside.  Got the pepitas scramble with eggs and a slice of french toast.  The pepitas scramble is fine, it has kale, poblano peppers, red bell peppers, crispy fried onions, and sweet potatoes scrambled with either eggs or tofu and topped with a pesto of some sort.  The pesto was actually great; I wish the dish came smothered with pesto instead of dabs.  The rest of it tastes like something I'd make at home for brunch on a weekend, not pay someone else to make for me.  Comes with toast (ours was not toasted...) and breakfast potatoes (a little dry). French toast was pretty yummy but not amazing.   Went again for lunch today, thought we'd have a quick lunch to start the workweek.  There were a few tables there which seems like a good sign.  I love hipsters, but the service here is hipster if you know what I mean.  We ordered immediately- the pepitas again (thought we'd try it with tofu this time) and the Monday special of Chili Mac Attack!- the smoked gouda mac n cheese that yelp loves, topped with chili, tortilla chips, sour cream, salsa.  Pepitas was just as disappointing as the first time (I was hoping for soft tofu but it comes with extra firm cubes that are sauteed), and the chili mac, while a great concept, didn't quite work: the chili and mac seem good separately, but the mac isn't cheesy/strong enough to complement the chili.   Honestly I like the mac at Mac's better (add spinach and tomato, yum!) or the Bedford (onion breadcrumbs).  Wish I loved handlebar more; the vibe is awesome, but the food/service aren't.

I go to this place for brunch basically every weekend. The biscuits and gravy are fantastic, and the fried pickles to die for (the dipping sauce is where it's at). I agree that sometimes it seems like the servers are inattentive and slow, hence 4 stars instead of 5. But the food is good, the vibe is good, and I usually have a great time here. Thanks Handlebar!

OK, so I think my meal deserved more like 3.5 star-rating.  We ordered the Handlebar Omelet - which included walnuts and pears - and the Chimichanga - which looked and tasted more like a breakfast burrito and included scrambled eggs and refried black beans (I wanted to order off the Entrée menu rather than the Breakfast menu, but that wasn't an option since we were there around noon). The Omelet was a little too dry for me and came with lukewarm potatoes, but the dish was good enough. The Chimichanga was covered in a guajillo sauce, whatever that is, that was just OK, but the dish was better than the Omelet. Even though I wasn't blown away by the food, I liked the hipster atmosphere and plan on going back some time -- most likely when they're serving their Entrée menu.

Buffalo "Chicken" wrap!!!! Say it with me.  Its the best. I go here a lot. And i know the menu well. However, the last 20 times i have gone, i get that one thing, because when it is perfect, you cant move past it Smoked gouda mac and cheese!!!! Amazing.  Chili mac!!!!! Amazing  The could get better desserts. But I am stuffed from buffalo chicken and mac and cheese, that i couldnt eat dessert anyway.  Coffee is pretty awesome also.  I used to live around the corner and never went here, now i live in the burbs and drive 30 minutes for it.

I finally made it here for brunch (and it didn't hurt that I had a $20 gift certificate) on the first day that they opened up their newly redone patio. Tons of room and sun out there and a great atmosphere! I ordered the vegan diablo and it was so yummy! Really hit the spot and was seasoned very well! Loved the black beans and brown rice, and the combo of the sause with the hand made corn tostadas and tofu! Really unique take on breakfast! Can't wait to go back!

The bananas foster ginger bread with ice cream dessert was the best dessert I ever ate in my life. And even the ice cream alone would have been the best dessert I have ever eaten.  Entree portions are huge; be ready to take stuff home.  Place is pretty busy. Perhaps a Handlebar II  ?  I will def.. be back here!

Handlebar has recently become my default place to go when I don't want to deal with the question, "where should we go eat?" I have never left there dis-satisfied with what I've ordered. I especially love the catfish tacos, their chili Gouda mac, and their fried pickles. I can't wait to go there for breakfast.
Service is OK, the seitan (which everyone recommended) was meh and i thought the chard leaves were monstrously large.   Overall it's an OK place and you can take your weird veggo friends there.

I live down the street from this health conscious, pescaterian joint and eat here often. Everything I've tried has been awesome; I get something different every time. My favorite is the plantain & black bean stack (not sure what its called). I've never tasted anything like it. They have a very good craft beer selection, daily specials, and the staff is good people.

My Fiance and i went here for Brunch, she is a vegetarian and has been wanting to try this place.  I was a little hesitant about the no meat thing in my Biscuits and Gravy, but I would most definitely be back. The service was ok, I could tell they were really busy.  At the same time you don't go there for the service you go for the food. I would definitely go back especially for some of the drink specials.

Absolutely fantastic.  Went there again last night with a buddy for dinner, and they have the best creative dinner and drink menus.  Great vegetarian selection, cool layout, and awesome beats.  Very friendly staff with excellent service!

Handlebar is great because the food is really good and they have a lot of vegan options. The service on the other hand is so bad that I make sure to only come if I'm not really hungry or if I'm feeling like spending a couple hours waiting for a second beer (a good tip is ordering two at the same time). The waiters are usually hard to find and are typically really unpleasent. ...Except for that one time when my waiter was hammered. He was super friendly, friendly enough to forget to charge us for everything we ordered! But then (as drunk people tend to become), he was really mad, mad enough to yell unkind things pretty loudly behind the bar. Either way, I paid a lot less than expected so that's pretty neat.
The best veg-friendly place... EVER!  I love their pepita scramble for brunch or their ground nut stew for dinner... LOVE this place!
Vegan buffalo wrap is where it's at.  Also the ranch dressing is vegan!  Great selection of craft beer and an outdoor patio for those nice weather days!

Handlebar, I miss you so.  I moved out of Chicago a couple months ago and the place I miss the most in the city is Handlebar. What beats a a snowy Sunday morning brunch of bottomless coffee, biscuits and gravy and a bloody mary? Or even more so, a summer Friday afternoon drinking Tecate and tequila specials on the patio? Yeah, I thought so.

I found this place while looking up vegetarian restaurants in Chicago. Overall, it was fine, except for the service was a little off. The atmosphere is fun, covered in local band flyers and such, drawing a younger "hip" crowd. I had the buffalo 'chicken' wrap, smoked gouda mac n cheese, and fries. Everything was good. While paying the bill, I waited a bit to get more change so I could tip a few bucks more, but our server was too busy chatting it up behind the bar with the regulars, so we left. Other than the service, solid place and would go back again.

You know the hypothetical question of what your last meal would be, should you get to choose? Mine would be Handlebar.  Green Meanie, yes. Gouda mac and cheese, always. Handlebar salad, on point. Fried avo tacos, please. Pepe Ole or Schneider-weisse? Let's get both. Always has good music, and always pleases my carnivorous significant other (in fairness, he was the one who introduced Handlebar to me). I. Love. Handlebar. PS. Great year round, but summer on the patio is tops.

Food here was excellent, our waiter was nice and helpful. They have GF and Vegan selections clearly marked and my food was fantastic, worth four stars on that alone. The only problem (why the 2 star rating) we seemed to have was this extremely loud and obnoxious girl two tables away from us that clearly was intoxicated. I am a loud person but this girl made me look like a church mouse. She was definitely over-served and the waitstaff did nothing to slow down her alcohol consumption. Look, I can drink, and have been a bartender for many years but when tables are complaining and not one person says something to her, I have a problem. She seriously cleared out all the tables around her. I get that restaurants can be loud, and the restaurant was very busy, but even though the food was great in my eyes, I'm not sure if I will be back. It's sad that I can't even remember the specifics of my food, which was really good because of that experience.

Handlebar has quickly become one of my regular hungover brunch place after first being intorduced to it by a friend around two years ago.  It's causal vibe, enegry, outdoor patio, and fried pickles will leave you wanting more and more.  The service is pretty calm and pleasant -- nothing snooty or overly agressive here.   Their Bloody Hammer, which is a Bloody Mary with the fixin', sooo hits the spot.  I recommend starting off with this.  As for appetizers, I love the Chorizo & Black Bean Nachos.  I make it vegan by requesting the queso and sour cream on the side.   For entrees I am a fan of the Buffalo Chicken Wrap or the Green Meanie (I got this prior to veganism) The Smoked Gouda Mac is good and different -- make sure you really like the taste of gouda because it is really rich.   My only complaint is that the host can be a little awkward at times.  It is not very welcoming upon arrival. The host will ask you to wait until your whole party has arrived -- even when the place is empty (this must be a policy, but sometimes common sense and logic should take the place of a policy).   It's a little uncomfortable waiting by the front, I wish they would were more accommodating here, first impressions go a long way.    The food and drinks will make up for any bad first impression!  I really do love eating here!

Came here after seeing a play nearby, at Polarity Ensemble, with a crowd of eight actors and a playwright.  This is a relatively small storefront space, with a bar and perhaps a dozen stools, plus seating at mostly two-tops for another twenty-five or so.  But they were very nice in accommodating our (for this place) large group, by getting us into a corner with a long bench and several tables pushed together.  Had a very nice snifter full of Revolution Brewing's Zanate Imperial Stout ($7 draft), which  I understand was brewed specially for the Handlebar's 10th anniversary.  It was a very nice beer, not quite as good as the draft Goose Island Bourbon County Stout I drank a week ago up at Goose Island on Clark Street, but then again it was 3 bucks cheaper.  After sipping the Zanate, I then opted for a more reasonably priced gulping beer: a $2 PBR on draft, as a chaser. The host, waitress & busser couldn't have been nicer. The interesting menu was aimed very much toward vegan, vegetarian or non-red-meat eaters, which makes sense as a Wicker Park bicyclist place.  I didn't have any food here, though I noticed someone at the other end of our very long table had guacamole and chips.  I saw that the plate was practically licked clean, so it must have been good.  On the other hand, these were hungry actors after a show.

I have mixed feelings about this place: Infested with hipsters, but hipsters often leave a trail of tears to good food, beer, and music. Consistently bad service, but one time our waiter was so drunk he forgot to charge us for about half the items we ordered. Vegan-friendly for my ladyfriend and they have a great mac and cheese, super creamy with gouda (tastes like the good is applewood smoked aka tastes a little bit like bacon), the fried pickles were very solid as well. So to sum up, being vegan friendly and reasonably priced will have me returning from time to time despite the poor service and somewhat pretentious attitude inside.

I eat here regularly and am a big fan. Their brunch (served until 3pm) is especially great for vegans like me: they have the BEST vegan biscuits and gravy in Chicago. Yes, I have done a taste test at other vegan friendly Chicago spots and Handlebar wins. CROWDED: Be prepared to wait for a table. No reservations are available. There's a small bar that's usually pretty full, so it's not really a waiting option. Be ready to stand near the front door if you come at a busy hour like Sunday brunch or most evenings. In the summer they have outdoor seating in the back though.  ** they will not seat you until everyone in your party arrives** FOOD: I have never had a bad meal here. I'd recommend the vegan biscuits and gravy (blacked tofu optional), fried pickles with vegan ranch dressing, samosas, everything green salad, ground nut stew, buffalo chick'n wrap (spicy), green meanie sandwich, and the fried plantains. SERVICE: because it is so crowded, service can be slow but it's just par for the course at a popular spot. MISC: they have really big bathrooms, very wheelchair accessible, bike racks out front and there is unmetered (and usually plentiful) street parking out front.

LOVE! Great beer, great food, always. I've never been disappointed. The black beans maduros are spicier than hell, but so tasty. The buffalo chicken wrap is the bomb dig, along with their pesto tofu sandwich. I'm currently rattling off all the things I am craving, but I can assure you, whatever you order will be delicious. And they have great beers. Even if you aren't veg, you'll enjoy the party in your mouth here. GO! Oh wait, only go with 1 or 2 of your closest friends because seating is limited; make sure you arrive together or you'll have to wait to be seated until your whole party is present! NOW GO!

Was recommended this place by a vegan friend as her favorite spot, knowing that I like spice, particularly for the BLACK BEAN MADURO  yelp.com/biz_photos/hand…  and there was no disappointment. Black beens with brown rice, on fried plantians in a spicy chipotle sauce (vegan cheese and avacodos optional).  It sounded simple when I heard it but the dish had so much deapth and flavor.  I'm generally not a fan of brown rice but everything went together so well.  I like vegan food but I usually not a fan of fake meat and the great thing is with such a well composed dish, there's no need to order fake meat (but it's there if you want it). Also, got a side of the SMOKED GOUDA MAC & CHEESE  yelp.com/biz_photos/hand… Nice well done smoked gouda taste. The ambiance is very trendy and this place was packed through 11:30pm.  It's great that they serve food so late so you can always grab a late night bite.  Would definately like come back and try other things on the menu like Country Fried Portobello.

Came here for lunch today and some things were awesome some things were so-so some things were shit. Decor was very hipster but adorable. Lots of awesome art on the walls. From the outside, the banner would make me think that it's a creepo bar, but it proved me wrong. As for the food, some things that we ordered I loved, some things were ehh. The french toast was good sometimes, but then other bites would be super burnt....would not order again because the good parts were just mediocre. I can make better french toast toast... The biscuits and gravy were fab. Definitely didn't taste like the usual ones but I love seitan so that sausage in the gravy was great. The country fried portobello was deeeeeeelish. The portobello was oh-so juicy and the gravy was spicy and different. The potatoes on the side were eh, not much spice or flavoring. I didn't like the collard greens, but my friend was a super fan. Also didn't like the blackened tofu, but he loved every single thing on the plate.  I got an Americano which was pretty good, and it was awesome to be able to get soy milk on the side. (I asked for almond, which they didn't have. I try not to eat soy products.) He got an espresso and seemed happy. Where they failed: service. Actually, the servers at the other tables were fantastic. Our server, not so much. She never came back once to ask how we were. Every time I wanted water, and when we needed a spoon and wanted to order coffee, we had to flag someone down. The spoon and a water were brought by other employees who should be making tips off of their tables....she had a sass about her too which I thought was pretty rude. The other gentlemen who were serving/busing were very kind and helpful, however.

I stopped at Handlebar on my way home from a friends this morning. I got the breakfast burrito with chorizo added, breakfast potatoes, and they gave me a small order of black beans as well, I'm assuming it came with it. Everything was absolutely awesome, and as this is my first time here, I gave it 4 stars, and will rate higher the more things I try there. The burrito was huge and freshly made and the tortilla was awesome and really pulled it all together.

Let me just say right now that I love a big hunk of meat.  Bacon, burgers, filets: I love them all.  However, I don't discriminate, and I have some vegan and vegetarian friends.  This place is great at pleasing all of us.

Handlebar's food was delicious. I had the black bean maduro. The portion size was great. And each bite had some of the delicious ingredients in it. The entire time I was eating I kept thinking this is my new favorite spot. And then I got food poisoning. I will never come back here again.

I've been a frequent customer of Handlebar for 7 years. The food is always good, and I never feel it is over priced. Drinks are good, service is good. I love the back patio when its nice out.  I love the chili mac attack, its my new fave. The brunch is awesome. This is my go-to brunch place in the city. I bring friends here from out of town all the time. I love that they have gluten free options for my younger brother. I love the breakfast burrito with seitan chorizo. I used to go with a bunch of friends Friday after work for $5 car bombs. They always have a good drink special. $5 tecate and a shot of tequila everyday! Good coffee here too! Seriously go here, enjoy your food, drinks and the prices!

Came here with a few friends before a concert. The buffalo 'chicken' wrap was amazing - holy house-made ranch. Absolutely delicious. Can't wait to go back to try some of the other dishes.  The selection of beer was good. Our table had an assortment of drinks and it turned out to be very cheap (considering they were taking shots of patron). Also, we paid the bill and reopened 20 minutes later when we found out the concert was cancelled. Our server gave us a small discount on the second bill with a little note that said "sorry your concert was cancelled". Didn't make a huge monetary difference but was a very nice gesture.  The only annoying thing - couldn't get a table until my entire party had arrived and the restaurant was basically empty.

I came here after work on a friday. We had ppl meeting us. We ordered for them ahead of time since the kitchen was closing in 15 mins. We waited for our food for 25 mins. Once it came out our friends were not there yet. The server says I hope they come in time if not here is boxes. What!? He threw boxes down. I get that they were closing soon but people were still at the bar.  The only reason I gave this place 2 stars is because the food was delish. 2 bites in he put down the bill and stood behind the bar and stared at us. Im a server, as much as when u want your last table to leave, you dont hurry them and make rude comments to get out. Our friends came and had to scarf their food down. They started putting up the chairs and we had enough. I also guess they are not open till 2 like yelp says. Good food, worst and uncomfortable service. We wont be back

YUM!  going to be my new go-to-spot in the neighborhood. I can't believe I finally came into the Handlebar after hearing so much about it for so long. It's delicious! A perfect casual neighborhood spot...very hipster and young. Tuna sandwich was bomb, add the avocado on it for sure!  Will be back...will do take out....this is a new deep relationship about to commence...
(Vegetarian Review) Good appetizers and drinks.. but just about average entrees.  Has a real interesting decor though.

Nice place but a little on the dark side at dinner.  And by dark I mean it's hard to read the menu.  Also a little loud for comfortable conversation and fairly tight on seating.  Probably better to go early when it's not as crowded. But the food was good!  I tried the tuna steak sandwich and collard greens.  This is one of the very few places I've been to that don't  severely overcook their greens, so fear not the stereotype. The tuna steak sandwich was really nice.  I forgot what kind of sauce they had in there, but I wished there was more because it was really good.  If I got it again, I'd definitely ask for some on the side.

I'll start by saying my review is mainly for customer service, since I've not had much to eat or drink here. Some of the staff are way too "hip" to give a shit that you are there to support their business. I met some friends here who were seated on the patio (which is in the back and pretty great) for a birthday gathering. The patio was closing, so we moved inside and grabbed a table right across from the bar. I don't know what was supposed to happen with our waiter, but he never came back and we never got a new one. I had to ask a busboy for a menu after a half hour and still no one came over, even though I saw, other tables being waited on by a gal who would look directly at us, I swear, and then turn away and keep chatting with her co-workers. So I ordered a drink at the bar. I don't remember which drink, it was a house special I believe, but it tasted like watered-down whiskey. Luckily when I took it back up, the bartender replaced it for free.  I will give props to one skinny dude who waited on us once. We decided, at his urging, to try the $1 malort shots, which I have heard described as tasting like rubber bands and rusty nails. It was pretty gross, not as bad as I expected, but fun to try a Chicago original. Anyway, he was down-to-earth and fun to chat with.  I also went for brunch once. I really only remember the biscuits and gravy, which were whole wheat and more of a turkey gravy (but vegan, with seitan) which is not what I expect from biscuits and gravy, whole wheat is fine, but I want a creamy gravy. One friend graciously finished his, saying it was "not bad" but another just picked at his and thought it was gross.  But the vegetarian chili cheese fries are good.  I'll go back only if a good friend is going and asks that I join, but never again of my own volition.

I love Handlebar and I make it a point to stop by at least once whenever I am in town. In the summer you can sit out back in the sun and the staff is very friendly and attentive.  All of the food is fantastic and they have a terrific beer list. Try the Buffalo Chicken Wrap. Even if you aren't a vegetarian you will probably love it. The seitan that they use is phenomenal.

Just came back from New Years Day brunch, and was thoroughly impressed.  We were sat after a minimal wait, which is always made easier by the presence of a bar (with bloody mary's!). The bloody was pretty standard and nothing to write home about, but it was a good "hair of the dog" to start the day with.  The food, however, was WELL worth noting and definitely warrants re-visiting. I got the vegan diablos breakfast, it was the perfect amount of spicy (i.e. enough to wake up your taste buds, but not enough to make you cry and spout a runny nose). The black beans and brown rice that came with were porportioned well and perfect side kicks for the main dish. It was also filling enough that I had left overs, which is basically unheard of, as I enjoy over-eating as much as most people enjoy breathing. Anyway, my boyfriend got the portabella omelet, which was made with fresh ingredients and came with some toast and breakfast potatoes. He said it was awesome. I cannot comment on the taste of the omelette myself, as I was neck deep in a food fantasy swimming through delicious chipotle sauce, and dense masa cakes.  While our waiter didn't stay around and chat, he was efficient, and very quick and friendly. We waited no more than ten minutes for our breakfast, despite it being was very busy.  Pros: Excellent food, good drinks, great service Cons: The place is crowded, can get pretty loud and is the definition of hipster

Vegan BBQ what more do I need to say. I went on a Saturday night. It wasn't too crowded, the service was good. The food came out quickly. I absolutely loved the BBQ seitan sandwich. This isn't strictly vegan, they also have vegetarian items on menu that include cheese. They also had a pretty good selection on tap.

First I must note this review is solely about the service received and nothing else. We arrived at the Handlebar late Sunday morning on November 18,  to a short line which included a couple waiting inside the door and a family waiting outside.  So we walk up to the door and notice there is a guy taking names for a waiting list.  Well we hear him tell the couple ahead of us it will take about 15 minutes.  At almost the same time the family that was waiting outside walks up behind us and the waiter walks between us with no acknowledgement at all that we were in line and proceeds to take the families cancellation.  He then walks back between us without one single word and walks away.  We see him walking around the restaurant serving food, taking orders to the kitchen etc.  I look at my boyfriend and say is he really ignoring us.  We give him the benefit of the doubt and wait for a few minutes.  Well during our wait a guy comes in and walks between us since we were standing in the doorway.  The same waiter makes a beeline over to him and asks for his name and tells him it will be a 15 minute wait.  I say to both of them we were here first.  The customer was gracious and apologized.  The waiter proceeds to take his name anyway.  He then asks for our name and tells us it will be a 1/2 hour wait and that we could sit at the bar if we want to.
