Now I am the person who gives everyone the benefit of the doubt even when I know people are rude.  This guy sucked!!!!  And while we were the only black people in the place at the time I refrained from going there as I truly want to still believe 'he' was just an F'in A'hole.  For the record, the guy at the bar was awesome and friendly and provided great service.  Thank God for him we will go back because my boyfriend is vegan and loved the food but if I see that guy again I probably won't be so nice.  I will take the opportunity and make the biggest seen ever and then call the police myself.

The service here is so awful. Ill never go back again.  We waited for a table for an hour and everybody after us got seated.  I was so appalled I spoke to the person who took our name and he pretended he knew nothing.  I left and ate somewhere else.   Theres better restuarants in the neigborhood where they dont treat you like dirt.

Handlebar makes me so happy. It's one of my favorite brunch spots in Chicago. Lovely waitstaff, awesome food and I can't get enough of the patio! I've been accommodated more than once while with a large group of people. Try to the fried pickles! Try a margarita! Try everything.

I can sum it up like this:  I can order a different vegan item every night of the week, and a different beer every night of the week, and can still have an excellent meal every night of the week, and I can't think of any other place about which I could say that.

Definitely one of my favorites in Chicago. Try the pepita scramble for breakfast/brunch, and for dinner, the black bean tostadas (appetizer) and the grilled fish tacos. I haven't tried everything on the menu here, but I've had enough to know that some dishes are far better than others. . . and the main reason this doesn't get 5 stars. But the great dishes are really great, and the others are still good. Pretty good margaritas too :)

Came here over the weekend for dinner. We were a party of 3 and got seated immediately.  $3 Tecate? Yes please. We started with the hush puppies, which were a special appetizer of the day. Really tasty.  At the table we ordered the buffalo chicken wrap, the greenie meanie sandwich, Gouda mac and cheese, seitan sausage, and the handlebar salad with pesto tofu. Everything was really tasty, especially the mac and cheese and sausage. My salad left a bit to be desired- it wasn't as flavorful as I would have liked. But they do get props for homemade tofu.  Service was a little spotty, but it is a casual place that is conducive to sitting around and throwing back a few Tecates and catching up with friends.  I am not a vegetarian, so if I was I imagine I would come here more often. But when I want veggie/ vegan, it's so hard for me not to vote Native Foods.

I can't get enough handlebar! Their brunch is one of my favorite in the city because of the relaxed atmosphere and inspiring yet familiar menu.  Great beer selection. Friendly service. You have to try the buffalo chicken wrap (vegan)!! And fried pickles!! Yummy!

Handlebar embodies a typical Yelp dilemma for me. I see this place as a definite 3.5 stars, so do I go 3 stars or do I go 4? Well Handlebar delivers a casual atmosphere, a small yet sophisticated beer menu, and food choices that preference vegetarian offerings. I was impressed with the continuum of beer choices that spans typical stuff (e.g., Guinness) to more obscure finds (e.g., Three Floyds Robert the Bruce) all accomplished with only about 8 or so taps. They might be missing out on being able to hit everyone's palates this way, but hopefully it will push people to try something they might not try if offered more choices. Lots of stuff on the menu sounded good and I ended up splitting the sambal tofu and a salad special. The waitress warned us that the sambal tofu was spicy which heightened my expectations for what would come. Although there definitely was a kick it's not a dish I think needs to come with a warning. Everything was good but nothing I'd order again but I'd definitely come back to Handlebar to try some other options.
Awesome brunch food. Cool atmosphere. I love this place.

I was underwhelmed by Handlebar. After seeing Yelpers rate it a 4 and hearing from my friend that it was highly recommended to him, I was looking forward to it. Unfortunately, it didn't wow me enough to want to come back. Our table was right by the front door, so I might as well have left my coat on as it was a chilly morning. The table was also so cramped with the one behind it that we had to physically move the table so that there would be enough room for me to sit down.  Brunch is my favorite meal of the day and my main issue is typically whittling down the list of everything that looks good on the menu to my final selection. Here it turned out that the only thing that stood out were the biscuits and gravy. The gravy had a great flavor but I learned I'm not a fan of Seitan sausage - I'm not vegetarian but I am totally willing to try new things, that just didn't hit the spot for me. On the bright side, the spiked apple cider was delicious and was the perfect drink to warm me up considering the rain and cold.  What surprised me most was the service. Our waitress was barely around and not friendly. The gentleman "greeting" new guests kept telling the two-party groups that they could "sit at any of the small tables up here or sit at the bar." I finally realized he was trying to save the 4-person tables for groups larger than 2, but why not just show people to an open table? Wouldn't that be easier than having to move people when they choose the wrong table? Probably not going to be on my list to revisit.
One of my favorite spots in Bucktown/Wicker Park. You just can't go wrong here. Awesome brunch, great night spot, delicious food.

First off, while I like vegetarian food, I am not a vegetarian, so my restaurants are not limited in Chicago.  I went to Handlebar last night for dinner.  We had the tostadas as an appetizer.  Nothing like I expected, but they were pretty good.  We also got the fried avocado tacos.  The filling was good, but it didn't need the blah flour tortilla.  We also got the shrimp po'boy - it was awful.  Shrimp is my favorite food and neither one of us wanted to finish it.  It wasn't deep-fried and the sauce was truly bad.  The fries that came with it were good. I enjoyed the atmosphere.  The service was friendly, but not great.  The waiter didn't take a drink order first - he wanted drinks and food all at once.  Then he brought the dinner with the appetizer.  Not the end of the world, but I like my starters to come before the rest of the meal. With so many restaurants in Chicago that I want to try or revisit, there's no need to go back here.

Meh's the word. Good service. Fun atmosphere. Sunday lunch. Wilty greens. Less than fresh fish. Seared tuna was 3xseared. Slop style food presentation...Go to Manna or any of the other  places that take pride in their kitchens.

Meh...not too impressed.  We arrived with 8 people early on a Friday evening.  It was moderately crowded but there were several open tables so we grabbed a cocktail while waiting for a seat.  Two 4-top tables beside each other became available on the back patio (very nice patio, by the way) and the host asked if we'd like to split the party.  We were denied a request to pull the tables together when we realized they were literally right beside each other - not a big deal but then we had the same server so I'm not really sure why it was an issue. The food itself was pretty good...nothing amazing stuck out to me.  All was OK until mid-meal a table away, sitting 6 deep all began smoking.  We asked about it but were told it's allowed.  What???  The patio is long and slender so I'm assuming past 15 feet from the back door, smoking is OK.  Nonetheless, it was very unpleasant.   I'd probably go back but I'd ask to sit inside which is a bummer or closer to the back door if on the patio so I don't have to eat with smokers.

The food is pretty damn good and it looks like a gazillion people have already mentioned that so I'll just top off the two things I liked, I mean other than that it's a bike-themed restaurant. 1. Everyday Special: A shot of tequila and a Tecate? YES! 2. That backyard seating area is wonderful. I'm sure it's impossible in the winter but man, the other three seasons have that place on lock down.

I've been here a couple times, and it's always been really good. It sometimes takes a little long to get food, and when I've asked for boxes to take my food home I've been met with a little resistance (and some ridiculousness - a leaky cardboard box to take my beans home in? I know you can do better, Handlebar!), but that's the biggest of my concerns. Usually it's just tasty, reasonably priced food. I probably wouldn't go out of my way to eat there, but when I'm in the area it's my first choice.

I've been here 4 times and it keeps getting worse. Two stars because the food is wonderful _BUT_ the employees are rude and uncaring.  Last month I came here with friends for my birthday.  My girlfriend has a tiny pomeranian, we walked in with the pup in an enclosed carrying case. While we were waiting to sit on the patio the bar tender (I think he might have been the manager?) proceeded to YELL at my girlfriend telling her to get out with the dog. He could have politely explained they don't allow dogs on the patio. Luckily we didn't live far so we took the dog home.  We had a party of five and they sat us at a small four person table. There were two 6 person tables on the patio. We asked multiple times to be seated at an appropriately sized table. Our waiter was uncaring and told us there were 6 person parties coming out at that moment. About 20 minutes after ordering the larger tables were still empty so we moved anyway... IMMEDIATELY the waiter rushed over and told us to move back to our cramped table.... OR LEAVE!! We were shocked. We got our food, everything was yummy but it barely fit on our table. We left and the six person tables were still empty...  I would recommend getting take-out until the employees work on their people skills.

Pretty solid place.  I've been here twice.  Once for brunch and once for dinner.   Good beer selection.  For brunch I had just eggs and toast.  I'm simple when it comes to what I like for breakfast.  It made the grade because I'm picky with the way my eggs are cooked. For dinner I had the grilled fish tacos.  Those really hit the spot.  I'll be back again for those.   Also, we get their handpies at the farmers market.  Some of the best we've had.  Keep up the good work Handlebar!
I love handlebar. Really great food and drinks, and a cool, funky atmosphere. I highly recommend this place!

The last time I was in Chicago, we ate at Handlebar and had a great experience so we headed back there this time.  When we arrived, our friend hadn't yet arrived and they won't seat incomplete parties so we had to wait a bit until she arrived. This bicycle bar is very popular so expect a wait if you are going for dinner.   I ordered the wasabi tofu that was topped with green beans and edamame over rice. I loved the flavors that the wasabi sauce imparted on the tofu and thoroughly enjoyed the dish. Zach ordered the buffalo chicken wrap, which was soooo delicious. We had this the last time so it is consistently good. For dessert, we ordered the chocolate raspberry bar, which I found to be quite dry. I wouldn't say that desserts are their specialty. Maybe a scoop of soy ice cream would have made it better. We stayed for a while and had drinks as well. Their alcoholic drinks are pretty good. This is a great place to go for good food with good friends. It is a bar-like atmosphere, but is very laid back, which makes it a nice hangout joint.

Mmmm...I just love me some good vegetarian food!  I don't know why, but I just get such a kick out of fake meat.  The mac and cheese combined with Seitan sausage is pretty awesome!  I had to look up what Seitan means, and found it to be "food made from wheat gluten".  Tastes just like sausage to me, texture and all!  I just want to try everything on the menu from BBQ Seitan to fried avocado tacos. For dessert, I ordered the special of the day - deep fried peach and ginger pie - DELICIOUS!  The pie is like an empanada filled with goodies.  I also saw that they had other kinds of fried pies like PBJ! The decor is pretty cool.  The walls are lined with artsy posters.  The service was pretty good and I would definitely come back next time I'm in the neighborhood.

Met a vegan buddy for late mid week brunch at the Handlebar. When I mentioned the place, my buddy was ecstatic and said it was one of his favorites.  Well I know why, it is so veggie friendly and people friendly!  I ordered the Biscuit and Gravy where the gravy is made with seitan, yeah!  It was so good and rival the one I have had at Tweet. I also was able to order coffee with soy milk, without my server having a blank look.  Finally... a place that gets me!  My buddy ordered the Breakfast Burrito; and can I say not a crumb was left behind!    So veggie folks, we have brunch place for us!  So bring veggie and non-veggie friends to this causal eatery with a bar and have a great brunch!  ~Chitown Veg Gal

I really, really want to give Handlebar five stars for its food.  The fried avocado tacos were superlative and, though the black bean maduro dish came served differently than I expected (in sort of a towering heap of goodness rather than as distinct components), I really enjoyed that too.  I also sampled a fellow diner's ground nut stew - they seem to do Asianish almost as well as they do Latin/Caribbean.   Anyway, the service ran the gamut of quality from so-so to plain bad over the course of the evening.  Sometimes snippy, other times inattentive, the service reached its nadir when, after my friend reported to a waiter that the rough wooden bench of the booth where we were seated had snagged and ripped her pants in two places, he was altogether indifferent and expressed no concern for what had happened.  She was drawing his attention to it so that they could at least fix it for future diners.  All he said was "ok" and hurried off.   I'd give the place the benefit of the doubt and go back just because the food was so good, but the service could definitely use some work.

I love this place. I went here for the first time on my 21st birthday because I'm into vegetarian food. The bartender bought my friend and I two rounds of Jameson whiskey shots. I've been back three times since then. I LOVE the bbq seitan... yum! (Just don't be dumb like me and order a Great Lake's Eliot Ness stout and then have vegetarian food).  The place gets really crowded and it's pretty small, so expect a wait on the weekends during dinnertime. I like sitting at the bar, and looking at the characters strolling in. It's a fun place to grab a few drinks, eat some good hearty vegetarian food and catch up with friends.

My vegetarian friend was in town and wanted to go here! I had been warned by fellow meat eaters NOT TO GO but I did and it was really yum! I had fried avocado tacos. There were about 3 vegetables involved that I never would have eaten in my life on it but it was still delicious!!!!!! I also went a few weeks later for brunch and I would eat every single brunch item on the menu! They have liquor.  4STARS!

Handlebar is a neighborhood fav. Food-great! Gouda mac and cheese, buffalo chicken wrap, exceptional! The food is generally 4-5 stars HOWEVER, today I went there with a group of 8 people to catch up, and they told us they were unable to move tables together, and that our friends who we had not seen in a long time would have to sit separately from us. (Despite the fact that there were 2 empty tables sitting next to one another. Because of this we left. So beware, if you are going with a large group, the biggest group they can accomodate is probably 6.

This is one of our favorite places to go in the summer, even more so now that we're following a mostly vegan diet.  The patio is great, covered in vines and lights and kind of deconstructed urban feel.  Go before 3pm and you can sit in the shade or sun and they have AWESOME brunch, go at night and sit under the lights and pick from their good beer selection.  The servers have always been very nice an attentive, so not sure whats up with the bad reviews on that.

handlebar, i'd ride you any day. i first came here a few years back with my bestie when she was vegan.  she was all about it.  me?  i was all about their fried pickles.  uhhh - yeah. while she may not be vegan anymore, their food is still superb as well as their drinks and it's still one of our go to spots. their nachos [when they're sans cilantro] are one of my favorite in the city.  i've even brought my most carnivorous critics here and they were pleased.  i mean, how could you not be pleased with fried pickles.  FRIED PICKLES, PEOPLE!

One of my favorite places in the hood for brunch because I am addicted to their omelet with apples and gouda with sourdough bread on the side. I like this dish so much that I don't even notice that I'm not eating meat.  The wait staff really lets you just be at this joint, whether you like it or not. I personally prefer it this way.   Nice patio space in the back.

Wish I had more meals in a day. Stopped by on a trip through Chicago and stepped in for a late night drink + snacks. They have lots of vegetarian and vegan options for the food AND drinks. I loved warming up with a spiked hot chocolate. Mmm. The space is a little narrow, so I wouldn't come here with a gigantic group. It's the perfect space to catch up with a few close friends. Not too loud, not too quiet. Juuust right. Wish there were more places like this.

One of my favorite restaurants in Wicker Park and I'm not even a vegetarian! My favorite is their buffalo seitan wrap. They have a great beer selection and drink specials daily. The servers are friendly and helpful too. They have a great back patio for the nice weather.

I'm not a vegetarian by any means, however this place was pretty delicious. I had blackened fish with sesame broccoli and it was very flavorful. Service was fast and attentive. AND check out their outdoor area, pretty glorious for the summertime :)

This place's food was amazing.  Got take out on a Wednesday night and got the Grilled Catfish Tacos that came with a side of rice and chili.  All of it was delicious.  Also tried my roommates Black Bean Meduro which was delicious as well.  I highly recommend this place.  I am not a vegan or vegetarian but I love the food here.  It also seems like they have a phenomenal beer selection!  One of my absolute favorites in the Bucktown/Wicker Park Area.

It's pretty obvious from fellow Yelper ratings that this place is worth checking out so I'll move on to the food part. I was a little skeptical of the vegan nacho platter coz I love chorizo n cheese (the real kind)! But this one did not disappoint me. It was pretty good. For the entree, try the Diablo if you make it there before 3pm. The combo of fried eggs n plantain in some chipotle red sauce was amazing! Next time on the list is the Mac n Cheese. Can't wait.

Went for lunch with my family on my birthday.  Our waitress was very nice and accommodating, even when we were asking several questions and asking for substitutions.  Food came out promptly, everything delicious.  Great experience.

Erica N. and I headed to Handlebar on the quest for a healthy dinner.  The restaurant serves vegetarian and vegan fare so it must be healthy, right?  Well, as soon as we were seated, we were asked if we wanted to partake in the craft beer + french fries special of the evening.  If beer and fries are healthy, I've apparently been doing it all wrong. Let's hope that the Sambal Tofu that I ordered is magnitudes healthier than IPAs and fries.  The kale, collard greens, broccoli, and green beans were all cooked such that they were still crunchy (because who likes mushy vegetables, anyway?).  The sambal (a chili-based sauce) was much milder than I expected, but didn't prevent me from enjoying dinner.  In fact, after resuming my horrific and disgusting eating habits later that week, I found myself craving Sambal Tofu. As for the atmosphere, it's loud and the tables are on top of one another.  The artwork that adorns the wall is really interesting; most of it pays homage to bike culture (for example, the iconic Cycles Gladiator poster). Try not to be seated by the door - unless you like keeping your coat on during dinner and enjoy random bursts of cold air every time someone enters and leaves the restaurant (which was pretty much happening on a continuous basis because it was so crowded).

My vegetarian friend's birthday was last week, and so she chose Handlebar for some dinner - she had heard great things (and so had I) and was very excited. We were a group of 7, so we sat on the patio even though it was sweltering, which was not a big deal because we wanted to sit sooner rather than later. I am not sure if our waitress was having a bad night, or if we offended her in some secret way, but she was pretty much rude to us from the get go. It took forever for water to arrive, and then another long while for her to come to our table. We had one question about drinks and we seemed to exasperate her. We let her know we were celebrating a birthday, and another friend asked if there was anything they could do for her birthday. She said, "Uh no, this isn't Applebee's." Whoa. We were all a bit shocked by this... I've been to plenty of upscale/local restaurants and bars who bring out some dessert or something. We weren't asking for singing and confetti.. just a little surprise. Throw us a bone here.   We should have just left then. But no, we stuck it out.. another girl with us has a nut allergy, and so she asked if the whole grain bread had nuts in/on it. Our server replied, "It's whole grain bread... so yes." Again, we were kind of shocked with the tone, as though this was the most obvious thing in the world. Another friend politely informed her that she had a nut allergy. to which the server replied "Fine, I get it. We do have sourdough you know." No, we didn't know, that's why we asked. It was just so strange the way she talked to us, like we were idiots invading her home or something.  I'm not sure what the deal was, an off night or something, but we felt really bad for our friend whose birthday we were trying to celebrate.
Meanie Greenie is sooo good!  All of the items on the menu are very very great!  I have never had a less than awesome meal here!  The back patio is way chill! Check em out!
This place is scrumptious!! A bar with everything homemade, ranch sauce, chips, pickles are ridiculous. Drinks are yumm. YES! I miss you.

This is a nice spot in the neighborhood for food and beer, but the area is eerily quiet at night off if the main intersection at the Damen station, so be alert. Had the Chicago style tofu and there were a couple of bites that were heavy on the dijon as someone else noted, but other than that good focaccia and pesto. I don't know if they make their own pickles, but that was quite tasty. The garlic mashed potatoes were good, but what stood out more was the pumpkin pie spices which wasn't bad, but I was expecting just garlic and didn't taste much of it. I wasn't about to ask a neighboring patron to see if they could detect a hint of garlic on my breath just to make sure it was there. I was kinda bummed about the PBR tap not working: $2 PBR up in Mpls is non-existent outside of happy hours where you're looking at $3.50-$4.00 for that in tallboy form or a "cheap" beer equivalent. The Eugene porter was good and assertive and they had special Chicago Old Style cans, which I forgot to rinse out and keep as a souvenir. The decor at the bar and the music are great too.

Wow! I came here with my parents and a friend and we all LOVED it! We literally argued over who ordered the best dish. I ordered the Sambal tofu and it was sooo delish. The outdoor patio is also super nice, and although we had to wait a while for our table, it was worth it.  Highly recommend.

I ate here some time ago and had mediocre food and awful service. I recently gave them another try and didn't even get to the food. We sat down, got water and menus, and then nothing. Several minutes pass, we're ready to order, I'm dying for coffee, and still nothing. I look around, and the place is by no means super busy. I try to wave down someone, but none of the servers are paying any attention because they're all to busy chatting with each other while siping their own coffees and staring into space. Sheesh. That's great that all the people who work there have a super fun place to hangout, but what about the actual customers? I continue to be of the opinion that Handelbar is overrated and generally crap. So we took our business elsewhere, and will continue to do so.

This is one of my favorite brunch places in Wicker Park. It's VERY hipster but the food  is delicious!! Great for vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike. There's also outdoor seating in the back. The restaurant is pretty small so it's nice for an intimate brunch, but definitely not a good place for larger groups

Food is awesome. Service is hit-or-miss. One night we walked in with three people. We couldn't be seated because the "host" gave a 4-top to a couple instead of us. After waiting for 30 minutes, we asked to be seated at a smaller table and we didn't mind being a little cramped. His response: 'Oh, well the table next to that are waiting for some more people." Even though the table had been empty the entire time we'd been there. We left and went to Piece. The food here is really good. I recommend the Chicago-Style Tofu or Black Beans Maduro, which might be a little too spicy to finish, but it's still delicious. Fried pickles are really good, nachos are awesome and mac and cheese is great. The patio is really nice and has quite a bit of shading so you can go there on a nice, sunny day and not get scorched.
Fun spot, food is on point, outdoor seating is really nice.

I love Handlebar so much. I really do. The outside seating in the summer is awesome and the drinks will knock you on your ass...which is always a huge plus. Excellent bloody marys, super strong margaritas, and an impressive beer list. I really like the biscuits and gravy and am a huge fan of Handlebar's nachos. Pretty much everything I've tried there is great.

This place is rather unsuspecting when you just walk by - especially in the summertime! They have a great patio out back that I would recommend sitting at.  I am a vegetarian and this place has a TON of options. I didn't realize it was even a vegetarian/vegan place until I looked it up on Yelp. I had the black bean burger and it was massive! Beer was on special ($1 PBR on Mondays, I think). Staff was really friendly and prompt.  I would definitely go back!  Oh, and they accept Amex! Woo.

The boyfriend and I decided to try a new vegetarian friendly restaurant and wound up at Handlebar.  For starters: kudos on a wide and reasonable range of beverages!! He ordered a couple beers and I went with a Hibiscus Mint Tea Cooler.  We went with Samosas as our appetizer. Average. The pockets were a tad hardened and tough to cut into. Flavor was decent, but nothing special.  I ordered the Avocado Tacos and was not disappointed. The tacos were filling and loaded with texture. The cabbage slaw and lightly fried avocado gave the dish a fresh crisp flavor. But lets talk about that green rice side. Under or over cooked, the rice was hard and virtually flavorless; a bit of a letdown considering how delicious the main dish was. My boyfriend went with the Chard special served on a bed of couscous, which was also loaded with texture and flavor.  We splurged, and ordered the Plantain's Foster for dessert. Again, average. The plantain's we pretty darn good, but the ginger cake it was paired with was incredible dry and in my opinion did not compliment the flavor of the fruit.  Bottom line: I will definitely be back for dinner, minus starters and dessert. The menu is wide and innovative and I look forward to trying something new.  If you are looking to accommodate vegans, vegetarians, meat-eaters, or any combination there of, I highly recommend giving Handlebar a try.

We showed up here late, hungry and loud. Our first order was a round of Tecate and tequila shots which might make other wait staff grimace, but our waitress brought our drinks with relish.  The food was incredible; two of us ordered the black bean maduro and two ordered the Green Meanie sandwich.  The black bean maduro was perfection. The plantains were sweet, the sauce was very spicy but flavorful; I didn't feel like my tastebuds were burned off. My fiance had collard greens on the side of his sandwich that were garlicky perfection.  I really can't say enough about how great the food was. I wanted everything on the menu! It was dark, but the decor was cozy and fun. And the prices were totally reasonable!

Went today and had a terrible experience. I have been twice before and loved it. Today, immediately upon being seated two people came by and made a point to say something dick about the fact that my friend and I had Starbucks coffees with us. We walked from Starbucks. We both ordered a drink off your menu. Don't be dicks about it from the start. We are both servers. We get it. The food was terrible. Our server got my friend's order wrong. Our server walked by our table three times while our cards were out and we still had to stop him to ask for the tab. We normally wouldn't ask a server to split a $30 tab, but we were both so over it we didn't care. We also would normally tip more than 20% but our server was terrible. He didn't give a crap and was a jerk about the iced coffees before he even greeted us. I will never return. My friend and I were so angry about the whole situation we couldn't wait to get out of there. We walked somewhere else and had a lovely lunch.

I didn't even realize this place was vegetarian. After flying to Chicago from Los Angeles, I was just in a haze of starvation and the need to eat a large amount of food to get my strength back. (Might be exaggerating the hunger.) $1 PBR special? Sold. Awesome chips & guac? Sold. SMOKED GOUDA CHILI MAC? I must have died, this was exactly what I wanted to stuff my face with. A little too much chili-bean action, and the chips were awkward to eat, but all in all, a delicious choice. I could eat the homemade pickled jalapenos all day long if my stomach would let me.
Have to say I thought I'd hate it but it was pretty good.  To be fair, I'm a carnivore.  They did vegan about as well as I could have imagined.

The Handlebar has become one of my favorite spots in the Chicago.   The food is great, the prices are fair, the specials never disappoint and the staff is kind. Good music adds to the relaxed atmosphere.  The patio out back is unique and inviting. Try this place out.  You'll be glad you did.

a favorite for many years!  great for brunch - and added bonus - there is usually no line on the weekends! awesome dinner entrees - black beans madura or the gouda mac n' cheese are my go-to's. reasonable prices, good service, soooo tasty!
Ordered take-out.. The food was mediocre and cold, the staff was rude. Will not go back.
One of my favorites.  I go here often for brunch and am always pleased.  The food is unique, fresh and delicious.  love it!

Handlebar was my first vegan resto for my vegan challenge! It's awesome. The food was delicious and really healthy. I love healthy food. Therefore I love Handlebar.  The decor is awesome, it looks cozy and like you're in someones apartment. A very cleverly and creatively decorated apartment. Especially the bar area. There is a whole lot of different posters. Looks very cool though. The place is really small though. A bit too small. We were all very close together, from one table to the next.

I was glad to find another vegetarian restaurant in Chicago, and bike-friendly, too! or at least by name. The area on North Ave. isn't all that nice, it turned out.  I got the Chicago-Style Sandwich. Pesto tofu, the menu said. But the dijon mustard totally overpowered whatever pesto flavor there might have been. But then I don't quite like dijon from the start and probably should've asked for none of it. Then again, if the main thing in the sandwich is pesto tofu, I would think there should be more pesto taste than anything else. Got gouda mac as a side as other yelpers have suggested.  Not that great. A little too salty. Gouda mac at the only other place I've tried it, at Local Habit in San Diego, is way better.  The place is alright, though. They were playing indie-electro/nu disco songs that I knew, which must mean they haven't updated the playlist in a while. Which means that they're not super hipster-ific.  Which can be a good thing for all those hipster haters.

I used to live across the street and came here pretty often.  I have had takeout and dined in.  All times were for dinner and all times I had superb service and food.  I can't wait until the patio is open, because this is a great place to come chill outside in the summertime.  I think the fish tacos are awesome, and the black bean tostada appetizer is really good too.

Years ago, this was my in-hood go-to vegetarian spot, and if it was summer and I had a club night to run, I'd bring the headlining touring artists / DJs here for a pre-show nosh out on the patio accompanied by some leisurely-imbibed beverages. These music types I seem to bring in always seem to be food nerds, and this consistently proved to be a safe bet. It's one of those restaurants where you aren't limited by the three-way choice between the salad, some pasta dish, and a DIY flight of sides.  Also, they take their booze seriously and their craft beer menu is fairly solid. So....fast forward a few years (last month) and my boy and I pop in for brunch on a Sunday to casually run some ideas between us before we head out for another adventure. Yes, the place is loud with all that sound bouncing around on hard surfaces, but the tables are small enough where you can hear your companion,  which might be partially due to the fact that most people are nursing a hangover and just don't yell anyway.  Then the weirdness then begins to set in.The table on our left is clearly full of newly-emigrated Trixies from Lincoln Park passively demanding validation from each other and then loudly encouraging all at the table to share some fattening and AMAZING desert selection. A woman is struggling to push a baby carriage through the double doors at the entrance only to awkwardly stumble upon a serpentine queue with this high-tech stroller outfitted with a suspension system fit for an off-road vehicle. My companion and I order our meals, he this crab-cake via black bean riff that's one of the specials of the day, and I a BBQ seitan (wheat gluten pulled in a certain way to resemble the stringy-ness of pork) sandwich, with a side of their smoked Mac n' Cheese, for max-sharing action. Well, my BBQ sandwich had RAW red onions and an impossibly crusty bread. First, red raw onions work best when they provide a bit of bite, texture, and color in mostly raw dishes: wraps, salads and the like. But we're talking BBQ here, and there needs to be some cooking of those guys. Those onions should be caramelized, providing sweetness and texture and just a hint of bite and softer texture.. But please no! Don't carmelize red onions. When you cook them they turn this hideous purple brown color that is just sickening to look at. I think Handlebar tried to combine their super "freshie vegan wrap" mentality with BBQ pork and ... no. I just ended up eating the M&C--which I really wish they threw under the broiler for a few minutes to get that nice crust of baked cheese. Next up, the extremely-crusty bread. Do you realize that biting into two pieces of wood with slimy stuff in the middle basically forces all the gooey insides out of the other end? This is basic fluid dynamics, people. Come on, chefs: pretend you're on a date. Do you want to look like a slob in front of your date and then go home alone and cry for 5 hours with a painfully loofah-ed mouth rubbed raw by your out- of-control rock/bread? I tried my boy's "black bean crab cakes." You've got to be kidding me. Fish is a delicate flavor and texture, which you'd probably want to go chasing after variations on soft tofu to get something analogous to happen. Black beans are so not it. Good god. Tasteless, mealy, bland, and nothing like fish. *Sigh* Vegan (and vegetarian) does not have to be disappointing. It can be extremely awesome and creative. For instance, Karyn's on Green has spoiled me, I think. I remember leaning back from an "omelet" I had there one morning and just blabbering adjectives about how delicious it was. Karyn knows what she's doing, and how to do it right and consistently. Went there for dinner and ate vegan sliders and time slowed down while I slowly noshed down a teeny appetizer.  Do you see what I'm saying? Yes, Handlebar is hip and fun (and the bike-friendliness with the bike racks outside and bike-details within, like the bar stools made from rims) and has an inclusive menu, but just a few tweaks in standards here and there and they could have the hipster-bar equivalent of something along the lines of Karyn's. Just sayin.'

I have heard some great things about Handlebar.  Nice to have some more vegetarian option.  I had their Gyros with cheddar grits....the pita should be warmed up to have the whole entree taste better, and the grits were really just ok....this comes from a person who really likes grits.   The service was pretty good and I liked the ginger drink they have.   I am open to coming back, but not really going to put it on the "hot" list.

Perhaps I ordered the wrong thing. Perhaps its just possible that one *can* mess up grilled cheese and tomato soup. The sandwich was not tasty and the soup way too tangy. Perhaps too much dill? I tried getting a basic item but I was utterly disappointed. The price was too high but I must admit, the atmosphere was great.  So why two stars over none? Well their veggie stew was pretty good.

This place is probably in my top 3 restaurants in the city. I am a pesca-tarian, so i very much appreciate all the veggie options. The buffalo seitan wrap is my fave. Their soups are always amazing and their beer selection is great. This is also our #1 brunch place. The servers are always good, and we only have to wait if it's a weekend night/brunch and we have a group larger than 4. Which happens, since we all love this place:)

Fried Avocado Tacos.   I have died and gone to taco heaven.   LOVE them.  Still love this place.    Still think they should get 12 stars.   The only thing they could improve:   Opening another spot next door to me.
Everything I ate here was delicious. The interior has a pleasant, casual, urban feel. The inside is fairly small. I would go here with a small (four or less) group on a Sunday-Thursday.
Great Bloody Mary.  Lost points on the po' boy.  Ew.  Good fries, good collards, good green meanie.  But most of all, great Bloody Mary.

It took moving to Andersonville to get me to come here, go figure. I went on a busy Thursday evening, but was pleasantly surprised to be seated straight away. It's got the cozy and intimate thing going for it, but I never at any time felt crowded, even though we were seated by a high traffic area. I was a big fan of the overall atmosphere, nicely casual but with that aforementioned cozy and intimate feeling overlaying everything. I'd checked out the menu prior but left dinner up to my gut, which meant I got the Ground Nut Stew. It was delicious. I can't remember the actual ingredients but it gave the feeling of being hearty without any of the actual weight of being so. Well flavored and in good portion.  I didn't go crazy in beer selection, sticking with the special of the night, but I eyed their list and it appeared to be worthy of the neighborhood.  Service was good too. I'll definitely be back.

Out in the Wicker Park neighborhood of Chicago, you're going to find a meal like no other. Handlebar has taken vegetarian/vegan cuisine to new heights along with comfort food - think Smoked Gouda Mac and Biscuits & Gravy. Experience some of their best kept secrets.
i love the handlebar! great environment, delicious vegan bloody mary, fried pickles with vegan ranch dip, vegan buffalo chicken wrap....so delicious!

This place has one heck of a brunch! Kale and Sweet potato with pepitas is my favorite! They also make some tasty sannys! (and don't forget the fried pickles!) The food is delicious, and the atmosphere is alright.  In the spring/summer/fall they open up a back patio that is a nice little getaway! I love hanging out in the back and having a few beers! When you are walking in check out the street art in the Alley? next door. The only thing keeping me from 5 stars is the volume of the music. I'm not a fan of shouting to understand conversation.

For fuck's sake: Could the service BE any slower? I'm sorry, but waiting 45 minutes for a freaking omelet on a Saturday is just criminal. I appreciate what Handlebar is doing... vegetarian/vegan, bike-friendly, giving hipsters a place to call home, but it doesn't mean you can take that long to cook some eggs. Bah.

I heart handlebar (food) 4 eva and eva. I moved out of the neighborhood a couple of months age and STILL crave the huevos diablos. Their homemade corn tostada? Insane. Black bean maduro? Should be illegal.  The only thing that sometimes leaves something to be desired is the service. It seems to range from somewhat apathetic (which is fine with me) to downright frosty.  Bottom line: it's totally worth it

My sister and I went around 2:30 on a Saturday afternoon. We ordered guacamole and the pepita scramble, 2 waters. The food took 35 minutes to arrive, the server only came to the table to order, serve the food, and deliver the check. The service annoyed me the most. The servings were small for an $8 entree. We read about Handlebar in the Tribune a few weeks ago and wanted to try the plantains foster dessert, but weren't willing to wait another 35 minutes for the food to arrive. NOTE TO HANDLEBAR: YOU WILL MAKE MORE MONEY ON FOOD IF YOUR SERVER GIVES THE TABLE ATTENTION!

Breakfast at Handlebar (served until 3pm) is great, especially now that they've added the chimichanga to the menu. As an omnivore, i find their lunch/dinner menu underwhelming and too tofu-dependant; but the nachos are ok as long as you ask for them without the icky fake sausage, and the smoked gouda mac is out of this world. Don't expect the best service here - it's incredibly slow, regardless of how busy the restaurant is.

I love the Handlebar! They are my long distance romance of restaurants - I moved way out into the northwest suburbs, but this place is good enough for me to stay loyal and drive all the way into the city for, when the craving for it hits. There are lots of goodies on the menu here. I have come here with meat eating friends, who always left satisfied as well. I love their sandwich options. They have some delicious sides available too. Amazing beer selection, and the waiters have always been wise with their suggestions for me when I've been undecisive about what beer I wanted to sip on during my meal. I have been here every time of the day - lunchtime on a weekday, evening on a weekend and everything in between. The atmosphere is always young, hip and laid back.  It has been my go-to for several first dates, and would reccomend it as a laid back place to sit in and have a conversation in. The menu is affordable without being cheap, as cheap comes with obvious connotations about quality. The Handlebar has always had high quality food for me, which looks good on a date as well. Their kitchen staff must be extremely dedicated to the presentation and quality of the food, as well. My sprouts are always fresh-off-the-farm stand crunchy, my avocado is always creamy and perfect and unblemished, my bread always tastes like it was pulled out of the oven that morning, and the fries are always crisp and fresh. The sandwiches look downright stacked, stuffed with contents, you could photograph any single sandwich that comes out of their kitchen and run it as a magazine ad without needing to retouch it at all. It is a big deal to me, as I have gone to restaurants with nice pics on their website of their food, only to find their sandwiches flat and squished-down looking in person. The Handlebar has been consistently awesome with every visit.  Thanks Handlebar. If I ever win the lottery I will make sure I open a Handlebar location next door to me. The only sorrow I have is having to drive forty miles now to enjoy this great spot... I'm sorry Handlebar, I didn't mean to move out of the city on you. I will make sure to visit no matter the distance.

attn: bitter handlebar employee with your stupid mustache i'm sorry that my friend from cali didn't know what stupid little town from michigan that you came from. for you to ask her if 'she owned a map' is really embarrassing...for you.  if you miss home so much, GO BACK TO MICHIGAN.  i come here to enjoy good veggie eats, not for my out of town guests to be belittled by poseur hipsters like you.  ps-get the black bean maduro, that sauce alone is worth the trip.

I came here for brunch with my girl who is on a vegan kick. I myself, am not a vegan. Street parking was readily available...no meters...bonus.  Walking in  I immediately noticed the place was jam-packed with hipsters.  I myself, am not a hipster. There were no available tables so the two of us opted not to wait and just sit at the bar. Imperial Porter? Don't mind if I do!  Almost everything on the menu had a vegan option. Did I mention this was a vegan restaurant?  I ordered  the biscuits 'n gravy with the optional over-easy eggs on top.  Take that, vegans! Even though there was no real meat in it, the seitan sausage gravy was hearty and filling. The portion was more than enough. I almost forgot it wasn't really sausage. I would definitely order them again.  The smoked gouda mac 'n cheese was a TOTAL FAILURE. There wasn't enough cheese! How do I know? Because melted cheese has a gooeyness to it. There was nothing gooey here people!  It was more like pasta that was dipped in a cheese "sauce." I could have made better mac 'n cheese at home. For God's sake, just throw in some shredded cheese people. I should have sent it back but I didn't.  The service was good. The drink selection was legit. The atmosphere is chill. I wouldn't mind coming back here. I just wouldn't order the mac 'n cheese.

I don't know... I just cant get enthusiastic about this place.  I had the grilled cheese and the gouda mac & cheese.  It was fine.  I think I wanted the mac & cheese to be cheesier, and maybe some bread crumbs on top; it was just sort of blah.  Good flavor though.  The BF had the 'chicken' wrap and garlic mashed potatoes.  Also fine. Also - not totally vegetarian, also fish options.  What would you call that, pescatarian?

Cut that Green Meanie in half!  I made a mess of myself (more than usual - ok, ok) avocado and goat cheese yumminess all over the place.  Still all got eaten, but the mess could have been prevented had I a big ol chef knife on hand.

this place has delicious vegetarian food, i fell in love the first time my bf took me here.  their bloody hammer is to die for, bloody mary with that delicious fried pickle in it!! the buffalo 'chicken' wrap is so delicious and the vegan ranch dressing is HEAVEN basically everything i have ever had there is delicious sunday $5 bloody mary's too!!  it is pretty funny that you are in a sea of flannel every time you go there though, and also the waiters have always been really nice and attentive and i'm not a bearded dude so idk what all these other reviews are talking about

Wow!!!!!   I LOVE my meat, and was doubtful I would leave this place satisfied but man was I shocked!  This place is AMAZING!   Great food, and even better service.  Our waitress was super nice and did a great job of recommending great dishes.  I ate Vegan and loved every minute of it!    Prices too are great :)

This place has a nice vibe and some great beers. The food is aight. I love vegetarian/vegan food and would chop off a finger for the last vegan milk shake from the Chicago Diner, but at this place the food was just aight.  The abundance of glowing food reviews makes me pretty sure that the vegan/vegetarians on Yelp are out in full force and give extra stars to any place with extra vegetarian options. Nothing wrong with that. But if you're a vegetarian (or meat eater who loves veggie restaurants like me) looking for dinner, then keep moving.  That said...the buffalo chicken wrap was tasty and my only complaint is that it could use more chicken!

So, i was recommend to this place for vegetarian grub. I was looking to order a plain veggie burget but beware its only on tuesdays that they serve em. I am not a vegetarian by any means but once in a while you know. Although I am looking to become one again. (yes again) At least pescatarian w a side of vegetarian.  Anyway, i read another review about the unfriendly service and i dint experience that whatsoever. I mean the hostess wasnt overly friendly or anything but she was semi-hospitable. So i ordered the Buffalo Chicken Wrap and again I am by no means a vegetarian so im not even familiar w the terms etc. (well kind of) Whatever it was made of it did not taste anything like chicken but it was tasty. I think maybe it was falafel w wing sauce on it. I wasnt crazy about the sauce, it was tangy w a spice and stuff but i never was a sauce guy.(again i guess it was like a chicken wing sauce) But it wasnt bad for being pretend a chicken falafel wrap thingie.  But the side of garlic smashed potatoes were AAAwsome w a capital A. (a nice healthy side too...enough for two people) very Garlicky w Scallion pieces chopped on top. Very Yummy.    Oh and their to-go boxes were interesting little brown things. that looked like chinese take out but not really. The atmosphere seemed pretty laid back but it was 12 noon so i dont know. Decor was Coffee Shoppe w a twang. All in all i would def go back cause my curiosity would like to try so many other things. Plus I definitely wanna try a veggie burger.  If you visit HB def get you some Garlic Smashed Potatoes and stay away from your lover for a while cause its probably best. Oh and i bet the Smoked Gouda Mac is the shiz.  Go HandleBar, they are Balls Deep Vegetarian.  cheers,

We arrived a little after 7 pm on a Saturday night and the small restaurant/bar was full. There were just two small tables against the east wall available so we were seated right away. Within 5 minutes we ordered a cocktail. I had the special which on Sat. is a $5 margarita served rocks in a pint glass. I'm pretty picky about margarita's and this one passed the test. My partner in crime had an Allagash White.  For our appetizer we split an order of the fried pickles because I had read so many raves here on Yelp. Yelpers, I would like to thank you! They were so deelish we almost ordered another for dessert! They are housemade and the cucumbers are just lightly pickled and the perfect crisp texture for frying. It seems they have a cornmeal style batter and are flash fried because they were so light, crisp and not at all greasy. They come with a vegan ranch for dipping and the texture/flavor is so grand it's hard to believe there's no dairy in there.  For the entree I had the blackened catfish which was served piping hot, moist, sweet, delicate & perfectly seasoned. The blackening spices had just the right amount of heat and flavor without overwhelming the mild fish. I loved it and wouldn't have changed a thing. It comes with two sides and again after reading so many raves I had to go with the smoked gouda mac. Once more, the majority of yelpers got it right! The smokey creamy gouda and firm macaroni were a dream and perfect companion to the fish. For the second side I felt I had to get something green so I went with the collard greens. These were a miss for me as they were not as tender as I like and they were served cold. They were very chewy and bitter probably becasue they weren't cooked as much as I like. I would go with the broccolli next time. My cohort ordered the fish tacos which looked very fresh and tasty with big slices of avocado resting on top. He said they were excellent.  Handlebar is a small room and the crowd is mostly young hipster/bike messenger types. It sounded like they had an old sub-pop compilation playing which I enjoyed. Tables are small and tightly packed together which is necessary in a room this size with the amount of people hungry to eat here. After we were seated there was a pretty steady stream with an average of four people waiting during our stay. We  took our time and didin't feel rushed or like they wanted to turn the table - we were comfortable. Service was steady and unobtrusive. We stayed and had a couple  drinks at our table and by the time we left there were plenty of places to sit. It seems people eat and head out to the bars/nightlife afterwards.  Our tab with 3 drinks each without tip was about $65 which is very reasonable in my book! We easily scored rockstar parking right in front. Summary: Take a dip in the pescetarian/vegetarian/vegan pool. I promise you won't be missing a thing at Handlebar! I'm looking forward to checking out their brunch!

Oh, Handlebar, how I love thee!!! I am a regular here, and love all the food and great beer selections! Hipster service is surprisingly sweet, quick and actually good. A great spot in the summer, as their outdoor area is in the back, so no cars to stink up your meal.

I am lucky enough to have a super cool aunt that lives in Chicago who took me to all the best spots.  The Handlebar was new to us both but she had heard good things so we checked it out.  We got a bunch of food that night but the first thing that I remember is the fried pickles.  I love these things and Handlebar does them right.  Lightly breaded, cripsy, and made with homemade pickles.  My gf and aunt each got a Monarch White from Two Brothers Brewing.  To this day they talk about that beer as one of their favorites of all time.  I'm not crazy about white ales but I have to admit it was quite tasty.   Obviously this place does a lot of vegan and vegetarian stuff.  I tried a bbq 'beef' sandwich with seitan, super tasty.  They also have a bunch of southern type fish dishes like shrimp and grits, catfish, etc.   I see a couple people are a little upset about the service here.   While I had decent service, I could see how this sort of thing could happen at a place like this.  Sometimes people working for cool restaurants think they are too cool to give friendly service (even if they are in the service industry).  Hopefully that was just a problem early on and they have remedied that because it can quickly make it not worth going to a place if you aren't taken care of. The next time I am in the windy city I will be going back to Hot Doug's and Handlebar.

I love this joint, its my peoples. Straight up hipsters, no filler, fuck what you heard, this is where the real hipsters be staying yo. The drinks are always great and amazing. And the food is vegetarian. So if your looking for a meat and cheese concoction, you stepped into the wrong bar, son. Straight Ghouda mac n chee up in hurr. I have literally got everything on this menu that rarely changes so I recommend: Samosas - not like the ones on devon, but real good for being homemade AKA better than you could make.  Maduro - Filling and the best item on the menu as far as price to what you get.  Gouda Mac N Cheese - straight delish yo. I dream of this when I am stuck in airports. Any of the salads - super fresh and always pleasing. For real. Get em. I order salads in restaurants and I somehow manage to keep my masculinity.  Soundtrack is lively. Treated best if you have facial hair and wear pants that hug the nuts. No pool tables.

I went here with some friends and I think we all ended up enjoying our visit, but unfortunately we almost left before we got to eat because we ended up waiting way longer than they said (we thought they forgot about us)... but we waited and waited and finally we were seated. After that everything went well though! Our waitress was really nice, and the beers and food were good. I ordered the black beans maduro. I like spicy food and I liked it, but I think I would have preferred it a little less spicy so I could taste some of the other flavors. My non-vegetarian friends even liked this place though, and that's always cool. I would like to give it another chance because this experience was just OK, so I feel like maybe it was just an off night or something.

Enjoyed brunch here on Saturday and once again left extremely satisfied.  I stayed from my usual this time and got the shrimp and grits and fell in love.  What an indulgence!  The thing I think I love most about handlebar is that they are not afraid to use spice in their food.  Everything I've ever ordered from here is bursting with flavor!  Can't wait to go back again.

i'm not a vegetarian but i can enjoy most vegetarian food. this place was OK. i ordered the green meanie which sounded good but had a weird sauce that tasted like spicy windex. the flash fried fries were good. this place is pretty hipstery so if you're not into that then skip it.

she said hello and welcomed me to sit down. asking me if i would like something to drink something she ended up pouring this wet liquid, cold, refreshing and satisfying into a glass of roundness and placed it in front of me...with another smile. my heart she pounded another pound and i too soon found a smile upon my face. the food that sizzled upon the grills a few feet away in the open kitchen was calling out. ...all of it was simply explained on a piece of paper called a menu and I begin to review the options. a small joint with small intentions and large hearts and bigger decisions of goodness. she makes me fall in love every time. she reminds me that healthy in mind, soul and body can be possible. she reminds me that beautiful things appear in the most unexpected locations and moments so soon once again i fall hard. i chose the fried pickles, samosas, grilled seared tuna sammie and side of mac n cheesenoms.. holy bang a gong batman...  she brings another beer with another smile and i feel it again. satisfaction.

I definitely recommend the Handlebar. It's vegetarian, it's delicious and the wait staff this morning was comprised of several attractive, disheveled young people.  Anyway, I ordered the Portobello Mushroom Omelette, a house coffee and one of their Sunday-Special $3 mimosas. The two other people in my company ordered the Biscuits and Gravy, and the Eggs, Potatoes & Toast. I highly recommend the Portobello Omelette to anyone seeking a heavier breakfast. It was decadent, which I suppose can yield mixed gastrological results depending on how much you've had to drink the night before. Overall, the omelette was very, very good. My only complaint is that the side breakfast potatoes on my dish were a little soggy. They had a nice flavor but seemed like they had been sitting out under a lamp for a while.  My friend let me try a bite of her Biscuits & Gravy and, I have to agree with a lot of the other reviews, for a vegan dish it was very, very good. The Seitan "Sausage" was creamy, surprisingly meaty and peppery-spicy in way that wasn't painful. I'm extremely sensitive to spicy food but I could tolerate it. In general, Biscuits & Gravy aren't my cup of tea, but I understand why people are so enthusiastic about it at Handlebar. If you love it, order it here and maybe share it with someone. This dish is also fairly rich. I'd go back.

Me and the wife went in after hearin some kid at the bus stop talkin about "Chicago tofu". The doc said, "no more hot dogs" and I heard tofu was a healthy option so we decided to drop by. Those hipster kids play some wacky music, but that damn tofu ain't bad.  I'd give them five stars if they hadnt played that Om record twice in a row is give em 5 stars. Not bad. Not bad.

After several failed stops on Saturday morning looking for a hangover cure, I landed here. I was in search of greasy food to cure my hangover, and this surely was not the place for it, althought that is not necessarily a bad thing. The breakfast burrito wasn't greasy and heavy at all. The spinach inside was nice and fresh, although there was far too much in it. The coffee definitely left something to be desired as did the cramped space. Certainly a different option that doesn't leave you feeling like a bloated bag of crap afterwards. If you're looking for healthier dining, this will do fine.
The vegan buffalo chicken wrap is heavenly. This was the best vegan food we had outside of Chicago Diner. The service was so/so but the food was delish.
I eat here everytime I'm in Chicago. Great veggie spot, very accommodating. The green beans are garlicy, which I'm into. The fried seitan chicken is great. Awesome vegetarian breakfast options, too.
Best veggie food in the city - but the place is generally too loud and crowded. Great beer selection!

I love Handlebar for three reasons; the black beans maduro, the Handlebar salad, and the beer selection. The black beans maduro is for people who love spicy only. The intensity of the heat varies with each visit. When I asked about this, I was told that the sauce is home made, and that they cannot control the heat. In spite of the sometimes intense heat, I still love it! The salad is a wonderful blend of arugula, pears, walnuts, parmesan cheese and a honey mustard dressing. It never fails to please. There are a number of other good items that we enjoy from time to time, but the afore mentioned are our favorites. The owner seems to enjoy finding good micro brews to serve. Although I am not sure if Three Floyds still qualifies a a micro brewery, this is where I first enjoyed a number of their offerings. The staff is generally quite friendly, though not always attentive. We do enjoy the outdoor patio in back. Unfortunately, sometimes a smoker will taint the experience. Bike riders will enjoy the ample bike parking in back, as well as a long bar in front to chain their rides to. Also, we have enjoyed arriving at six PM frequently, as that is when the parking regulations on North avenue switches to allow parking right in front.
Barbecue "chicken" wrap and seitan chorizo/black bean nachos. Fantastic. Awesome beer selection, great service. Glad it's in walking distance. This place Is in my top 10 favs. In Chicago.

Dear Vegan Biscuits and Gravy at Handlebar, I want you inside me. All the time. Every day. My heart aches for you your smooth, creaminess. My loins ablazened every time I think of your hot, steamy fluffs of carnal carbohydrates. And finally, your tender seitan. I cannot take the pain of being away from you even for a second my love. Soon, we shall meet again. And I will possess you once more. With Love and Lust for You, Meredith

I don't go here as much as I should. They have a good selection of beers, a mostly vegetarian menu, and a lot of attractive/ 'hip' people tend to go here (nice scenery, try not to drool.) The portions are generous and everything I've tried has been super yummy (Tofu scramble, BBQ Seitan, Green Meanie, Chicago Style Tofu, and the Buffalo Chik Wrap.) Only downside is there is not a lot of walking room becuase of the closely packed tables, and there is usually a lengthy wait for the ladies room (one stall in the hallway beside the kitchen. You will be in someone's way waiting.)

This is my favorite restaurant in Chicago. I keep coming back here for the Fish tacos, Everything green salad, and African nut stew. Truly, everything is delicious.  Its a great place for vegetarians and carnivores alike. Vegetarians/vegans have tons of choices, and carnivores won't even notice that its a mostly vegetarian restaurant. Even my dad loves this place!

This place is great. The food is so fresh and not greasy. I had the breakfast burrito, it was great, and actually did not make me feel like crap later, as burritos often tend to do. We also shared a delicious slice of chocolate cake... I'm not even a cake fan and it was pretty great. It was almost brownie-like. The mac & cheese is really great too. My only complaints about this place are:  1. it's slightly overpriced. 2. i just hate how there's barely enough room to maneuver between the way-too-close-together tables. 3. one bathroom stall? I had to stand (in the way of the servers) and wait, 10 minutes while some other lady took a dump. :/

I have only been to this restaurant once, for a friend's birthday dinner. I really loved my food!! To start, we shared the fried pickles (spears) for $6.25. Enough to share. I love guacamole, so I considered getting it, but I saw the guacamole at another table and it was quite small. Not enough to justify the $7 price, in my opinion. I ordered Black Beans Maduro with avocado ($12.25). I absolutely loved it. It is black beans, cheese, rice and crispy plantain surrounded by a spicy tomato sauce with avocado slices on the side. It was a really excellent mix of textures and flavors. My friends got the BBQ seitan (she usually loves seitan, but she wasn't crazy about it), another friend got the fish tacos (just "OK"), and my other friend got the nachos, which she liked. Besides the Black Beans Maduro, we LOVED the Plantains Foster for dessert (served with ice cream and gingerbread cake). We were crazy about it.

I really like this place!  Since a friend introduced this place to me earlier this year, I've been going somewhat often, and the weird thing is that I didn't even realize that it's a vegetarian restaurant until I read the reviews below! I really like their breakfast burrito with a nice ale.  It sits well on a Sunday morning!

We typically come here for brunch with our vegan friends...and even though neither my husband nor I are vegan/vegetarian at this point, we always appreciate handlebar. #1 for their wonderful patio #2 for unique food selection that don't disappoint.   My personal favorite is the pear and  gouda omelet with walnuts. Mmmmmm Don't be afraid of seitan and certainly don't read the definition of what it is :) Enjoy!

This is my go-to place when I'm in Wicker Park! Not only do they have many good local brews, they have unique dishes, like the black beans maduro, with black beans, fried plaintains, and this really tasty chipolte tomato sauce.  It's a great place to share entrees with others, because the portions are pretty big.  Also, the Green Meanie sandwich is amazing, with it has herb goat cheese, sprouts, spinach, on whole grain bread.

Another place with a stellar patio. Reminds me of lounging in someone's back yard. Oh, and the foods not bad too. Great vegetarian options, love the salads and a good selection of local brews as well. And the fries are my fav. So glad its just a hop and a skip away from my apartment!

Came here for brunch with my brother during his trip here. My brother had the vegan diablos and I had the buffalo chicken wrap. I have never had buffalo chicken so was a little confused as to what the sauce would be like. Our waiter was really nice and after explaining to me what it was (which only confused me more...) told me that they could put it on the side so I could decide for myself whether or not I wanted to use it. Yay! Turns out the sauce is pretty good but I definitely appreciated that it was on the side. Both of us were very happy with our meals. I ended up taking home half of the wrap since there was so much food. I then came back for brunch on a Sunday. I was feeling a little under the weather so just ordered a bunch of sides (Seitan sausage, breakfast potatoes, side salad), which were all really good and flavorful but my friend had the Handlebar omelette which he said was good, but not great because it was kinda bland. We both ended up taking home food.  The atmosphere is really casual and definitely hipster which definitely works for me. Both times I've come so far, I've been able to find street parking right outside of Handlebar and there's no meters! Next time I come here, it'll have to be for dinner! Can't wait!
I love Handlebar.  The food is always fresh, the staff is friendly and they serve quick! I've never ordered anything I didn't enjoy.  There is plenty of bike parking! yes!

I'm dying to eat at this place again. I loved the biscuits and gravy. I WANT SOME RIGHT NOW!!!!! I love this place  for brunch,. Chicago is such a great city for Vegan food. Handle bar is definitely one of the reasons for that.  GO VEGAN!

Didn't feel very welcome here. Grabbed the last seat at the bar next to a regular who decided to elbow me while putting on his hoodie. Didn't even apologize. Wasn't feeling super hungry but they had vegan broccoli soup so I ordered a cup which came out promptly, delivered by a greasy unkempt bartender with his trucker hat on backwards. Most awful soup I've ever tasted! I don't even think Andrew Zimmeran would have been able to stomach it. Pushed it away from me quick and one bartender came over as if to take it away but he saw it was full so he moved on before I could get his attention. Another 10 or 15 minutes went by before my original bartender noticed I had pushed it away and wasn't eating it. Now that I had her attention I informed her and she apologized and took it off my tab. I paid the bill and moved on. One vegan friendly dive bar I doubt I will return to.

Get the Everything Green Salad and just stare and take note of everything that is happening around you. Cute hipster waiter? Check. Stuffed Crows meant to serve as an overdone hitchcock reference? Check. Mothers attempting to give their children "control" as part of some ridiculous "alternative parenting style?" Check. tight shorts and boat shoes? CHECK AND CHECK!

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago!  You don't have to be vegan to have a great meal here! I'm a huge fan of the meal of 3 sides, and you must try the smoked Gouda mac n' cheese!!!! I also love the patio outside!   There's also lots of bike parking. :)

I decided to have the Buffalo Chicken (not real chicken but seitan) wrap.  What is Seitan? Okay Wikipedia help!!! Wheat gluten, also called seitan, wheat meat, mock duck, gluten meat, or simply gluten, is a food made from the gluten of wheat. It is made by washing wheat flour dough with water until all the starch dissolves, leaving insoluble gluten as an elastic mass which is then cooked before being eaten! Thanks Wikipedia I'm not that hungry anymore!!! Not being Vegan but a huge meat lover. I decided to go for it!!!  The presentation of the wrap on the plate was really pretty.  So the moment of truth. I took a big bite and  you know that phrase, "It Tastes like chicken!" It does not apply here!!!  The first bite was not great.  I got the ranch dressing on the side and decided to pour it on top. That may have saved my meal and I hate ranch dressing.  I could see specks of red mixed into the dressing which tells me they spiced it up.  Now the reason for my two stars...the second half of my buffalo chicken wrap only contained vegetables. Yes I was literally missing my fake chicken...it had started to grow on me!!!  Complete laziness by the chef and unacceptable.  We were the only two customers in there. There was no rush...attention to detail is key here.  I kind of felt cheated as a customer!  I was a little shocked as I took bites...hoping to find some buffalo seitan but I never did!!! The hit of this place is the Smoked Gouda Mac and cheese!!!  It deserves 5 stars. In fact, if I ever come back I am going to get a giant plate of it and one of there nice drink specials!!! Two everyday specials. $5 Tecate Can and Tequila Shot and $4 Highlife Pony and Malory shot.   What is Malort?  Wikipedia please rescue me once again: Malört, a distilled beverage, is the name of a Swedish style of schnapps called "Bäska Droppar", flavored with wormwood. The word malört is the Swedish word for the wormwood plant. The smell and taste is musty and extremely bitter. Malört is popularly alleged to be a cure for indigestion. I wonder if Malort helps digest seitan?  I'm sure Wikipedia knows!!!

Holy lord on high. I just had lunch here. I ordered the black bean maduro. This is the kind of food that makes me fall in love with Chicago all over again.  Never mind the service is slow as #%~€ and the music makes me crazy, (i already went through my metal/rock stage in Portland and Seattle years ago) this dish is perfection. The presentation is beautiful and the heat is great! This is a wonderful fusion between Cuban and Mexican food. I cannot wait to come back and try different things on the menu. For now, I am giddy over this dish!!!

Great bar atmosphere with friendly service and a diverse menu with many vegetarian & vegan options!  I really like the tuna steak (but make sure to ask for rare or they sometimes overcook it).  Great selection of healthy side dishes.  Some of my favorites being Broccoli in Sesame sauce, and tasty fried plantains.    Also, this place has a great outdoor patio that is behind the building so you don't have to dine with cars like most patios in Chicago.  I highly recommend you check this place out!

terrific vegetarian option.  cute outdoor area in back.  food is always terrific.  love the mac & cheese.  had the fish tacos and they were delicious.  highly recommended for a small group or date night.

I am not a vegan.  I didn't go here to be wowed, but I did expect a brunch that was warm and filling.  Didn't happen.   The grits were really disappointing Dos diablos came out spicy yet lukewarm at best. Also there was fake chicken which didn't sit well either.   The outdoor patio is really nice and the staff is friendly.  I wouldn't eat here again but I'd go back for drinks.

If the noise level on this place was not so loud, I would give it a five. The food is great here. If you love vegeterian food with lot of flavor, then this is the place for you. Recommended items: Gouda Mac 'n Cheese, Black Beans Maduro (super spicy), and Fish Tacos.

Staff is amazing. Every single person is warm and welcoming, and will do just about anything to make your time there enjoyable. I've never had a bad drink and/or piece of food at Handlebar. I love the music, and the patio is a must. Most of all, you can bring anyone from vegan to carnivore, and they will find something they will enjoy on the menu.

I went here once late at night, and they cheerfully served us fresh, hot food (a rarity for a bar).  I went out on a limb and had the "nut stew", which was a super delicious and filling curry-like meal.  My husband had some kind of sandwich which was very good and a side of mac and cheese that was a bit flavorless before we added salt and pepper.   The piece de resistance had to be the lemon-blueberry empanadas we had for dessert.  O. M. G.  I still think about them today, and it was a few weeks ago that I ate them.  Even though they had run out of ice cream, these were super-winning on their own.  Wow.   Service was a bit perfunctory, but it was the very end of the night.  No big deal!  I've been dying to go back.

Wasabi tofu was excellent. The tofu is infused with wasabi and grilled, served with vegetables and brown rice. Plantains foster was good too. Service was a tad slow, since there was only one guy waiter when I was there around 2:30pm.

Always searching for places that serve a gluten free beer, these guys carry one of my favorites, new grist.  I've only been here once with my partner on a long wknd trip to chicago.  He had the vegan BBQ seitan sandwich which was fairly tasty but sloppy and contained only onions other than the seitan, the toasted bread was thin and sliding off the sandwich- generally effortless presentation, fries were yummy, well salted but also looked like an after-thought on the plate. The spinach salad with roasted beets was simple but lovely and easily made vegan.  The chips and guacamole were perfect.  All in all good vibe despite the typical barely there service.  It's a laid back place to have some drinks with some decent grub.

OK, Handlebar, you have won me over. I have found your gems and I continue to be pleased every time I come here. Last time I was there I had the tofu fajitas and not only were they the best thing I have had at Handlebar, they were the best veggie fajitas I have ever had.  Our service was also fast and friendly, and the all Metallica hour was appreciated by some in my group.

The food here is good and I love to support veg-friendly restaurants, but the service here has become absolutely terrible. I don't know if we interrupted their break time or what, but the servers seemed like they were deliberately trying to be as rude and slow as possible. First we asked to sit outside and the host told us there weren't any tables in the back, then my friend went back there and there were three empty tables that weren't reserved or anything! We were finally seated outside and then we waited for half an hour trying to get water, which never came, we eventually just got up and left, not that our server noticed or anything.

I have to agree with fellow yelper, Andre W, this spot is moe dangerous than a damn sex addict in a brothel.  They have $5 shots of tequila...EVERYDAY! Then they have some thing a ma jig with liquor and iced tea served in a pint! Umm, what are they trying to do? Fret not, fellow yelpites, I did not partake in the libations...THIS time. However, I did grab me some grub and boy was it pretty yums.  I ordered the Seitan Chicken Wrap and the mac and cheese (yeah, not vegan, but I had a weak moment). Let me begin with the smoked gouda mac and cheese. THIS IS NOT your mom's mac and cheese... unfortunately. I was disappointed with this. The yelps said it was good. It was bland. I added a little salt and pepper and that made it better. But, damn, so not worth my dairy binge.  The Chicken wrap, doe! This is BY FAR the best chicken seitan I've ever had. It was crispy and spicy and yummmmmy! I will definitely get this again, and again and again. My total was 11 bucks and some change before tip.  This place isn't far from my crib. I will definitely be going back. Yep, I was the only brown skinned persona in the place to be, who cares. I was full when I left! We're all the same color intoxicated. I'd reccomend to a friend-o.
great neighborhood place with plenty of veggie options. nice patio, too.

Was here on Friday night with hubby and friends. The food is really good. We were seated in the patio at the back, and I really like the seating. The weather was perfect too. The service was good, the atmosphere is very relaxed and casual. We ordered the samosa for the appetizer. Being Indian, we were curious to see how it would taste. They were baked samosas served with mint and tamarind chutney. They were surprisingly good and the mint chutney was awesome too. Then we ordered the Chicago style tofu sandwich, wasabi tofu and blackened tofu fajitas. The sandwich was nothing too memorable. But the other two dishes were yummy!!! We mopped our plates clean. The fajitas were very flavorful and the best of the lot was the wasabi tofu which was vegetables and tofu served over brown rice and it came with a side of collard greens. Yum!!!
