The only con about our experience was the ppl seated on the table next to us were smoking incessantly at the table and as a result all of us (all non-smokers) took in quite a bit of second hand smoke. And that was not pleasant at all.

Coming from a non-vegan or vegetarian person, I have to say, Handlebar is really good.  I love the hipster vibe it has, and the menu has tons of different options.  Their fried pickles and ranch dressing is AWESOME.  I've also tried some of their veggie sandwiches and fish tacos, all of which were delicious.  I've sampled their mac n cheese as well that my friends have ordered, and that was also ridiculously amazing.  The downside is that there is usually a wait, and the service can be a bit slow.  However, I had no problem hanging at the bar and having some reasonably priced craft beer while I waited.  They have different drink specials every night.  I've also been there for brunch and enjoyed it just as much.

I'm rewriting my entire review because I have decided that if their Sambal Tofu dish were a human, I would marry it. I would have it's babies. Do I even want babies? Who knows, but if that's what Sambal wanted, what choice would I have but to give it everything I had? That's it. When I was a nubian, I wrote in my review about other great dishes. And there really are plenty of others; I haven't gotten anything there I didn't love. That gouda mac! That tuna steak sandwich! That nut stew! And that beer selection! But really, none of it matters anymore. I'm becoming a vegitarian, and Sambal Tofu and I are running away together.

Good food but, in our experience, you will be told the wait is 30 minutes and then end up waiting an hour and a half, still not be seated and ultimately eating at the bar! To add insult to injury, there was not even an apology for the inconvenience. Do not go with more than 2 people!!!

This place knows how to make amazing dishes. Even their guacamole is packed with flavor. I had the shrimp and aged cheddar grits for a main and seriously could not believe how good they were. I was lucky enough to get tastes of the Seared Tuna Steak Sandwich and the Wasabi Tofu and would have loved any one of them for dinner. Servers are casual, which makes for a really relaxed atmosphere and the back patio is comfortable and quiet. Inside at the bar they play some good tunes and I never did ask why they have a sign saying "Detroit" over the kitchen? It's a fun place with really great food, many dishes can be made for vegans.

Holy Bloody Mary.... pretty generous (and strong) with lots of fab garnishes... And how can you not love a place with vegan options?! The buffalo chicken (seitan) wrap was really good. The blackened tofu fajitas were not as good, but still decent. We'll definitely be going back!

They had a nice outdoor seating area in the back.  The staff was friendly and we were seated right away.  This was the first time I tried seitan.  The BBQ seitan had the texture of soft beef tapa.  It was very messy and hard to eat between two slices of bread.  I liked the sweetness, but didn't like how it was also a little spicy.  I really enjoyed the fried seitan and found the texture more tolerable.  The best side was the smoked gouda mac n' cheese.  It was the best part of the meal!

The gouda mac and Cheese was the highlight to our brunch. It was nice and smokey and cook to perfection. I really like the the buffalo chicken wrap but I wasn't a fan of the bbq seitan. The reason was it was a little to messy to eat on two slices of bread, I wish they used  a  hoagie bun or something to hold the whole thing or make it into a wrap, the favor was on the sweet side. The aged chedder grit was ok but I would over it again.

Can't say my first visit to this place was very exciting.  Went with my wife and brother-in-law, got seated right away.  Staff seemed nice; I didn't perceive any attitude like other people seemed to notice.  Our waiter was friendly and generally attentive, although he did space out on us a couple times and I had to signal him. Food was mediocre.  The blackened catfish was good, with a kick to it, but it did border on being overcooked.  The sesame broccoli came in a soup cup that was half-filled with some variant of a sesame oil/soy sauce mixture.  Literally half the broccoli was drowned under a couple shots worth of oil.  No thanks. The smoked gouda mac and cheese?  Pathetic.  I'm not sure if they make it a different way now, because after all the raves on Yelp, I expected to be wowed.  Instead, I got a barely-lukewarm side dish with no flavor--smoky or otherwise-and the barest signs of a cheese sauce coating the pasta.  Depressing. The brownie dessert tasted like it came premade and right out of the freezer; that, or someone in that kitchen really needs to learn to make a brownie.  The PB&J samosas were better and an interesting item; serving them in a bowl made it pretty difficult to split them properly. Overall, nice enough people and decor, but unimpressive execution in the kitchen makes it a place I can skip.

Their gluten-free menu is not safe for celiacs. They deep fry using the same oil that they deep fry flour-based items in. Once, I was served a big fat glutenous noodle amidst my rice. They did, however, pick up my check. But they have yet to alter their fictional gluten free menu even after I pointed out that it isn't safe. You might be able to eat here without hazard, but stick to the salads, ask lots of questions and be sure to tell them no bread or deep fried stuff.

Ok I know this is supposedly a must-love for vegetarians/vegans but frankly the food was just so-so. The menu looked good, but the seitan was a bit tough and grainy - definitely not the best I've had. The back patio, while nice, was extremely loud and difficult to have a conversation in. Eh.

The food is very yummy.  We always get the vegetarian buffalo chicken wrap and it never disappoints.  My kids always have the seitein BBQ sandwich.  Also very good.  The beer selection is very well rounded. Local selections like Half Acre and Metropolitan.  The service is hit and miss depending on the time of day, but it's not a deal breaker.  The problem is with cleanliness.  This place seriously needs a good cleaning. I would go back but I don't think I could ask a guest who has never been here before.  The prices do not reflect the scumminess of the place.  Bottom line, if you don't mind a dive ( but paying for a nicer place), the food and beer are good.

Two things I am not.... Not a vegan, not a vegetarian. I do love good food though, and handlebar has it. My girlfriend is however a vegan, she's the one who took me to handlebar the first time, since then I have been the one at times to suggest going to handlebar. The chef of handlebar makes some killer seafood along with the vegetarian fair they are known for. The fish taco's are top notch, additionally they usually have an very interesting special with fish item on their specials menu.  The food and drinks are very affordable also, so we know they are a safe bet.

I am a long time Handlebar customer. That being said, at times the staff seems a bit moody. Also, I'm not liking the new-ish crow decor thing they've got going on. It's creepy attack of the birds style. HOWEVER, their everything green salad is one of the best salads I have ever had. It is filled with very fresh spinach, sunflower sprouts, avocado, green beans, cucumber, edamame, pistachios and goddess dressing. Also, they have a great beer selection, including Hitachino Nest White Ale, which I think is a great summer brew. Handlebar has managed to keep putting out good, fresh vegetarian food, even if they've grown in popularity.

The mac 'n' cheese will leave you wanting ... to lick EVERY LAST SMIDGEN of smooth, smoky gouda goodness off the crock! Admittedly, I'm one of those blood-hungry meat lovers who, upon hearing the that a place is "vegan", "vegetarian", or healthy in general, feels disappointed, sad, and a little bit angry.  Luckily, I didn't know Handlebar was one such place until just now. I only found it because I Googled "best mac 'n' cheese in Chicago," no foolin'. Hey, when ya got a hankerin', ya got a hankerin'. I ordered the black bean tostada appetizer and a side of that famed gouda mac. Both were fantastic. And I'm a mac 'n' cheese snob, through and through. My husband got the fish tacos, which he seemed to enjoy very much. We also shared a bloody hammer which was also AH-mazing. It comes with a huge juicy cherry pepper, olives, a salt and pepper rim and a DEEP- FRIED PICKLE. Do you really need convincing beyond that? I almost forgot about the fried pies. You get two little guys, so we got the evening's featured flavors: PB&J and Strawbarb. Not a lot to them, but they tasted melty and wonderful.

It's unfortunate really, because in a Chicago where the Chicago Diner doesn't exist, Handle bar would reign supreme. But, like a more accomplished brother, we demand more from it's less perfect sibling.  That said, Handlebar is a more than delightful alternative cuisine restaurant with both vegan, vegetarian and pescatarian options. My friend and I split both the Chicago style tofu sandwich, and the buffalo "chicken" wrap.  The Chicago Style Tofu sandwich is skippable. I think it'd be better off if it more closely resembled a Chicago style hot dog, but instead, it has only a few elements of the Chicago dog, plus other elements. The focaccia bread that it was on wasn't very easy to eat as a sandwich, it easily fell apart. The homemade giardiniera was pretty good, but that's basically the only positive note concerning this sandwich.  The buffalo "chicken" wrap however was great. I definitely didn't miss real chicken being in my wrap as the buffalo "chicken" tenders inside the wrap were very fulfilling. The vegan ranch dressing feels like a low calorie alternative to the normal ranch or blue cheese dressing that comes on buffalo style menu items.  I got the seitan sausage as my side dish, which was delicious. It was perfectly seasoned, and was served in a very large portion which I was unable to finish. Overall, Handlebar is pretty good, but it seems like certain items on the menu just don't live up to the rest. In terms of vegetarian creativity, I'd pick Chicago Diner, given the choice. Meanwhile, Handlebar is a great alternative to have.

Non-Vegetarians, DO NOT TURN AWAY!  Handlebar is great food and a great time for all. The negative stereotype that a non-vegetarian can have towards vegetarian food is that it's too rabbity and salady, and cannot fill up a carnivore.  Handlebar serves hearty, comforting, delicious food guaranteed to fill up vegans, vegetarians, and carnivores alike. There are no meat dishes on the menu, but there are seafood dishes.  They have nice fish tacos, and their crispy, warm samosas are quite good.  They have plenty of "meat substitute" items (seitan, etc).   You definitely should plan for this place, it can get crowded.   They have a great beer selection.

Bike parking is in their back patio...yay. Deep fried pickles - in cornbread....not greasy = great Seared yellow tail tuna sandwich...it looked like ahi = great Fish tacos....served with cabbage and avocado = great Ginger beer and a shot of rum...wish there was a larger rum selection = great Apple juice (for low blood sugar)....as fresh as it gets...thought I was in an apple orchard in Michigan = great Sprecher Lo-cal Root Beer....always a favorite = great Big beer list for next time = great Outdoor patio was inviting and a great experience even though it filled up fast. Table spacing is perfect and servers are on-the-ball.  It was fun to see what others ordered. Great place to take a vegetarian. This was my first time here and I don't know why....I will be back soon. Thanks for adding to our date experience. Like I said above bike parking IN the back patio area AND out front AND on the street.

Sometimes vegetarians, vegans, or other noble forked folk want to go to a cheap bar with great bar-esque food, drown their hunger in oily french fries, and down two or three beers along with their cheesy tofu pesto sandwich, or greasy seitan BBQ, or whatever. Surprisingly, there aren't a ton of great and affordable places in Chicago for vegans and vegetarians to do this. You can roll up to the Handlebar on your bike, and partake in all of these earthly pleasures and still get outta there for under twenty bucks. There was a strange period last fall where there were some bizarre menu options and the place seemed to stray from the killer motif that is currently being used, but this summer, Handlebar is back with a punch. Check out the classic sandwiches and great sides that everyone loves. The drink specials also seem pretty tough to beat!

Me and the lady headed down here the other night and had a great time! The patio is great as well as the fried pickles! Nice beer selection + good vegan food+ gluten free menu for the lady = happy couple.
Several vegan options on the menu, the fried plantains are amazing. Very friendly, great place to get lunch/dinner. I need to go for brunch still.

Hi, I stopped by to meet a group of friends who were eating at the HB.  I joined them at the table and ordered a beer from the server.  Before my second sip the manager informed me that I could not drink my beer at the table and I had to drink it at the bar.  When I asked why then did the server just bring me a beer to the table, he asked me if i wanted my money back.  Wow, in my 37 yrs of life i have never been asked to leave anywhere, ever.  My friends were flabbergasted and left immediately.  Be clear those who frequent HB...Management/owners are total douche-bags.  I would be happy to verify this incident.  There is no excuse for their rudeness and arrogance.
everything on the menu is great. the patio is great the drinks are great the staff always great yay for greatness
Decent value for decent food. Ground nut stew and smoked gouda mac & cheese were good. Not much to say about this place... very casual service, doesn't over-achieve.

The food is a great!  Its a good relaxing spin on the new healthy veggie/fish craze.  The beer is cheap and they have great drink specials.  I got the Black Bean Maduro that was healthy, delicious and filling.  It was a combo of veggies beans & fried plantains! I also love it because it was unique.  I'll definitely be returning for drinks and to taste all the other delicious things I saw other people order when I was there.

Ive been to handle bar a few times and always loved my food. This time, I ordered the  chili quesadilla, it was pretty good, but a few hours later it made me totally sick! Ive eaten the same meal before and never had a problem,  this just makes me wonder if there was an issue with sanitation or food going bad. I called them a few hours later to talk to the manager and let him know what had happened, I shouldnt have to pay for a meal that makes me terrible sick, he offered me a beer if I came back, not what I had in mind but whatever. This made me pretty sad considering its one of my favorite places to eat with my husband.
YUMMMM to Veganism that's all I gots to say! Ugh who cares abot anything else =P FYI....It does get crowded but worth the wait! Drooling....

The Bad...PASS on the fried pickles. I've had better...Handlebar if you read this...switch to dill chips and not the spears...it will taste more like a fried pickle rather than a soggy mess and it will appear to give your customers a bit more to snack on as an appetizer while waiting for the real food. Four pickle spears isn't quite worth the $6 either. Now the Good....DO get the Handlebar Omelette.... An omelette with pears, walnuts and smoked gouda. A great vegetarian alternative to your normal omelette stuffed with ham, bacon or some other greasy hot mess.
Fried pickles and cheap drinks? What more can you want with garden seating on one of those rare beautiful days in Chicago?

3.5 stars.   The sandwiches are delicious.  On my first visit, the S.O. and I split the green meanie and the Chicago-style tofu.  The green meanie was fresh and the thin goat cheese layer added a nice flavor.  The Chicago-style tofu was very good.  The tofu was pressed to a thin layer I have never seen before, so much so that I kept forgetting I was eating a tofu sandwich.  The giardiniera was good but not overwhelming, which was beneficial as I don't generally like giardiniera.   The veggie chili is thick but satisfying on a cold day.  The plantains satisfied my craving, but weren't the best I have ever had.   On my second visit, I had the buffalo 'chicken' wrap, which didn't actually taste like buffalo sauce or meatless chicken I have had previously, but it was good.  I would order it again when I am craving a wrap, since most restaurants don't serve vegetarian-friendly wraps of substance.  On this visit, my friend ordered a special, which was essentially the black beans maduro entree on a torta.  It was good, but the amount of bread was overwhelming and my friend ended up removing one piece of the bread and turning it into an open-faced sandwich.  I would strongly recommend the black beans maduro entree on its own.   I was surprised that this place wasn't more of a bar, but rather more like a cafe that serves food and beer.  The tables are uncomfortably packed in, and they were busy both times I was there (Sunday afternoon, Tuesday evening).  I never felt like I could just chill with a drink, but rather that I needed to order and eat my food and clear space for the next patrons.   I'm very happy to have a pescatarian-friendly place where I can order everything on the menu without worrying if there is bacon or chicken hiding somewhere.  I just wish the vibe was less rushed and more linger-worthy.

Wooohooo!  Such a tasty, lovely place!  When Piece had an hour wait, my friends and I decided to go to Handlebar.  I was hoping that it was going to be loud and that we'd be screaming to each other during dinner, but the music wasn't bad at all.  Funky, cool decor.  I ordered the blackened catfish, veggie chili, mashed potatoes.  The catfish was just oozing with flavor...baked just right with a slight black crust.  The potatoes were light and homemade, with just the right amount of green onions mixed in.  The chili was ok, but a little bland...could've been spiced up a bit.  I've been to Karyn's and Chicago Diner, both vegan places I totally dig, but I think Handlebar may just beat both of them by a smidgen.  Maybe a bit pricier than the others, but perhaps it's worth it because the food is just so great. Now the REAL home-run was the rum, gingerbread, plantains and ice cream dish.  There isn't much else to say except that it was just simple heaven.
Amazing vegan breakfast. The vegan breakfast burrito is fantastic. Vegan biscuits and gravy, also wonderful. Awesome staff and a cool atmosphere. If you go in the morning try the beermosa - awesome!

LOVE this place! I had a "Bloody Hammer" which was pretty good! It's not the best bloody mary I've had, but it was very yummy. It comes with a fried pickle which was amazing. I had one of the specials which was the Rustic Benedict and the Mr. had the Green Meany sandwich and the Gouda Mac & Cheese. We loved every bit and cleaned our plates! The desserts sounded so good that we just couldn't resist. We shared the fried banana & nutella pies. Oh so gooooood. The staff is really friendly and laid back and the dining area is fun too. We'll definitely be going back to try out more of the menu!

I'd been wanting to try Handlebar since going vegan for Lent. I decided to go on a sunny afternoon for lunch. I had a doctor's appointment that morning that I was required to fast for, so by the time I got to Handlebar I was hungry enough to eat the table. It wasn't too crowded and I got a glass of water pretty quickly. I ordered the hibiscus-mint tea and a vegan breakfast burrito. It didn't take very long to get my food at all, and my server was very friendly. I've seen comments here about the service and while it wasn't lightning fast, I never felt ignored or unattended.  The hibiscus-mint tea is my new summer drink, hands down. Lightly sweet and slightly minty, it just tastes like summer in a glass. Their breakfast burrito came stuffed with fried potatoes, vegan chorizo, creamy avocado and fresh spinach leaves. The tortilla was toasted and a little flaky on the outside, but soft and pliant on the inside.  It came with a side of black beans and two kinds of salsa. The beans were simply just OK, leaning on the side of being slightly overcooked and undersalted. I didn't really need to eat too many of them because I was too busy making messy love to my burrito, which was so delicious I don't know why I'm not eating it every day. i was full when I finished it, but never felt weighed down or heavy like I'd feel if I had a more "typical" breakfast burrito with eggs, bacon, cheese, etc. Great experience at Handlebar, and I'm looking forward to another visit.

Me and my boyfriend love this place. The wait staff is always friendly, they have delicious vegan food for both brunch and dinner. We visit about once a week, if not more. The coffee is amazing as well, and the beer selection on tap never lets me down. They also have seafood and vegetarian options, but I can't speak on those two. :)

Not at all what I expected...pretty small, every table was taken, bar was impossible to get to, pretty young crowd (early 20s).  The service was very good - we only had a beer and shared an entree - pork enchilatas - it was very good.  I'll definately give it another shot.

I've been here a few times, but I had either just eaten, or I was with a coworker that had just eaten. Either way I enjoyed their beer selection - reminded me of all the great selection I get in my home, Seattle.  This time I ate lunch, and it was great! I ordered the BBQ seitan sandwich with soup. Was going to order the Mac and cheese, but I was so stuffed with just the soup. The sandwich was piled high with seitan. The sauce was just spicy enough, and it's simplicity of bread, seitan, sauce and onion was great. The soup was hearty and tasted great. The pickle was amazing - I am going to miss it. Seitan was good, and reminded me a lot of te stuff I make at home but it was a little saltier.  Beer was great, filled my belly, and now I am back on the blue line headed to O'hare. I am definitely coming back here next trip.

My favorite thing to do on vacation (or, well, all the time) is eat and if you love to eat, Handlebar is a place that doesn't disappoint. I dined at Handlebar on a busy weekend night with a party of three. We arrived at around 9 and were told there would be a half hour wait, but ended up being seated within 15-20 minutes. Our waiter was friendly and the service was prompt. I ordered the fish tacos (amazingly fresh catfish with red cabbage, ripe avocado, and tomatillo salsa) and was thrilled with my choice. The tacos had a great balance of textures and flavors and the sides were delicious. The portions were generous and the prices were moderate. (OK, it felt a little pricey, but I'm totally cheap and the food was amazing, so I assume that works out to "moderate prices.") I don't normally order dessert, but ended up indulging in the fried PB&J pies -- two mini-empanadas filled with peanut butter and jelly. The pies were a little heavy on the PB vs. the J for my taste and ended up seeming a little heavy, but I bet I could have easily offset the heaviness by adding a scoop of ice cream, were it not for my aforementioned cheapskate nature. Dining at Handlebar was one of the highlights of my eating experiences in Chicago and I definitely look forward to chowing down there again (hopefully soon!)

After having fried pickles here, I have come to the conclusion that they are, after the tater-tot, my favorite fried appetizer (I'm excluding wings here, because buffalo wings are a true art from).  Handlebar's are pretty good.  Not only that, given the fact that they have pretty good craft beers makes this a pretty awesome spot.  The only drawback is that it's in the Wicker Parkish area.

Well, Handlebar definitely lived up to it's name. I spotted at least four dudes (and maybe one lady) sporting handlebar mustaches here on Saturday night. I guess I shouldn't have been surprised. Vegetarian restaurants usually are a magnet for this type, especially ones located in such a prime ironic-handlebar-mustache-ugly sweater or flannel shirt-skinny jean-thick framed glasses-wearing-carry my bike helmet-neighborhood. But I'm not here to review hipsters, I'm here to review the restaurant... Handlebar had a lot of potential. The wife (a vegan-terian) and I were pretty pumped to try some of the things we saw on the menu while checking out the website. We got there (we drove in a car, not a fixie) and were seated right away.  Appetizer: We ordered fried pickles. They were ok, but nothing to write home about.  Entrees: We ordered the bbq seitan sandwich (with fries) and the buffalo chicken wrap (with the mac n cheese). The bbq seitan sandwich came out cold. Well, scratch that, a few of the chunks were luke-warm. So obviously, an attempt was made to serve the sandwich warm, but that attempt failed. So needless to say, the sandwich was a huge letdown. The fries, on the other hand, were pretty great.  The buffalo chicken wrap was slightly better (and warmer!). Unfortunately, it seemed as though only one piece of chicken made it into my wrap. Bummer. The mac n cheese was alright...nothing too special, but not too bad. It got cold really quickly though, so I felt that I needed to eat it kind of fast.  Service: "Slow" and "Inattentive" come to mind. We didn't order drinks, that might have been the problem? Who knows. It wasn't extremely busy when we were seated, but it took a while for the waiter to come around. The food came out pretty quickly, but our waters weren't refilled until after we got our check. Kind of inconsistent. Overall: We won't be back. Might have been an off night for the staff at Handlebar, but maybe that is typical, I guess we'll never know.

The Ground Nut Stew is hands down my favourite thing to eat within a 1 mile range.  The fish tacos are also good.  Good beer selection, great service.  My friends and I love this place, brought my family here too.  I just wish it was open a little later.

I've had a few good meals here, but my last experience was disappointing. The day started with poor customer service. Then two of the seven meals at our table were very disappointing. My wife ordered an overpriced salad, which was lacking pears and walnuts. It seemed a little pricey for a plate of arugula. My daughter ordered a nacho dish and the tortilla chips were chewy. She is a little shy, but was disappointed enough to send the plate back and order something else. Other diners in our group said their meals were "OK" but lacking flavor. If I want a vegan meal, I'll probably skip this place and go to Chicago Diner.
Fantastic delish food and awesome drink specials!  $3 Pabst on draft and Metallica!?  So many vegan dishes to choose from and super friendly staff...stop in you won't be disappointed!

Green Meanie. Smoked gouda mac and cheese. Bells. Can't beat it. I can walk there from my place, the music is always pretty good, the staff is pretty nice (if you have the right haircut and the requisite tattoos) but the food is great. As a vegetarian, I'm spoiled.  Oh, but they don't split checks so know before you go.

So.  I have to say that I was not happy when we walked in and saw that there were no open tables.  The quickest way to upset me is to put me in a crowded group of people and tell me I have to wait for food.  But, much to my surprise, we got in after about 3 minutes.  Sweet.  Anyway, good beer selection, good mac n cheese.  I liked my sandwich but I couldn't finish it.  Server was polite and the food came very fast.  Overall, it was a good experience!

5 stars because: 1) They have amazing food 2) They have great servers 3) Never so busy that I had to wait more than 20 minutes for a table The servers are aware they are serving both vegetarian and vegan cuisine and will ask you if you are "ok" with cheese on your entree if you didn't specify.  I think this is a nice touch - it shows they are looking out for vegans. Great for pescatarians (sp)/vegetarians/vegans!!

Today we tried Handlebar for the first time, and we met some friends for brunch. We were lucky that we showed up early enough that we did not have to wait for a table at all. We started with the fried pickles, and I was blown away by the vegan buttermilk ranch dressing. It was creamy and delicious. My husband and I are both meat eaters, but we loved the food. I had the vegan burrito and my husband had the shrimp and grits (I know.. shrimp isn't vegetarian). Everything was perfectly cooked. We will be back!

i expected a heaping plate of tasty vegetarian fuel at this space that is supposedly a bike messenger hang out and seemingly has a mexican inspired menu. you know, you need to fuel up to ride that bike. what i got was surprisingly fru fru and i spent twice what i normally would have for a well rounded vegetarian meal. in retrospect, maybe i should have ordered the "three sides" which would have cost half the amount, but i made the mistake of ordering an entree and a side of protein, (seitan) thinking i would have enough for 2 meals, as i usually would at a vegetarian place, for that amount of cash. nope. the place has a nice vibe and the food was tasty enough, but, sorry kids. certainly wouldn't go at all out of my way to go back.
Had a great time here on my visit to Chicago. Great food, great atmosphere and great theme.
Enlightened beer selection in both bottles and draft.  Tasty food, satisfying to even non-vegetarian palates.  Homespun in all the right ways.

Love, love, LOVE this place. I was vegan for a few months and was greatful that my boss had suggested the place.  The food is DELICIOUS. I have not been disappointed with anything that I've ordered there so far. The service can be slow at times but it's really no big deal. There's usually good music playing and I'm never in a hurry to leave.  Little tip: The nachos are a meal in itself. It's hard to tackle with even 2 people. It's definitely my go to after a hangover. Also, I feel like this place has like, a hotness requirement. Pinky swear that the male servers are very easy on the eyes. Especially one in particular. But, I wont get into that. ;)

Stop complaining about the customer service. Its been that way for as long as I can remember. You go there for the food or because your friend hooks you up at the bar. If they all of a sudden started giving great CS, I'd prolly not go back. Wouldn't seem right.

Let me start from the very beginning. My dad wanted to try this place out a few years ago and had me call to see if they were BYOB.   Me :Hello, what are your hours, and are you byob?   Handlebar: We're open till 11 tonight, and we aren't byob.  We're a bar. Me:  Oh right, handleBAR.  wow, I am slow. Handlebar: (laughter) So we went to handlebar and I have been going there for about 3 years now.  The food is super yummy and you won't need meat ever again unless it is fish! Food:  Pretty much everything is yummy here.  Black bean tostadas, chili nachos, the black beans maduros, just about everything is great.  Right now I am currently in love with the huevos diablos for brunch, with avocado. (Although I recommend soul veg east on 75th if you want a delicious bbq sammich that is meat-free.the one here is just okay in comparison) Service: i love the staff here. they are very honest about their opinion of the dishes and will be more than understanding if you have foodie's remorse or dietary restrictions. The beer list is great and they always have good specials for both drinks and for food.  I will continue to go here.  forever. Also!  they have rotating art work on the walls.  which is fun and changes things without changing the layout of the spot.  love it.

A vegan friend and I came in to get some grub and I had never been here. She and I both ordered some cups of soup that were delicious and then we split the tofu fajitas. That was 3 weeks ago and I'm still craving those fajitas. I've even ventured to the grocery store and purchased all of the same ingredients to attempt making them at home but whatever that seasoning is, the dry rub on the tofu, it is like crack. Although I steer clear of neighborhood as much as possible, I am completely willing to go just for these damn fajitas. YUM!

This place was seriously delicious. I absolutely loved that I could eat everything there. Even though it was all vegetarian my boyfriend (who eats meat like it's his job) loved the food as well! I got the fish tacos which tasted so fresh and delicious that I had to eat them all. My bf got the shrimp and grits which were also fabulous. The beer selection is also pretty stellar. This place is literally a block away from my bf's apartment so I can't believe that we haven't gone before. The service was great and we got our food super quick. They also have a deal of a pony of high life and a shot of malort for $4 which probably sounds terrible to most people but it is a little bit of home to me. I will be coming back here a lot. Sooooo yummy!

Handlebar has more of  a bar style and atmosphere than it does a restaurant style and atmosphere. You should know this going in-- that's why it's handlebar and not handle-restaurant. The staff is excellent and very friendly and provides good casual service without the formal airs of typical restaurant service. They have an very nice selection of craft beers and delicious cocktails, and there is a drink special for every day of the week. They frequently change up the beers that are on special, which is nice because it allows you to try new things without worrying about the cost as much. That said, the staff is pretty friendly and will probably just pour you a small sample of something if you want to try it before committing to it. What really makes Handlebar special in addition to the staff and good casual service is the food. I'm not a vegetarian or a vegan-- in fact a bacon cheddar burger is one of my favorite things to order. I've eaten at vegetarian and vegan restaurants in San Francisco and Berkeley and Washington DC, but I have to say eating vegetarian isn't normally my preference. Handlebar has really delicious food. It is far better than most pub-grub and much more delicious than a lot of high-end vegetarian restaurants I've tried. I don't care if it's vegetarian or not-- the food is just plain awesome! It's not high-end fancy food from the Publican, but it is seriously delicious. So, if you like bars and you like good food served in bars, then Handlebar is perfect.

1) If it is vegan it must be healthy. 2) If it is vegan it can't taste good. This place undoubtedly reveals statements 1 and 2 to be false. Everything here is freaking delicious. Mah-gawd. That's really the best way I can put it. Plus, they have great beer selection to go with your meal. However, fried pickles, fried sweet plantains, etc. These dishes, albeit delicious, aren't too friendly to thee ol' waistline. This is particularly true when consumed in large quantities. The sad truth is that I'll keep coming here, and I'll keep living in a fool's paradise... a yummy, delicious, fool's paradise... filed with fried pickles... /drool.

This place is spacious and chill and boasts a friendlier-than-they-look staff. The vegan "buffalo chicken" is a favourite (even our non-vegan foodie friend loved it) and they have gluten-free beer available. The only reason a star got knocked off is location - it's not necessarily the easiest place to visit.

Went with my brother (who had been before) and my son to Handlebar.  What an incredible find (by my brother and his wife).  Waited on immediately by our fabulous server Kyle who couldn't have been more accommodating.  The best macaroni and cheese I've EVER had and fabulous French Toast.  Had the breakfast burrito which was incredible.  Nothing to complain about other than wishing it was closer to Naperville!  Will return!!  Thanks little brother!

Great place.  As a proud omnivore, it took me a while to try Handlebar.  Glad I finally did.  The space emits that cool, "hole-in-the-wall" feel that reminds you why you live in a great food city like Chicago. (although I was puzzled by the fake birds) The samosas and black bean tostadas are must-order items. I could easily made a meal out of those.  I went with the seared tuna sandwich.  The flavor was great and the tuna was cooked perfectly.  My only real complaint came from the bar side.  In what I deemed to be a health conscience, attention-to-ingredient restaurant, I was only minorly disappointed in the use of Roses Lime in some of the mixed drinks.   Good stuff and Handlebar is now definitely on my list!

I really like this place because its laid back and as unpretentious as you could get, yet the food is really really nice. It even looks nice. You can tell that thought was actually put into the menu. The portions are huge, so you'll definitely have leftovers. Its a great place for a chill dinner with friends in a quiet-er area of the neighborhood. Definitely try it out! Prices are great, too. Can't wait to go back.
Black Bean Maduro......soooo good!

Handlebar is wonderful. The food is always delicious, no matter what you order. They have a great beer selection and something is usually on special. The prices are pretty reasonable as well. The people are awesome here, both the staff and the other patrons. Such a wide variety of individuals, but everyone comes because the food is that great. I love the decor as well...everything is bike influenced. Sometimes it's a bit too crowded and the service gets a little slow, but it's well worth it.

No offense but I can't stand the tofu based meat substitute "seitan".  So for me that wipes half the dishes I would try off their menu.   And why serve real eggs and not real chicken?  Since I don't see the difference that's probably why I'm not a vegetarian and also not their fault.   But lunch service was really slow.  Actually it was obvious they lost track of our order for a while.  We visited in the middle of weekday lunch rush and maybe they were having an unusually bad day.  But it doesn't offer any confidence for visiting on the weekend when it's going to be really busy.  I might try them again if coerced.

Ok, there are +500 reviews already, so I'll keep it short: Favs: black bean tostada, buffalo chicken wrap (and I'm VERY picky about the buffalo 'chicken' stuff...this taste awesome and not rubbery like so many other places); black bean maduro (SPICY!!) Also: Great beer selection. Veg food that appeals to everyone and not too much of the fake meat stuff. Only reason I took 1 star off is because i feel like they could use a little more entree choices. There are only 4 vegetarian entrees...Handlebar would you consider adding more?

There are over 500 reviews for this place, so my dumb little review will more than likely get lost in the wave.  I am absolutely not vegan or vegetarian, so I chose to review this as a *restaurant*, not as a special one.   The restaurant's environment was adequate, but the food was not that impressive.  The samosas were tasty, but the sauces to go with them were meh.  I got the grilled catfish with collard greens and the gouda mac-n-cheese.  The fish was a little bland, while the mac was pretty tasty.  I'm southerner, and those collard greens were not good at all.  They were crunchy and way too vibrantly green.  One friend had the Green Meanie and the other had the black been burger, neither of which they raved about.  We got some (vegan) ranch dressing to dip the fries with which was simply delicious, but they charged us a dollar for it. While the beer list was impressive, sluggish service does this restaurant no justice.   This place does nothing to convince me that vegetarian's the way to go.

The Handlebar is the best of ALL worlds.   ---I'm vegan and love that I can come here with vegetarians and carnivores alike.  They use quality ingredients for creative dishes that I often times find myself trying to replicate at home.  In addition to their stellar vegan options they have seafood and plenty of cheesy dishes for vegan-phobes (not that many people who hang out here are vegan-phobes). ---They have a solid beer list at reasonable prices .  This makes my beer snob husband happy and also makes it a great place to go with a group if some people want quality eats while others just want drinks. ---Maybe I'm biased because I heart LCD Soundsystem, but their music selection has never disappointed and isn't so loud that it's intrusive.  The atmosphere is laid back with lots of character and I like the waitstaff. ---And I save the best for last....CORNMEAL BATTERED FRIED PICKLES!!! w/ house made vegan ranch dressing (you'd never know it was vegan and even haters of ranch dressing have been known to find it tasty).  The night I ordered fried pickles with a Revolution Rye Stout was heaven.  This place goes in my five star hall of fame because it's so reliable, so comfortable, and always impressive.

As far as beet salads go, this is as good as it gets. Add to it a side of fried plantains and it is total heaven. Service is always great. Prices are always great. I've been going here a long time and have never had a bad experience or less than stellar food. I can also come here with my vegan friends which is a huge plus. Great selection of beers and easy parking.

My lady friend is a vegetarian, so its nice to go a place where she has more than one option.  There are over 500 reviews, so people like this place and you don't need my description.   I had the grilled tofu sandwich and my lady friend had the black beans maduro.  The fries that came with sandwich were great, my lady friend liked, not loved, the black bean maduro.  I think she was just expecting too much because its vegetarian friendly.  So she was let down, I told her to deal with it just like everyone who voted for Obama...anyways I would return to Handlebar and I like the eerie birds all over the place.  P.S. I did make the mistake of leaving my over-sized dark rimmed glasses and facial hair at home, but whatever.

I've been there a few times and can't wait to go back.  Their Huevos Diablos is a little spicy with a great mix of flavors.  The french toast and syrup are also excellent.  I did try their macaroni/cheese and it's probably the best I've had.  The service is  friendly and attentive.  I think it's a little pricey (hot choc $4, french toast $8.50) but again excellent quality.

For people who fear vegetarian food or shy away from vegan fare, Handlebar proves that veggie and vegan-friendly food can be delicious, creative and absolutely satisfying. Some dishes here will simply knock your socks off. On a winter night, try the Ground Nut Stew. In the summer, the Mexican dishes are delish. Always, always, always order fried pickles, year-round. Handlebar, if you're listening, please make that delicious Root Vegetable Shepherd's Pie a regular October-to-March offering. Sweet sally celeraic, that is GOOD. Plenty of delicious beers on tap, good drink specials and a lovely bar for libations. Come for your veggie/vegan friends, stay for yourself.
I love this place because it is good to take your non vegan friends to and everybody can eat! The Samosa is the business!

I fucking love this place. Given the location and style, the typical crowd is tolerable and not too in your face. The  Buffalo Chicken Wrap is incredible and I try to go here once a week. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

I've been here a few times. Definitely try the smoked gouda mac & cheese. Service is attentive and the place is spacious. Try sitting in the back garden patio area when it gets warmer. Nice drink selection. All I have to say is...vegetarian/vegan grub jackpot! Whether you are a vegetarian or not, the food is tasty here. One of my favorites is the bbq seitan. They're very friendly to bike messengers here.

This is our go to brunch spot.  Whenever we go here may day becomes exponentially better.  Tons of terrific vegan options. My favorites are the biscuits and gravy and french toast.  Come here and come often.

I am not a hipster. I don't own skinny jeans, wear oversized glasses, or confuse leggings for pants. However, I'll walk into Handlebar in my REI fleece, regular old jeans and running shoes anyway, because their food is so damned good. This is vegan/vegetarian comfort food at its best. Sure, you won't find dishes that are as artfully arranged as Karyn's restaurants, or crazy experimentations with root vegetables, but that's not the point. The purpose of going to Handlebar is to get incredibly tasty, stick-to-your-ribs goodness in large portions at reasonable prices. The deep fried pickles? The best I've had, thanks to their cornmeal and chile exterior. The black bean maduros? Everyone else on here's covered them, so all I can say is go order them, shell out for the avocado, and enjoy. Also, they really aren't that spicy, at least if you're a spicy food fiend. So far, all of the specials I've tried have been superb, and their vegan fried pies are worth buying extra to take home. I'd give it five stars, but I'm a curmudgeonly Seattleite who thinks the music is too loud, the service a bit too laissez-faire, and the strength of their bloody Marys inconsistent. Nonetheless, I absolutely freaking love this place and will drag everyone I can to join me for late brunches on chilly winter afternoons.

Not only is service attentive, but the food is good. I shared the chili cheese fries with a friend. Chili is definitely a bit spicy, though I prefer more cheese. I got the gouda mac and cheese (omgggg so good) with the buffalo wrap. That was actually too spicy for me. I couldn't finish it because not only was it spicy, but there was not much dressing. My friend had the grilled cheese. He liked it. Four stars still.
Liked this place, fun/crowded/fast paced.  Service was slow for a breakfast but there was plenty to look at :) Vegan (didn't realize it when we went in) and good.
Servers are cool as HAIL with a nice beer selection. Love the seitan nachos, fish tacos and nut soup (no snickering).

Gotta Get Take Out So, I was sitting around thinking that I really wanted to try out some new restaurants but I wanted to stay in and watch a movie. I don't know why I don't get take out more often.  Once I got to Handlebar I was wishing a had come to stay. The place wasn't that great and it was busy so it would have definitely taken a while to get a table. But for some reason it made me want to stay, hand out and get a bite to eat. Never the less I still had a great night with some good food.

I absolutely adore this place.  The back patio is great in the warmer/warmish months.  The inside is appropriately dark and cozy.  The food is always on point.   My heavy recommendations go out to the meal of sides -- I prefer greens, chili, and french fries.  The fried 'chicken' salad is perfect and it's kissing cousin the buffalo 'chicken' wrap are always sure to please.  The specials are somewhat hit or miss here however.  I've had some winners and some dogs (hence my 4 stars) My brunch fave is the pepita tofu scramble.  It is really a knockout of basic ingredients in the correct combination poised for deliciousness.  The pesto made with pepitas (pumpkin seeds) is so crave-able and it just sings when combined with the sweet potatoes and kale.  Yeah, I said it sang; it's that tasty.   Another fave are the fried pies if you save room.  They are always vegan and the flavors are usually seasonal and super on point.  The best I've ever had are the coconut ones.  Please.  Please.  Bring them back.  I think we may have gotten a second order that's how good they were. Friendly waitstaff, wide assortment of adult beverages for my friends who drink and for me perfect coffee that always puts a pep in my step...basically yes.  I do love this place.

Love love love.  An actual BAR that has vegan/vegetarian food?  Get out of town!  LOVE IT.  Went on a Thursday night...and this place was packed at 7pm!  Thankfully we beat the rush by a few minutes and didn't have to wait to be seated.   They have a great list of bottled beer, and their list of drinks on tap are impressive as well.  I was happy they had one of my fave beers on tap (Allagash White).   Very laid back environment..casual wear (think dive bar type)...ambiance is quite chill/laid back...its a little dark in there too.  I think I ate so much here, they had to roll me out the door...the nacho appetizers were yummy with the seitan chorizo...for my "meal" I had the BBQ seitan sandwich which was great (and filling), the smoked gouda mac and cheese was to die for (i wish that was an entree)...and for a special they had polenta fries with an alioli sauce which was outstanding!  The grits were ok...had a lot of that left over. We didn't have room for dessert...as i stuffed my face with all this amazing vegetarian food. Since parking was easy, and the prices were great...I will be back for sure!

Confession: by no means am I vegetarian.  A friend recommended having dinner here and I was a bit apprehensive with no meat options but thank goodness I took the plunge.  One word: delish! I ended up ordering the black beans maduro and I still crave it today!  Perfectly cooked plantains, brown rice, black beans and some other things.  The kicker - chipotle tomato sauce surrounds the whole thing.  Definitely not for those who don't like heat.  In fact, I saw others order it on the side. My friend ordered a special - sloppy joes made with tofu.  Pretty good.  He was worried he would still be hungry but after it came to the table, we were afraid he wouldn't be able to finish it.   I'll definitely be back, especially now that I  know they have a outdoor patio.

We went here for a quick bite on Wednesday night.  It was impressive that all six of us were able to get seated without a wait--but given the size of the restaurant, and its popularity, we were probably just lucky.  The atmosphere is small, casual, and funky.  Service was very prompt, and wait times were very reasonable. Onto the food:  We ordered the nachos with "chorizo" for an appetizer.  Delicious.  And HUGE.  There were six of us, and nachos left over.  For dinner, I had a delicious bowl of their tortilla soup and a small Handlebar salad.  The soup and salad combo were amazingly delicious--I think if I were to go back, I'd just get a large handlebar salad the Parmesan and balsamic dressing rocks!   I would have given 5 stars, but my girlfriend got the Tuna Sandwich, and ended up throwing up all night.  It was definitely food poisoning, and while there's a small possibility it could have been something else, in all likelihood, it was the Ahi Tuna.  In spite of this, I would go back.  Just probably would stay away from the fish items.
Love this place.  Great selection of beer both on draft and in bottles.  Get the fried pickles.

This is one of my favorite places to go in the entire city and I am not even a vegan! The buffalo "chicken" wrap is my favorite and while I'm usually willing to take an adventure on the menu , I can never pass this entre up. The environment is great. Not a hipster? No judgment here. They play great music, have fun artwork, and nice staff. They also have a great beer list which can be enjoyed to the fullest in the beer garden out back. It has the perfect ambiance with a good mix of mood lighting and a not-too-loud atmosphere. Can't say I discovered this place on my own and I probably never would have, for fear of being judged for my non-hipster, non-vegan self; but it has come to be an absolute favorite.

Words cannot describe how much I adore Handlebar. We came for brunch, and chose to sit in the back patio. It was a fun, quirky space with great atmosphere. They brought over a carafe of water right away (always a plus in my book) and the waitstaff was friendly and attentive.  I ordered the vegan breakfast burrito and was pleasantly surprised. Most restaurants either make veggie breakfast burritos as if they've just taken out the meat, or jam pack it with tofu. This was seitan-based, but it was subtle. The flavors of the spinach, potato and avocado stood out much more in a great way. The salsa was fresh and the black beans were flavorful.  My fiance order the vegan Diablo and really enjoyed that as well. Good coffee, great laid-back atmosphere, and friendly people. We'll definitely be coming back.

always solid. i ALWAYS try specials now because i've had pretty much everything else on the menu & it's safe to say that it's the way to go.   perfect neighborhood place with a great bar.  the hours are perf.

This is the closest vegan friendly dinner joint to my apartment and I'm SO HAPPY about that because this place is awesome. The beer menu is good for a restaurant and they have a pretty damn tasty brunch too. I've never had anything I didn't like here and I really appreciate the huge number of choices available for vegans. Adding some vegan cheese to the menu and a vegan mac and cheese is really all I can imagine to make this place better. It's a little loud for my taste sometimes, but the noise level goes with the atmosphere so I give them a break.

went here the other day with a friend who's been here several times, and seeing that i'm not eating meat this month (it's vegetarian awareness month) it was a good place for me to grab a bite. she said they had pretty decent food, so i was in. i'm very open to eating fake meats, and i really do enjoy most of them, as long as they are done right -- same with meat. i love meat, as long as it's done right, or it can be a total disaster. luckily for hamndlebar, i think they can do it right. i went with the bbq seitan sandwich, with a premium side of cheesy grits. my friend ordered the tostadas and a side of gouda mac and cheese.  the service was pretty good, and the food was pretty good as well. the bbq sauce had good flavor, the seitan had good texture, if i had a complaint, it would be that i wish the sauce had a little more smokiness to it, but that's just my own personal opinion =] the cheesy grits were kind of awesome, cheesy goodness. and so was the mac -- had a deep intense flavor cause of the gouda, and i likey. i would definitely come back for more veggie goodness, and i'm also tempted to try one of their seafood dishes.  ps. if you enjoy hipster watching, sit by the window, and knock yourself out.

My wife and I are vegetarians of long standing, so ... we perk up when presented with the rare opportunity to sample a place like this. Once in this joint, we realized we are not the target demo ... not being adorned with rasta dreads, tatoos, body piercings and what not. That's OK. I'm with them in spirit if not appearance. What did not sit well with us was the music and the lighting (or lack there of).  The music (indie rock?) was blasting at such a level that I commented to the waiter that I felt like I was hanging out at the Aragon. Quiet, romantic dinner for two - not. Go there with a gang of friends who don't mind yelling at each other across the table - OK. Maybe i didn't like the music so much either (picky picky). If you're going to blast music that loud, make it Metal. The lighting was such that I really resorted to blind faith as I navigated my way through a decent African Nut Stew. I knew the ingredients because I read the menu. Candles on the table would have helped the overall murkiness. The food was OK. Hard not to compare to stuff we make at home for ourselves most nights at a fraction of the cost. My return to this place will probably be after a Jesus Lizard show with a rowdy bunch instead of a date night setting.

Food:  5 Service:  2 Atmosphere:  4 Value:  4 I went for lunch with my wife on labor day and we were impressed.  Like most places in Wicker Park, the atmosphere was quirky, yet inviting.  It took a little while for a host to seat us, but as you can see by my ratings, service is not their strong point.  We outside in the back patio and felt quite comfortable. The menu is large and diverse, and obviously I loved the vegetarian-friendly fare.  It was hard to choose, but my wife had the Roasted Beet and Spinach Salad with Blackened Tofu, I had the Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap with Smoked Gouda Mac N Cheese, and we split the Chili Cheese Fries. The Fries came out first and they were delicious.  The Chili was rich and filling and had a zesty flavor, the cheese was melted nicely, and it was a great appetizer-size portion.  My only complaint is that the fries could have been a little crispier, but that's tough to do when you douce them with chili and cheese.   The Buffalo Chicken Wrap was a treat, as I love fried chicken.  The buffalo sauce wasn't overpowering, and the vegan ranch added a nice, cool, refreshing flavor.  I would have liked a few more pieces of "chicken" in it, though.  The Mac N Cheese was out of this world-definitely worth the upcharge.  It was creamy-not baked-and the gouda added a smooth, smoky flavor.   My wife enjoyed her salad, which was presented nicely and large enough to be a complete entree.  She said it was pretty standard, but done well.  She also said the blackened tofu was well-seasoned. Overall, I would definitely recommend this restaurant to vegetarians and non-vegetarians alike. [Thanks for reading my review and be sure to check out my other reviews on Yelp.  My mission is to find restaurants that have great vegetarian, kosher, and vegan fare.  On every review, I rate food, service, atmosphere, and value on a 1-5 scale to give you quick and easy overview of the restaurant.  I love cooking, eating, and doing both with my friends and family.  I always welcome your questions, comments, and suggestions so contact me on Yelp or Facebook if you want to share ideas.]

As a fish is my only type of meat girl this place is the best!  I eat here approximately 3 times a week and have never had a bad meal.  In particular I love love love the vegan chili, fish tacos and gouda mac & cheese.  Awesome selection of well priced micro brews that are mostly local and hard to find i.e. Half Acre and a daily special of a shot of tequila and tecate for $5!  The service I find to treat you like royalty once they know you and be rather standoffish at first.  I am not a bike messenger or hipster from Wicker so the first 2 or 3 visits they were courteous not amazing. If you aren't a messenger don't go on a Tuesday when the place is swamped with them - a very cliquish group.

Are you funny about meat?  You kinda like how meat tastes, until you have that weird gristly bite?  Well, the Handlebar is for you. Offering dishes such as a bbq seitan sandwich and fried "chicken" salad, they do vegan interpretations of casual meat dishes very well.  I last had a seitan gyro special that was really fresh and tasty. They do serve fish, and I'll have to try the fish tacos at some point. Service is great.

I realize this makes me a minority amongst Yelpers, but I'm just going to go ahead with it. Handlebar is A-OK for now, perhaps in the foreseeable future I will give it another try and perhaps a star bump.  I was here for a friend's birthday, I wasn't too hungry so I ordered beers and this smoked gouda mac & cheese I've read so much about. Beers were amazing, selection was good (including some nice seasonal choices involving pumpkins and Oktoberfest!). But this mac & cheese arrived in a lukewarm state with small chunks of hardened cheese in it, anyone with a tastebud can tell it's been sitting out somewhere for awhile. While disappointing, that's certainly not so horrifying that I wouldn't come back to try other food someday. With all the sexual innuendo from other reviews, I thought this place was going to literally knock my socks off!! But really, not so much...

Someone worked really hard to try and make this place look as cool as the food they served.  I really have no qualms with how The Handlebar is runI have eaten there twice in three days since discovering this fine establishment.  The kitchen staff really does an amazing job, and I can't but help take a bite of everyone's plate while i am there.   They food here is sort of pricey, however there isn't a price you could put on some of the menu items.   For instance the Smoked Gouda Mac N' Cheese, they could charge triple for it and I would still purchase it (don't get me wrong, I'm glad they don't.).  The dishes they have that are traditionally meat dishes are pretty incredible.  The buffalo chicken wrap taste's just like chicken wings, but with a little less sauce.   The seitan gyro wrap was a better gyro that I have had in most Greek restaurants.    They made their own pickles, and having them battered and fried was pretty divine.   Service was pretty stellar when I was there, with pretty epic drink specials.  I sat on the outside patio and they let me smoke outside.  I have yet to try their desserts, but only because I gorge myself stupid on the grub.  Also every time I've been in their they have great punk, and garage music playing.  My only suggestion would be maybe a couple of more appetizer items, maybe a hummus plate, or "value items"....   I am definitely a fan of this place!  I highly recommend this place as a fun take a date establishment, or even a casual mid afternoon snack.  Definitely gonna make this a regular thing, me and the Handlebar are gonna have a sordid affair.

Today I lost my handlebar virginity (ooohh...that didn't sound entirely good, but whatever!).  I got the handlebar salad and some fries and, boy howdy, were they good! My dining companions got breakfast burritos, wraps, and other goodness that made me a wee bit jealous. One had a beermosa. I don't know how that would taste, but she guzzled it with little trouble (along with a vegan bloody mary...which I wish I would've tried).  I'll definitely come here again when I'm in the 'hood. But seeing as I live all the way in Andersonville, it mightn't be for a few weeks. I want to try out a breakfast burrito next time...

I realize I risk being called loose, but I tore my pants off last night and humped Handlebar until I could hump no more.  No flirting.  No foreplay. No nothing.  I had never even seen him or heard of him before our little romp.  It was a raw and dirty case of I Came, I Saw, I Conquered.  Or more accurately, I Saw, I Conquered, I Came. I have to admit, I didn't use protection. That being the case, I didn't even feel guilty the morning after. HOT DAMN, HANDLEBAR!  HOW DO YOU DO IT? I rolled into Chicago a few days ago and was looking for place to go to dinner with my other half and his friend.  His friend suggested Hooters.  I suggested no effing way.  Boobs are nice and all, but I have two of my own.  Moreover, I'm a vegetarian, so the wings don't do anything for me.  Nor do the loins draped in tangerine spandex.  Since I haven't lived in the area since the late 90s I consulted Yelp!, looking for vegetarian Mexican options.  One of the first reviews said something about hipsters on bicycles, and despite being neither a hipster nor a bicycle lover, I know this restaurant was going to cater to my lost San Franciscan soul. From the second I saw our hipster waitress in a revolting crocheted sweater and granny glasses I knew I would be in for a sexy time explosion.   The black beans maduro were mind-bogglingly good.  The plaintains in them are cooked perfectly and the BBQ chipotle sauce was as hot as Ricky Martin in tight pants back when we all pretended that he was straight.  MUY CALIENTE!  The two folks with me both ordered the blackened catfish, gouda mac & cheese, and sesame broccoli.  Both were fully thrilled by their choices.  Our tostada appetizer was also spot-on delicious. Great meal.  Great service.  Great drinks (not very stiff, but delicious nonetheless).  Great in general. Will I be left pining over Handlebar when I leave Chicago in a few days?  Who knows, but I'm always excited to have a smoldering sexy sailor waiting for me in every port.   It was real, Handy.  See you soon. [If you like Handlebar and go to Toronto, check out Utopia!]

ahh, labor day -- a three day weekend meant for pbrs, good company, and ... faux chicken?  okaaaaay, so my friend messed up and brought us here inadvertently.  due to his slight inability to read, what was supposed to be a meal of burgers and bbq ended up being vegetarian.  what's really crazy is that this bunch of carcass eaters didn't even miss the meat! everything that i tried on the menu was great, but standouts were the "chicken" gyro, french fries, buffalo seitan wrap and the gouda mac and cheese.  i want to stress that this the type of place where vegetarians/vegans can drag their friends and not worry that the friends will try to gnaw on the other patrons in order to avoid eating sprouts.  this is also the kind of place where you can marvel that ALMOST ANYTHING CAN TASTE LIKE CHICKEN!  if a bevy of illiterate carnivores can dig it here, you can too.  because at least you can read.

My friend suggested this place for dinner knowing I was vegetarian. While I am open to pretty much all restaurants, I love when I have a whole menu of options to choose from. Handlebar definitely epitomizes Wicker Park- a cool, interesting hipster joint. The bicycle decor lent a casual and funky atmosphere. And the food...so good! We started off with the nachos which were great but the black beans maduro entree surpassed all expectations! The sweet plantains were crunchy and soft at the same time and the chipotle sauce...now I have the highest tolerance for spicy food and I hardly ever find anything adequately spicy but the chipotle sauce in the maduro was so flavorful and spicy, I couldn't stop eating!! The beer selections were also good All in all, a great place in Wicker Park for a casual dinner and drinks, especially if you are vegetarian/vegan.

If your in the neighborhood this place is where you want to eat.  Awesome little patio, cool bar, friendly staff and everything I have ever ordered came out amazingly great.  Smoked Gouda Mac n Cheese !!!

I came here with my boyfriend last night for the first time.  I was impressed by the amount to vegetarian options they had and that fact that you could veganize them if desired.  I was eying up the fried pickles right away!  (At the MN state fair they are on a stick and filled with cream cheese!)  I was delighted to see that one came with the Bloody Hammer (Bloody Mary with a little Guinness and a spicy mix.)  Unfortunately I didn't get the vegan ranch dressing that comes with the appetizer order, but it was DANG good!  For my entree I ordered the Nut Brown Stew with sweet potatoes, kale, brown rice, nuts and a curry sauce.  Good, but a LOT of food.  I could've split it with someone and still had leftovers.  I also ordered a side of caramelized plantains that were awesome.  My boyfriend ordered the fish tacos and a side of the Gouda mac n cheese.  He's kind of a mac n cheese snob and although he said it was good, he said it tasted exactly like what it was: mac n cheese mixed with Gouda.  He also said the fish tacos were OK.  They're filled with a lot of cabbage, and even though they give you a salsa and a sour cream on the side, he said it was missing something.  He thought maybe a dressing of olive oil, lime and salt and pepper would've spruced things up a bit, just because they were kind of on the dry side.  Overall, I give it 3 stars and I'd go back for another round.  Their salads looked awesome!  The arugula with goat cheese and beets (I think) is what I'll be having next time.

I went here with a group of friends and we sat outside, which was awesome. It felt like I was in a friends backyard, very chill, very quaint and low-key. The menu was pretty great too. It had some very safe dishes along with some exciting new things to try and everything looked really good. I got the hibiscus cooler to start and it was delicious! Then I got the blackened catfish with some tapenade, rice and a salad and was totally satisfied. The boyfriend got the black bean maduro and  was loving it. The one thing though, he dearly loves spicy food and even he though it was a tad too hot.  Then, in addition to all of this, our server was super nice, and definitely came back to check on us a few times. Overall I'd definitely recommend it!

i'm not vegetarian or vegan and therefore, i would usually be hesitant of such restaurants, but i have to say that i really like Handlebar! i ride my bike past HB all the time and am always telling my husband that we should try it because the sign is so cute haha. finally, my vegan friend pursuaded us to meet her and some other friends there so we finally had our chance. we sat outside on the patio which was so nice. it's sheltered enough to be quiet and private, but well lit and large enough that you don't feel totally isolated. Also, i love that in addition to a bike rack out front there's also a large one in the patio area. I didn't order any food (only because i already ate before i knew we were going) but everyone at the table, including 2 carnivores, were really happy with their meals. i enjoyed the drinks and ambiance and the service was overall pretty great too. Our waiter was super cute and sweet pants....but i feel obligated to mention one slightly disgruntled hostess. She gave my friends a hard time about being seated until we were there, which i understand because it was saturday night, but there were 3 of them already there and there were plenty of available tables. why give them a hard time instead of seating them and letting them get started on drinks? plus, as mentioned, they were ordering food and we weren't. She also didn't crack a smile when clearing our plates, despite my friends super sweet attitude towards her. But i'm not letting that lower my 5 star rating because my friend convinced me that she was probably just having a bad day and the rest of the experience made up for her bad attitude.

Maybe I came on the wrong day but I didn't think this place was anywhere near the hype.  Sat at the bar for lunch and had the chance to soak up all the posters, stickers and other random paraphernalia around.  And that's where the coolness ended.   Number one, seemed like they may have been understaffed.  However, I wouldn't be surprised if this is how it's always run because none of the employees really seemed to be frusterated by the lack of service they were offering.  So anyway, I'm far from high maintenance but here's a sample...drank my bloody mary fairly quick and was never offered another, glass was never taken out of the way, didn't check to see if food was good, dirty entree plate never removed, had to ask for the bill, no pen when given back and no thanks for coming at the end.   Food and bevs were meh too.  Breakfast egg and sausage sammy was super bland.  Bloody mary, average. From the reviews, seems like everyone sums the Handlebar up to be a hipster joint.  Great, I love these kind of places.  But there is a big difference between hipster and just plain old poor customer service.  And their indifference doesn't leave me impressed.
The waiter who asks if you want a lemon or lime in your Diet Coke is a good one.

This place is veg*n heaven and I'm in love. Portions are ginormous and meat free (if you're not counting fishies as meat, that is).  I had the Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap, granted I love hot sauce more than most but it was good and spicy, but not put-tastebuds-out-of-commission-spicy.  The meat-loving boyfriend had the same thing and pronounced it "okay." He also got the gouda Mac and Cheese as a side which was delicious, not overly saucy-creamy, but the pasta was still mostly al-dente.  Yum. Anyways, the only thing that kind of freaked me out is that their outdoor seating is in the back and at night opens up into the alley, and one of Chicago's larger rodents decided to briefly see what all the fuss was about.  I completely understand that we're outside, chilling out in the alley, but still... eeek. Probably won't want to sit outside at night again. (but definitely will come back for some food INSIDE)

Dripping with hipsters this area is, and I like that.  Something pleasing about pushing a stroller thru a horde of my people (who politely respond by fanning their ciggy smoke away from the baby and making way for our entourage.)  I live in the Mission in SF, this is about as at-home as I could feel. Anyway, the Handlebar is truly great.  The black-bean/plantain cake thing was so good, I felt compelled to personally cite the chef for excellence in hipster cuisine.  She graciously accepted her honors, blushing slightly. The Half-Acre Daisycutter IPA was served at the utmost in freshness and at the ideal temperature, especially critical in this 80+F humid heat.  To say it was delicious would be disgustingly, disingenuously demure and criminally lacking in superlatives.  But I can't think of anything clever to say, so I'll leave it at that. The staff was terrifically accommodating to our 6-week-old and her parents, and exhibited a guileless courtesy that was as refreshing as the cold, local beers. My only minor, minor quibble is that the Handlebar is supposed to be a bike place, and there weren't any bikes on display (I expected a perfectly restored '72 Paramount track rig... this is Chicago right, home of Schwinn) and there weren't any portraits of Eddy Merckx being adored by fabulous 70s podium girls, or videos of him winning Paris-Roubaix. Still, it had sufficient cycling accoutrement that I knew I was in the right place, so disregard my previous comments.

This is perhaps my favorite bar in the city. I think the menu has plenty of options and never gets boring. The back patio is the ultimate spot for the summer. It's tucked away and much more private than nearby Big Star. The service and tunes put Handlebar over the top.
I love this place. Their smoked gouda mac and cheese is awesome, along with basically everything else on the menu... even something as simple as collard greens they make spectacular.

My friend who lives in the area took me here when I was visiting a few months ago and I am def a fan!       Basically we spend a couple hours here, drank a lot of beer and ate a lot of food and it was fantastic. We started with the samosas, then we each ordered an entree; the buffalo "chicken" wrap with the smoked Gouda mac and cheese, and then the everything green salad which we both shared.  Everything was really good, esp the mac and cheese.     I still haven't found a place in New York that can do a good faux buffalo chicken wrap. On my next trip back to Chicago I will def be stopping here again.

It kind of bothers me when people from out of town, or sometimes even people from Chicago, know only about Chicago Diner or Pick Me Up and have never even heard of this place. Handlebar is definitely my favorite vegan friendly restaurant in the city for many reasons. The food portions are hearty, the price isn't ridiculous, the service is friendly, and their breakfast/brunch menu is actually incredible, etc. A+, great job, yeah!

My husband and I both enjoyed our breakfast at Handlebar.  We went on a Sunday morning and had to wait 10 mins for a table.  It is a very small place and was extremely packed.  The service was good, especially considering how busy it was.  The thing that sucked was the fact that it was extremely noisy.  I mean, we literally had to yell and repeat ourselves several times when having a conversation.  If not for the noise, I would have given Handlebar five stars.  Maybe it is quieter during off hours?

after many years of eating at handlebar, i think i'm getting bored.  yes, the mac and cheese is one of my favorites in the city, but some nights its watery others its thick and creamy. the fish tacos usually are a bit bland, something changed with the green meanie sandwich 2 years ago and it hasn't been good since.  Its sad that the menu hasn't changed much over 4 years, the specials aren't as good as they used to be (where is the seitan gyros!!!?!)  if you are new to handlebar, you will most likely leave happy, if its your 30th visit, you're probably bored, and know that the kitchen isn't the most consistent.
Meh. Sietan biscuits and gravy had mad veggie oil all up in the mix. Tasty but too oily. Good service, good crowd.

The food here is excellent.  I had the blackened catfish fillet with collard greens and aged cheddar grits. The catfish was blackened and not burnt and seasoned perfectly. The collard greens were not like my mama makes them but what do you expect from a midwestern veggie kitchen. They were good all the same. The aged cheddar grits were closer to mamas (I don't even call my mother mama--just sounds good now). I had a hard time not scraping the platter. The staff was friendly. Though there seemed to be this hybrid of hipster/bike messenger boys as front house staff that tried very hard not to break a smile. Though my waiter and another staff member did but quickly corrected that once they realized what they were doing. And when I say hybrid, I don't mean half the staff were bike messengers and the other half hipsters. Imagine them having a hipster mother and a bike messenger father.   Anyway, good food all the way around.

I loved the Handlebar!  We sat on the patio, which was awesome, except as it got later at night, we started getting a lot of bug bites, but hey that happens.  The service was okay. I think there was a mix up and we somehow got forgotten for a little while. But again, it happens.  I loved the food. I had a grilled cheese sandwich with tomato and a salad. Hands down the BEST grilled cheese I have ever had. And I know a thing or two about grilled cheese. My friend and I shared a bananas foster kind of dessert, which is big and delicious and I don't even like bananas! I couldn't have finished it on my own, though, because it is so rich. My parents had a berry crisp kind of thing which they also loved.  Loved my margarita too! Bottom line: Great food. Go. Get the grilled cheese. You won't be sorry.
The place is too loud. We ordered cavatapi pasta and black bean ma....., both were below our expectation. One dish was too spicy and the other one was too blend.  They have very friendly service.

For those of you who don't know, for the past 3 weeks or so I've been on a raw foods diet to detox my body and then I've been adding things back in to see what if anything I'm allergic to.  Well, it turns out that I'm officially allergic to wheat and gluten. When I added these two things back into my diet I had the worst migraine and my stomach just hated me. I called my doctor to see what was going on and he confirmed that I might be allergic to these two ingredients. He told me to keep them out of my diet for a while to see how I felt. So, instead of wheat and gluten I've been eating rice and whole grains and have certainly felt tons better.  However, finding vegan-friendly, gluten free places to dine with my friends has been a challenge. So, I'm glad I found Handlebar. This is the kind of place that if you don't tell someone that it's all veggie, they might not know the difference and the best part is that they had a gluten free beer choice, whoot!  The food here was very spicy and well prepared. I had their Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap vegan style. Which boasted chicken style setian tossed in wing sauce with romaine, red onion, tomatoes, and vegan ranch dressing. So spicy and good.
