The side I ordered with that was the sesame broccoli which also was very good. I will have to attempt to duplicate the broccoli at home sometime soon. Then I tried their Lakefront New Grist gluten-free beer and it was super delicious. I'm just happy to have found a new beer of choice besides the standard lagers I've been imbibing on lately.  I'm looking forward to coming back and checking out more of their menu soon and soaking up the sun on their patio.

I walked into the Handlebar without any expectations at all.  It looked like a cool place, which was the only thing I could say about.   All I really wanted was a hamburger, yet I couldn't seem to find it on the menu.  So, I think to myself "What kind of place doesn't sell hamburgers?!?!?"  Oh well, what goes better with a beer then?  Oh, a breakfast sandwich.  I get the egg and sausage sandwich, which was really good.  Half way through finishing it, one of the people I was with asked me "It's not bad for vegetarian, huh?"  WTH?!?!  Not meat?  I never would have guessed.  Vegetarian or not, it was pretty darn good and rather big.  I'm not a fan of potato wedges, but they were ok considering I don't like them.   The people running the place were really nice and the crowd was pleasant.  If you are a vegetarian and have meat eating friends, take them there and don't tell them it's a vegetarian place.  See how long it takes them to notice.

As a vegan this is without a doubt my favorite restaurant in Chicago. The food is fantastic. Even my meat loving friends love this joint.  The staff is great, the drinks are good. Awesome backyard. Go here on a Sunday and try the 5 dollar Bloody Marys.

"Handlebar was awesome," says my wife.  Their nachos with "chorizo" were virtually indistinguishable from the real thing. They have a buffalo "chicken" wrap that easily competes with the best real-chicken wraps that I've tasted. They also have an array of tasty sides.  Their smoked gouda mac & cheese was perhaps the best I've tasted, and their fried plantains were like little pillows of goodness.  Their cheesy grits were good, but I felt that the cheese got a little overpowering by the end of the dish. They have a good variety of craft beers and microbrews, too. This is a vegetarian restaurant that even a meat-lover can like.

Sad to give this place a review that's not so great, but in my defense I loved it the first time. The samosas-amazing. Get those. The mac n cheese-fabulous, and I personally don't eat stuff that is super cheesy. I had the tofu sandwich-which was really really good, but I didn't really like how they just served it as the brick I can buy in the grocery store. Granted, that was probably the best way for it to stay together but IDK...I figured that wasn't the ONLY way you could keep your tofu on a sandwich. Unfortunatly,. my boyfriend got food poisoning here. He had the tuna sandwich. I read another review farther down here and someone said their tuna sandwich wasn't really fresh...maybe there's a common theme. I wish I could give this place at least 3 stars because I liked my own food, but my poor boyfriend throwing up all night-seriously-like 10 times-really killed it for me.

this place was one of my first dates with BenO and i have had a very soft spot for this place and him since that day. it was first for an early dinner on the outside patio and we've returned again for brunch to sit in the window nook. this place is vegan friendly. not that i am vegan or ever was. but if you are you would be content. as a former vegetarian i would have appreciated this place a few years ago when i was nazi strict with my diet. i had the grilled muenster cheese sammich w/ tomato. i have had panging cravings for this ever since. i have even tried to emulate it at home. on another day i tried the smoked gouda mac and cheese and i am a huge fan. i had the handle bar omelette with gouda walnut and pears... of everything i had this was one that i thought was meh; it seemed like a great idea, but overly ambitious considering that the execution was not as great as the blurb on the menu. opt for the huevos diablos as BenO did and you'll be smitten. if the weather is nice, bike on over to fit in with this biker crowd, debate how much $$$ you save or your carbon footprint with a fellow at the bar, or go to the patio.

I accidentally wore head-to-toe Gap to my dinner at Handlebar.  The staff kindly waited until I left the premises to unload their derision, I assume.  Our server never let on, at any rate.     While I was there, however, I had one of the best tofu sandwiches ever.  I had recently gone 'fu at Revolution Brewery too, and was so thrilled, so I kinda had a jones for it again.  This one was just as good; color me thrilled one more time.  It was messy, sure, but tasted great and had other things I love - spinach, multigrain bread - and even coaxed me into accepting avocado - something I don't love.   My companion had the Green Meanie, her fave from past visits.  I am tempted by that one too, but then again their entire menu is kind of up my alley, so that's not surprising.    We split a dessert featuring my one concession to the "no fruit with chocolate" rule: raspberry.  It was a chocolate/raspberry/oat tart, (yes, oats) and it was considerably dense the way a tart should be.  The woman dining solo at the table next to us chimed in her approval of our choice when we ordered.  Next time I'll be that solo-dining, tart-loving lady because I don't want to share it again.   Super.
Like I need to review this place.  It's super hip, and has delicious vegan food.  Try the sesame broccoli.

I came here with a vegan friend and the food was great! I am usually a meat and potatoes kind of gal but I didn't miss the meat at all. We had an amazing PBJ dessert that I would order again and again! Good option for those of us with vegetarian or vegan friends =)

A really wide variety of vegetarian/vegan dishes as well as stuff for the meat eaters.  The green meanie sandwich blows my mind every time and the gouda mac and cheese ahhhh so so good.  They have Sprecher sodas which is a bonus.

Handlebar rules. Their standard menu items range from just satisfying (chili, ground nut stew) to insanely delicious (BBQ Seitan sandwich, Smoked Gouda Mac and Cheese). The Green Meanie and the Buffalo wrap fall somewhere in between. And let me tell you about this special they had one time, a vegetable empanada that was one of the best damn empanadas I'd ever had. And oh man, I just remembered how badass their spicy  pickles are.

I've now been to Handlebar quite a few times now, so I felt that I should update my review. Since my first experience there the staff has been great!   Again, If you haven't been there they have a great vegetarian/vegan menu, good beer selection, and also serve my favorite - Metropolis coffee.  Breakfast and lunch is served from 10am-2pm daily (3pm on the weekend).  I recently went for a simple brunch.  Their lovely patio is now open for the summer - a nice addition to their smaller indoor space, accommodating more guests.  Appetizers include Fried Pickles and Samosas  among many other delicious starters.  Try their monstrous BBQ Seitan sandwich with Freshly-Cut French Fries, Chili, Garlic Mashed Potatoes, or one of their premium sides such as the Smoked Gouda Mac n' Cheese.  For lighter fare, the Green Meanie or one of their salads prove to be tempting options each visit.  Some of their entrees are the Black Beans Maduro and Ground Nut Stew  alongside a few fish dishes and Latin-American inspired meals. Large portions, great quality, reasonable prices!  I typically go to Handlebar when I'm in the mood for delicious vegetarian comfort food.  There is still so much I want to try and I definitely will do so!

Outdoor seating + good for groups + delicious food + you can take vegetarians and vegans + they have a bar + friendly staff + the Gouda Mac and Cheese. If this place does not deserve 5 stars, I don't know what does.

Cute place with a nice patio.  The buffalo "chicken" wrap was amazing and honestly better than it would've been if it were real chicken (this is coming from a meat eater).  The balsalmic vinaigrette was yummy and tasted homemade, and our waiter was cute and very personable. Plus beermosa's and shandy with oberon? YES!

Handlebar has a great veggie/vegan menu where taste is not an afterthought.  The Handlebar salad, gouda mac n cheese and BBQ seitan sandwich are fantastic. And there a ton of other options that looked great. Prices are good, probably because this is closer to a bar than a resto. Friday's special is $5 margies. Not super strong but that was fine with me as I wasn't looking to get wasted. The back patio is great for enjoying a warm summer night (but no dogs, boo!). Plus, they are super bike friendly and incorporate bike-related art into a lot of the decor.  I can't believe this place wasn't busier. I am definitely coming back and considering moving to this neighborhood so I can eat here more frequently.

I finally came here last night and I had the BBQ "chicken" wrap with a side of gouda mac and cheese. I definitely think that their mac and cheese is better than Kuma's, and the wrap was DELICIOUS and the portions were huge! I came to Handlebar super hungry but just couldn't devour everything on my plate! I kept eating and eating and it seemed like there was more and more food. Most of the food is around $8-13, and I'd say it's comparable to Chicago Diner but maybe more badass? The beer selection is really rad, too. A glass of Bells' Oberon was $5. My friends and I got here kind of late-ish (around 9pm) but there was no problem with seating. The service was pretty decent, and we all had a good time here. Definitely will be back at some point!

Praise Seitan! When I have described the sandwich I got here, it usually involves obscene hand gestures and a long discourse filled with expletives. I guess I can simplify and clean it up for Yelp's sake. My Chicagoland host knew I needed some veggie friendly goodness, and Handlebar fit the bill. We got to enjoy the humidity dined outside, and got to smoke while we slurped on IPA and waited for our food. I was having a terrific time, the waitress was super cute and friendly, conversation was flowing easily when I was suddenly blindsided. The girl brought out a ginormous platter of food, and it turns out: the platter was for me! 4 huge slices of toasted sourdough, suffocated by a whole cow's worth of seitan, a neatly slice side of avocado for some color and a heaping mound of salty fries. Oh wait, back up. A whole cow's worth of seitan? Yes, you read that right. Piles upon piles upon piles of sweetly barbeque'd seitan. For really really cheap! Holy crap, I just started giggling at the waitress like a moron, and didn't stop until I had stuffed a quarter of that stuff down my seitan hole. That's all there was room for, even after traveling 10 hours. The rest went home and fed me for breakfast and lunch the rest of my time in Chicago. Everything was sooooooo good, and I think a Handlebar Too would do well in Portland with the bikes and the vegan foodstuffs and the IPAs and whatnot.

Overall the food was just so-so.  Nothing you cannot make at home by just taking the ingredients and putting them on the plate.  On top of that you had to flag them down to get your bottomless iced tea filled.

This is one of my favorite places to eat in Chicago. The brunch and the dinner/bar menu are equally awesome and the service is always great. I almost always get the Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap or salad, but everything else I've had on the menu (the breakfast tostadas or "diablos," and the vegan chilli quesadillas in particular) are great. The beer selection is good and the bloody mary's are delicious and filled with a variety of picked things (including tiny peppers and amazing house-made pickles). Most importantly, I love that I can take anyone here (vegan, meat eater, mom, boss, so) and they leave happy. I recently stopped by with my ultra picky and carnivorous 18 year old brother before the Hawks game and he said it was one of the best meals he has had - period. Isn't that cool?

Horrible service. The food is decent although, I do think it's about time they changed their menu. I recommend the Black Bean Maduro. Why was my server so rude? Maybe she was having a bad day? Either way, that put a drag on me and my date's dinner: ( The place is ran by a bunch of dirty hipsters. One of the servers even had a bloody scabby elbow walking around bringing tables their food. Thank god he wasn't my server! D-

Eat the Black Beans Madura. Don't ask questions, just do it. Trust me. One of the tastiest, filling veggie-friendly dishes I've ever had. It's like opening a set of nesting dolls, each layer removed reveals another equally amazing layer... and then another. Shrimp & cheese grits - can't get enough!! So flavorful & the shrimp are huge. Gouda Mac'n'Cheese, fried plantains, fried pickles... honestly, I could go on forever.  Although I'm not personally a vegetarian or vegan, my quest to jam my fat a** into a wedding dress over the last several months (which successfully ended last weekend - *sigh*) has turned me to a meat-light menu. This place ruins that... I always wondered how vegetarians could be overweight... and now I know!! Everything is SO delicious, but still far from healthy from a preparation & ingredient perspective on the low-fat & low-carb front. I'll be back again & again, but more to enjoy the food rather than to watch my health & weight.

Handlebar is a great place but I find it a little small and the music is really weird.  Other than that, I really enjoyed the food and it is completely vegetarian.  French fries were A-OK and I will definitely return for another round at Handlebar.

I came here for a lunch meeting at my colleague's suggestion. We actually got a lot done! I didn't realize there was a patio because it's all the way through the back, but it's great out there if the weather is nice . I really enjoyed the beet and spinach salad with goat cheese and candied pepitas. One guy had rave reviews for the gouda mac and cheese, which I couldn't help eyeing jealously. I didn't think it would be appropriate to ask for a bite. Service was a bit slow, but the prices were reasonable, and I wanted to try pretty much everything on their menu.
the chorizo & black bean nachos were fantastic, probably the best nachos i've had! the bbq seitan sandwich good, better the next day, cold.

Great veggie food! Great music! Never too long a wait. Great outside area. Great beer selection. My 6 year-old loves the fries. it's a bit pricey, but a great selection of veg-friendly and vegan food. Some people on here talk about the wait staff attitude and haircuts.. but what do you want? It's Wicker Park.  We eat here a lot.

Visited this place accidently after doing bar hopping in downtown on a friday evening with my office collegues. We were looking for a place where we could fetch some vegetarian food since my manager at workplace is a veggie. It's actually not a place to visit with your corporate honchos. But late at night we had no other option.The first thing which one notices is the loud music of the place, for a minute we thought of leaving the place. But we finally settled down on the bar and ordered food. Surprisingly the food was dead awesome. We ordered fish tacos,blackened catfish filet, green salad and shiitake & broccloiette. Since it was a friday evening the place was buzzing with people. It took too much time for our food to be served to us. That sometimes is frustating when you are dying with hunger. But at the end the food was great so I am not complaining. The staff right from bartenders and people serving food were very friendly. So overall nice place to hang around for food.

OK so I just had to find out why the fuss and boy am I pleased. I asked for seating at the bar. I ordered the Vegan Diablos with avocado (to go) and a Bloody Mary. The meal was packed it an earth friendly box with the black beans in a separate container. When I finally ate it, you could have asked me anything and the answer would have been "YES"!!! I read the other reviews and thought this would be some little Veggie Bite type place. I assure you it was NOT!!! The dish was packed with flavor that kicked butt as soon as you bit into it. And the Bloody Mary was spicy, tangy and just plain Delicious bartender did not skimp on the alcohol either! My order was about $18 and it was worth every penny. I will definitely be back on a warmer day to chill out on the patio with another Bloody Mary and some of the dishes recommended by fellow Yelpers~
Hands down, my favorite restaurant in Chicago. Great beers on tap and in bottles, great food. One of the best patios. Great staff. What else can I say? Oh, it's a bike bar!
handlebar hasnt disappointed me yet.  rotating craft brews and hearty veggie fare in a relaxed atmosphere.  good stuff.

How is it that I haven't reviewed Handlebar yet? I've been eating here since I moved to Chicago 2 years ago, and have yet to find a complaint. As vegetarian food goes, theirs has been consistently delicious, offering both healthy vegan/vegetarian options, and more indulgent ones. The vegan 'buffalo chicken' wrap with any of the sides makes a pretty delicious and huge vegetarian meal. The margaritas (on special for $5 on Saturday!) don't taste strong but do pack a punch. I'm sorry to say that I have yet to brunch here - will update when I do!

And I'm back again... I loved the Handlebar before I moved to Chicago and years later, I'm still loving it. 100 Handlebar omelets later, I still can't get enough. Who could go wrong with pears, gruyere, and walnuts on an omelet? Combine that with such perfectly seasoned breakfast potatoes and a never ending flow of iced tea and I'll never stop coming back for more. Once upon a time, the Handlebar omelet had been pulled from the menu. I'll hope to never see that mistake repeated.  If it's time for dinner, then my combo of a Handlebar salad, fantastic tostadas, and masterfully crafted french fries also never fails to keep me satisfied.
Never been disappointed with all the yummy vegan food here... My fave is the biscuits & gravy.  Service isn't the best but tolerable cause the food is so darned good!!!!

Mmmmm Handlebar, I think I love you. Came here on a Thursday evening around 9 and were seated straight away. The art on the walls was rad, the lighting was cozy and the place was packed. Even though there were people right next to us, the atmosphere was such that our conversation was still private - in fact, it might have been slightly too loud, but no real complaints here, honestly. I ordered the vegan buffalo chicken wrap which was spicy in the best kind of way, and while it was a little green heavy, it wasn't overly so. I ordered the collard greens as my side and they were good, but a little too crunchy and not cooked enough (in my mind). My dining companion had the black beans maduro which he said was good, but I think he thought his portion was a bit small and overly spicy. It's worth noting that I wanted to try like everything on this menu, particularly the nachos and fried pickles, but I was still beyond pleased with my meal. They also had a great selection of beer and I ended up having a couple different ones.  All in all, I left satisfied and full. Next time, I want to try their breakfast!

Went on a Saturday night with 3 friends and the place was packed. They told us it would be a 30 min wait . We asked about the garden and they said "sure, it's open." It was a chilly night but we decided to brave it as we were HUNGRY :-) The servers came out sporadically and were quick and rushing us in our orders. The waiters in short sleeves seemed to be annoyed that we were out there, the same guys who told us the garden was open. If it's too cold for YOU then don't offer the garden as an option.  Other than that the experience was GREAT! The food was AMAZING! Nachos were a big hit for the table and the smoked gouda mac & cheese was also a good thing for the table as just a few bites was enough for me.  The salads and main courses were incredible. Don't forget to try the local drafts. I discovered 3 Floyds amber was a great discovery.

I noticed Handlebar is under a category of "vegan." They serve fish so don't go here expecting a completely vegan menu...they might also use eggs, dairy, etc.  I am always excited when I see brown rice on a menu - I dont see it enough! And I get really excited when I am served collard greens that still retain an appealing green color. I found both here! And it was goooooood. The brown rice was a side with my catfish tacos along with beans and greens. They need to advertise this is as a vegetarian restaurant on the outside so more people can experience the goodness.  The atmopshere is pretty cool. Local art for sale on the wall, interesting pictures, crowded space, cool wait staff and loud music,.

If you can stand the hipster shenanigans and cyclist snobbery, the food is so worth it!  My friends and I waited 40 minutes for dinner on a Friday, and there's not much space to wait inside (when the backyard garden is closed), but once seated, we got great service and even better food. I had, hands-down, the best Shrimp & Grits I've ever had in my life...and being a native New Orleanian, my standards are obscenely high.  I was a bit piqued by the obnoxiously high price, but figured I'd take a chance and hope for the best.  I was not disappointed!  The Gulf shrimp really were substantive enough to actually be from the Gulf - the aged cheddar grits were phenomenally rich, assertive, and creamy - the fried plantain garnish added a nice touch-and the wilted spinach was a nice way to fit my veggies in :)  My only advice to the chefs would be to cut the greasiness a bit--the spicy paprika sauce was awfully heavy on the oil...though it was yummy. For dessert...we tried the Rhubarb-Lemon Fried Pie (simple, slightly tart & OK) and the ridiculously amazing PB&J Fried Pie.  I must preface this with the admission that I previously eschewed it because I'm not big on the WT-revival desserts, but after hearing all the raves, finally gave in. O M G.  The peanut butter was high-quality PB...not overly sweet, and there wasn't a gross jelly inundation either.  It was literally perfect. In addition, my out-of-town guests loved what they ordered and were hella impressed with the fancy draught selections.

What a cute little joint! What Handlebar lacked in prompt service is DEFINITELY made up for in the high quality food and drink. The Wednesday Alagash pint special worked out perfectly, an old favorite of mine. However, some drinks on the menu did make me curious and I hope to try them on my next visit (Beermosa, The Bloody Hammer, etc.) The Smoked Gouda Mac N' Cheese is out of this world. I could eat the side as my entree and would probably still struggle to finish it. So rich, so creamy. I'm a huge fan of smoked gouda (I'll eat it right off the block), so I'm probably a bit biased, but seriously people. Try this dish. For my entree I had the lemon asparagus risotto with grilled tofu. I'm a meat- and fish-eater through and through, but I must admit this vegetarian treat was quite refreshing. The radish salad on top made for an especially interesting taste combo that stuck with me through the evening (not in a bad-breath sort of way, but in a wow-that-was-yummy sort of way).

I rarely go to Wicker Park. Not to sound like a jerk, but the hipster culture is very obnoxious to me, but damn, do they know how to make some outstanding vegan food. After doing a little research I decided to come by yesterday for dinner with a friend after work. I tweeted about Handlebar and immediately received a great response from friends and followers. Similar to Chicago Diner, Handlebar is very hipster, tiny, and compact. I decided to sit outside on the patio since it was relatively cool out. I started with the much raved about fried pickles for an appetizer and they were crazy! Tangy and nicely seasoned, they went well with the vegan ranch dressing. A great way to start the meal. After many recommendations, I went with the Buffalo 'Chicken' Wrap for dinner. Described as chicken-style seitan (my favorite meat alternative), tossed in wing sauce, romaine, and vegan ranch dressing. The first bite was a revelation. Wonderful texture, flavor, and very filling. Absolutely no complaints. I went with the organic brown rice for my side, also delicious. Handlebar is easily one of the best vegan restaurants I've ever visited. The service was accommodating and the food was above and beyond. I'm looking forward to come in soon (maybe even next week!) just to try out what else is on the menu. Like Chicago Diner, vegan cuisine does not get much better than this. Carnivores must experience, too!
Cute boys,fried pickles and good beer. What more could a person ask for in an establishment? I bring my friends here whenever they let me pick a restaurant.

I love this place. In the 6 years that I have been going here I have never been let down. I always get great service, good music, and most importantly the best food! There are many options to choose from if you have dietary restrictions such vegetarian or vegan. No matter what you get you can bet that it will be very well prepared food. The portions are great as well. My favorite things to get are the meal of three sides and any of the desserts that are offered. Great food!

BBQ seitan so numyummy, the crowd is friendly and atmosphere great. The con would be the wait,grawr. But that just goes to show how awesome this place really is. They even went the extra mile to find my blue hat I misplaced,thanks matt@handlebar.
all i can say is "smoked gouda mac n cheese"!!!!

Really laid back and lovely service. GREAT prices. Esp because HUGE entrees come with a big side.  Perfect place for me cause I'm all for seafood but not so much for any other animal .. so it's perfect for 'pescetarians'. Couple of fish related options and vegan/vegetarian options galore.  SUPER impressed with their VEGAN buffalo chicken wrap. I don't eat chicken, but their "chicken" in their vegan chicken wrap was SO GOOD. Tasted like the real thing. It was spicy , which was a plus for me. Maybe a litto salty but still really good. I ordered the garlic mashed potatoes for my side and they were SO GOOD. The pickle that came with my wrap tasted funky cause the spices they rubbed it with. Couldn't breathe at the end of my meal. Felt like I ate for 3.  My friend ordered the portobello sammich which she loved. We both ordered vegan desserts. I didn't really enjoy my dessert (raspberry torte), thus my one star off... but my friend enjoyed her spiced apple turnovers(?)   Definitely must return! I want to try their brunch.. and their fried pickle.. and basically everything else :)
Great for breakfast but get there when they open or you will wait. I had a salad there one time that was fantastic and I am not a salad guy. I imagine their lunch/dinner is good too.

My favorite margaritas in Chicago! Simple and good. We all know the smoked Gouda Mac & cheese as well as the hand cut fries are so great here. They let me add beets to any salad which makes me happy. I love this place and the killer patio. Brunch menus looks awesome. The menu is the perfect balance between healthy and decadent

I'll just say it: get the Green Meany or grilled cheese if your comin for dinner and opt for the better sides. Or, get the huevos diablos if your comin' for brunch. I recommend the latter. The patio is nice in the warmer months.

Was not especially looking forward to dinner when my cousin suggested "vegan and healthy", but was pleasantly surprised with Handlebar - a "biker" (as in cyclists) themed restaurant favored by vegans and pesco-vegetarians. Menu was creative without being off-the-wall-trying-too-hard as vegan meals often are.  Interesting selection of beers.  Waitress was helpful and friendly.  All in all, a very satisfying meal, at a very affordable price. Recommend the Smoked Gouda Mac 'n Cheese as a side. Can't wait to try out the brunch.  Fellow patrons were raving about it.

You will come away happy and full. Anyone worried about the lack of meat, put it out of your mind. I had the green meanie with collard greens, my wife had the portobello with fries, and both were good way too much food.  They do have a few seafood options, and I'm sure they're delicious. A decent beer selection too.

Delicious. This has become our yardstick of good, inexpensive food that appeals to vegetarians and meat eaters alike. We went on a Sunday mid-afternoon, and there was still plenty of business. Tried Goose Island's Green Line and the BF had a hot toddy as he was feeling a little under the weather. We split a green meanie and the buffalo 'chicken' wrap with sides of chili and smoked gouda mac and cheese. I wanted to start with chili cheese fries but as BF predicted, we were way too full from our mains alone. The green meanie and the chili were both great- the sandwich ingredients were all very fresh (how do you find a perfectly ripe avocado in the middle of winter?) and the chili was hearty without being overly spicy (although I would have loved a dollop of sour cream and some shredded cheddar) The real standouts, though, were the mac and cheese and the wrap. Oh god the wrap. It made my meat-loving BF want to go veg. The man is OBSESSED with all things BBQ/buffalo and this more than satisfied his cravings. As everybody else has raved, any meal at Handlebar would be incomplete without a serving of the smoked gouda mac and cheese. It just melts in your mouth and is not at all clumpy as some home made mac and cheese can be. My only complaint was that the music is a little too loud to really engage in conversation. Now that I've made myself sound like an elderly person, let me just reiterate: go to Handlebar! I'm still salivating.

I can't take a vegetarian or vegan seriously when they say "I like good food" because in my close-minded head I think meat is the way to go! But I tried out Handlebar with a vegan friend and I was so pleasantly surprised. I had tried seitan meat before, but they made it taste really good at Handlebar. Try their smoked gouda mac n cheese or the chicken and biscuits. Our whole table enjoyed what they ordered and I thought service was extremely friendly and excellent. They compensate for the lack of meat by incorporating great flavor into all their dishes and I would definitely go back to Handlebar, but I just have to be in a non-meat mood :P
i eat here all the time.  it's delicious.  vegan french toast - amazing.  "chicken" wrap - amazing.  vegan diablos - yum.  all the sides are great, as well as the drink specials.

I was excited to find a restaurant/bar that is vegetarian, however, I was not impressed.  The place had a slight smell of body odor, the food was just ok....nothing special, and I could have easily cooked what we ordered at home.  The mac and cheese tasted like it was from a box.

Full disclosure up front; I'm an unabashed meat eater. Pork, Lamb, Venison, Beef, Goat, you name it, if it's on the menu I'm usually ordering whatever comes with the most of it.  Grilled, BBQed, fried, baked, poached, braised, the preparation matters not, I still want it on my plate.  I do occasionally stray from this norm and choose to drown myself in veggies and I must say Handlebar was quite a glorious reward for doing so. I came by here once for some early Friday drinks and the place seemed mostly average. Fun bike and hipster kitsch abounds and it's mostly a chill place with a few decent beers on tap (Great Lakes Conway Irish Ale, Founder's Porter, Bell's Best Brown).  I saw and smelled some of the food of a nearby patron and figured that even though it was straight vegetarian fare, I would have to give it a try. I came back for a veggie lunch on a mid-week ditch day and it was delicious.  I started with the mini black bean tostada appetizer which is awesome.  It tasted like something I would happilly gorge myself on after a night of drinking.  The real coup came when I received my order; the Southern Plate.  This is an delicious heap of cheesy grits, greens, and black eyed peas all smothered in eggs.  It was amazing and hearty and more than hit the spot for an excellent lunch.  I'm sad to admit I couldn't finish the whole thing and sadly had to admit defeat. I don't know how soon or often I'll be back but I can't deny that I was very surprised and pleased with my visit here.  Recommended if you need a depth charge of veggies.
I ate the delicious egg & sausage sandwich. The potatoes are yummy too!

I am giving handlebar 3 stars. The food is good, the service is polite & nice, the decor is nice, but there is one big problem. The music is entirely too loud for a restaurant. I will never understand why a restaurant would need to have fucking obnoxiously loud music continuously blaring. Are they trying to discourage conversation? It's not even appropriate music for the restaurant. Since when do cyclists & vegans get down to bass-heavy dance music?  It's not even a weekend. It is Wednesday fucking night, I'm sitting 2 feet away from my date, and we are entering double digits as we count the number of times the other needs to say "what?" in order to clearly understand what the other is saying.  Yeah, we tried to ask the waitress if the music could be turned down. Didn't fucking happen. Next time, we'll go to earwax.

Veggie and Vegan Friendly place with excellent service and food. My fav's are the Green Meanie, and the Grilled Tofu Sandwich. Somosas are great as well as the mac and cheese. Tends to get crowded, but your in good company!

Mmmm got to be back in Chicago for a few days and got to brunch here once again.  The vegan diablos is (as always) spicy and amazing. My friend's french toast was very yummy, especially with the cranberry jam. And the coffee and service were both top notch!

Would give the place five stars if not for the small size and too loud music playing.   Fried pickles are AWESOME.  I highly, highly recommend them.   Smoke Gouda Mac 'n Cheese is heavenly.  Love the fries.  The "chicken" salad, made with saitan, is excellent.  Great breakfast foods, excellent beer selection, interesting atmosphere. 6 stars for the chef!  Her selection of vegetarian meals is outstanding.  4 stars for the overall establishment.

What a great restaurant! From the bar stools that have bicycle rims to the black birds that seem to defy gravity and adorn the walls and ceiling. This place is just fucking chill and awesome. Enough said. Vegetarians will rejoice because this place is probably one of the best places to get a good brunch (organic eggs! - or tofu scramble...if you're vegan (hey tofu should be tasty to everyone!)). The seiten here is also top notch I gotta say. I got the BBQ Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap which was very very tasty. Seiten done wrong can be chewy or gummy but this just had the right texture. I also got the sausage seiten which was just "meh."  Our group also had the fried pickles which were absolutely A-MAZING. I've had fried pickles in Minneapolis and these were comparable. Pretty much deep fried battered pickle spears with just the perfect blend of saltiness and sweetness! Service was commendable and the crowd skewed young and hipsterish which jives with my vibes. The whole time we were there, they had LCD Soundsystem on the speakers which is OK I guess, but would have preferred a mix. As far as prices go, expect to spend $9-$13 per person with drinks. Handlebar also has several beers on draft so try them out! If you are going to try out Handlebar, try going for brunch - that's my suggestion. There were just too many items that looked good I just have to get back here!

On a weekend its pretty loud... not a bad thing if you like to pump it on a Saturday night. I prefer the weekday scene myself. It's a great place for a chill environment, down to earth staff,  and a delicious meal. The tilapia is deelicious!

What can I say?  It's Handlebar.   Well the one thing I can say, is "who comes to such a tiny place with a party the size of the entire establishment?"  It made me very fussy.   Once seated, I was much happier.  Thursday's drink special is "bartender's choice." This has the potential to be freaking amazing, or your worst nightmare.  Luckily for me a Scrimshaw was what the doctor ordered... and what I ordered.   Fried pickles are good and the batter has a little kick to it, though I am a mega pickle brat from Hell and prefer pickle slices to spears when it comes to my fried pickles.  I still liked them.  It's pickles.  Fried pickles.  I got the "fried chicken" salad, which is always a good call in my book.  It's a salad whose healthiness is ruined by fried goodness.  It doesn't matter if it's real meat or not.  Boyfriend got the tofu fajitas which sounded good, but he said he'd go back to the sandwiches on the next try.   It's good for the veggie boyfriend, so I'm sure we'll be back at some point.  Besides, FRIED PICKLES!

This a great Wicker Park spot if you don't feel like eating at Earwax or Sultan's. I've enjoyed every dish I've ever tried (my favorite probably being the BBQ seitan sandwich) and all of the sides are pretty amazing too. In addition, they have a well stocked bar of great micro-brews and lovely outdoor seating when it's warm enough. The service is generally decent/good but I've also been a bit bummed out a couple times with the wait staff after receiving attitude. Their demographic is generally young, hip, and yep, people that like bikes. FYI, it fills up quickly and can be a wait. Also it's been known to get noisy and cramped.

came here with a large group of people with a wide range of tastes and Handlebar did not disappoint! We had meat eaters, no meet eaters, and a vegan and EVERYONE found something really tasty on the menu. Recommended: GOUDA MAC AND CHEESE IS SO GOOD! The millions of hipsters that go here make it a little bit intimidating at first, but the food is worth braving through the sea of nike dunks and gross hair cuts.

I'm writing this not to add to the existing 400+ reviews but to balance out my always negatve reviews! (I think I hoard my favorite places in the hopes no one will find out and just try to warn others about my missteps.)  I met a friend for dinner a few weeks ago and can still vividly remember the charred tuna/spinach/beet/goat cheese salad and samosa appetizer.  So delicious and the wait staff were really upbeat and attentive.  The music is a bit overbearing but, in truth, I was fully distracted by my tasty meal.   I did not stop to try my husband's catfish tacos and only had a nibble of my friend's stew because I wanted to focus on my dish.  A bit expensive but worth it considering all the mediocre joints where we've dropped cash.  I fully recommend!!!

Brunch here with my gf on Saturday.....she's on a vegan cleanse....I said I'd play along..... Food Black Bean Tostadas: These are fantastic and I've had them every time I've eaten here....they never disappoint!! Get them....you won't be sorry and neither will your non-vegan friends.... Vegan Breakfast Burrito: Honestly, not that great....with all of the things that could be included in a burrito....even a vegan one....this is basically just lettuce and potatoes....yes there are a few crumbles of seitan chorizo and some lumps of avocado....but they could put just a tiny more thought into it and make the leap from mediocre to yummy Vegetable Hash: This was on the specials menu.....it was gnarly......mainly herb marinated tofu and chunks of potato.....also was supposed to come with beets, carrots and some sort of pesto....had to dig for the beets and carrots....pesto did help the cause but not much.....the tofu was the worst.....had hardly any flavor at all.....I make better tofu at home.......ohhhhhhh and they also served this with toast......like 4 pieces of it.....why??  Service Nice guy....seemed a little busy....made the requisite 3 stops....to order....to see if all is well.....to drop off the check.... Ambiance Small-ish space....but cute and indie.....loud when it's busy.....tables are pretty close to each other.....but that only makes it more charming  Overall I've eaten here a few times before and usually the food is pretty good....both the vegan and the non vegan dishes....I don't know what happened today....maybe we just chose poorly......but the food....with the exception of the tostadas was awful :(  I will be back for another round.....to see if this was a one time deal or if Handlebar is on the decline.....

Sometimes, it's just the nicest thing in the world knowing you can walk into a restaurant and have more than one or 2 options you can choose off the menu. I've been to Handlebar on and off in the past few years, but since I've gone vegan this year, this is something I've come to appreciate with all new gusto. Thankfully, Handlebar delivers (and can accomodate most of the items on their menu to be made vegan)!  And even better, there are plenty of good options for my meat-loving husband! We stopped in yesterday and I had the Grilled Tofu sandwich, which was large and fresh and delicious. The tofu was rubbed with a spicy blend to give it a little kick, the bread was hearty and they didn't skimp on the fresh tomatoes, spinach, sprouts and avocado spread. I also got a side of sesame broccoli, which even my broccoli-hating husband enjoyed!  As for the hubs, he got the Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap. I only had a bite, but it was tasty and definitely satisfying enough for the average meat eater. I did nab more than a few of his fries, which were also super delicious.  They also have a nice selection of beers to accompany the food. Vegans might not eat cheese, but that doesn't mean they don't enjoy a nice brew...Yay Handlebar!

Finally an awesome veggie restaurant even my carnivorous friends are all about. Buffalo Wrap and great beer selection, that's all that matters really. They lose one star because both times I've ordered take out it's been really underwhelming so be sure to eat there.

handlebar makes me happy! why you ask? well, if you've read any of my reviews to date, you know that making me happy starts with a great beer list. so i'm going to go ahead and check that off. something that may not be quite as obvious in my yelp reviews is my love for anything that has anything to do with bikes. voila, there you have it... a bar dedicated to bike advocacy. i'm loving it already. what else? i like the cozy atmosphere, the laid back--yet efficient staff, and the concept of vegan/vegetarian bar food. (food that is delicious, might i add). i vote for the black bean madura plus a fancy beer.

Wait a minute, wait just one minute! Really?  Is this place really this good or was I just dreaming?  I waited a couple days to write the review just to be sure... Delightful service! Delightful surroundings! Amazing food! Four of us sat down for a late brunch, each of us was collectively blown away with every aspect of the experience! We started with the fried pickles, they are served with a vegan ranch that is crazy good, and its vegan!  HMMMM!  Two of my friends had the Huevos Diablos, I tried it and it was grand, they had avocado added and we were all in aww of the amount, who doesn't love avocado...   One of us had the Handlebar omelet with pears, walnuts, and smoked gouda...  Perfect! I had the Pepita Tofu Scramble, I substituted eggs for tofu, which was no problem at all, this was filled with amazing flavor from pumpkin seed pesto to sweet potato, from kale to poblanos, it was off the hook!  OFF THE HOOOOOOOK! I tried it all, and it was all more then memorable in a very good way! This place is a hike for me, something tells me this is a hike I will be making a lot more often!

Handlebar is my #1 favorite brunch place.  Everything I've tried (well, except one sandwich which I think was called the Green Goddess, and that was my fault for ordering something that contained ingredients I know I don't like) is fabulous. Especially the vegetarian biscuits and gravy. Their vegetarian and vegan options are actually brunchy and delicious--some restaurants seem to think that vegetarians will just be satisfied with a bowl of brown rice, but Handlebar does it right. I highly recommend the Bloody Mary.

I have a lot of vegetarian friends and this is a great place to meet up for drinks & food.  So good, that I catch myself eating there even when I'm not meeting anyone! Everything I have had on the menu is great and the beer selection is pretty decent.  A great place to stop & hang and walking distance from my business!!
some things are good, some things are not so good!  try the fake meat buffalo chicken wrap, gouda mac n cheese and the black beans maduro! yum!  local brews too!

Delicious. I love everything i've had on this menu and even the things that are still a glimmer in the chef's eye...try the collard greens; they changed my life. Good beer selection. Love the atmosphere. Food, obviously. -1 star for size (different story in the summer), bathrooms (always a line), and cold waitstaff that just want the turnover...

Love it! I've had most of the menu and I really enjoy that the specials reflect the season.  The drink specials are great (my favorite is Bloody Mary Sundays) and though they have a varied beer selection, the cheap stuff is still available (and still cheap).  The staff is friendly and tolerant of the stupidity that can come after a few drinks.

Oh handlebar, how I really enjoy thee! Handlebar has become one of my favorite past times. Being a pescetarian, unfortunately there are not many restaurant choices out there for me to go eat at. Especially, If I choose not to eat fish or salads every day. Life is all about mixing it up isn't it?! Well Handlebar allows me to enliven my taste buds on an abundance of choices. One of my favorite dishes, the chili quesadillas. Yummy in the tummy I say. The restaurant has a great vibe, great outdoor seating in the summer (can't come soon enough), and an extensive beer list. I'm so happy that it's only 5 minutes from my abode. See you Sunday Handlebar and keep my seat warm.

Recent visits make me think this is a booze or brunch only establishment.  The draft list, though small, is interesting enough, and they've got more variety in bottles.  And you still can't beat their outdoor patio for brunch on a warm summer morning.  Even in the winter, their large glass windows facing out onto North Avenue give it a nice atmosphere. But I think they're exploiting their niche's wallets.  As other reviewers have noted, it's one of the few places where you can get bar food for vegans/vegetarians.  Okay, great, but, dietary issues aside, would you pay that much for food at a different bar?  Not being a vegetarian or vegan, I always feel uncomfortable paying that much for something I'm not all that jazzed about.  It's good food, but no standout.  I'd spend this much on a professional kitchen at a specialty restaurant; not a Wicker Park dive.  Maybe paying higher prices is just part of the whole vegetable experience?

Great option when your with friends who are vegetarians - nice options for them and also are great tasty items for the carnivore beasts as well :) Great beer selection for the beer snobs. Just really nice quality food - fresh and very dependable.

I really like Handlebar. It has a nice vibe... kind of funky/bar atmosphere.  Lots of awesome beers to choose from. Great vegan/vegetarian food too. Nothing too fancy or wild, but just solid, good food.  I really like the spicy chickin wrap. It's pretty awesome. Also their vegan ranch is great, and I second (third? fourth?) everyone's opinions on the deep fried pickles... lovely.  I have also had really good soup there.  I don't think I've ever tried anything there that I didn't really like?  Except maybe the BBQ seitan (I think it was seitan?) sandwich, which was OKAY - but kind of boring.   Also the back patio is really really nice in the summer (OH SUMMER, ITS BEEN TOO LONG).

Deep fried pickles. Yes. I like to kick it off with a deep fried dill pickle in some vegan ranch. If I'm feeling extra hungry, maybe some samosas as well. Both tasty with great sauces/dips. The ground nut stew is very good, it has a spicy kick to it that I wasn't expecting but was welcome. The Green Meanie can be slightly overwhelming for a salad sandwich, it's chock-full of sprouts/spinach/avocado to the point of almost bursting. The side of fried plantains is so good, I could honestly probably eat that alone as my meal. The wait staff is very friendly and accommodating. Basically, go here and leave full.

For the price of the food, it's not really worth it. The sandwich I had was mediocre and like $10. You can get way better vegetarian food in Chicago. UPDATE Their brunch is amazing! I'm still not a huge fan of their regular menu items, but I get brunch all the time.

I love this place!!!!  Being a vegetarian (technically pescatarian) theres not a lot of opportunities for me to have "buffalo chicken" but, behold, handlebar!  a place with not only seitan but seitan dressed up as a buffalo chicken wrap with vegan ranch!  yes please!  and man is that mac'n'cheese awesome!  and being the daughter of a kraft employee who brought home copious amounts of mac'n'cheese in my childhood, i'd say i'm a connoisseur.  i love those two things so much i'm never able to get anything else but i always have a bite or two of my guests' (all non-vegetarian and still big handlebar fans) meals and have yet to find a disappointing dish. on top of that the beer selection is pretty great too.  lots of beers for the beer aficionado to choose from and a friendly cheap yet delicious pbr for those of us functioning on a budget.   a place to visit, indeed!

On the bar side they have some good dark and local drafts plus decent shot and can beer specials some days.  The mac and cheese is as good is it sounds, but at $4 dollars as a side you'll want to make sure to add it to meal for only $1.50 extra. There is no meat at all and the fish is expensive and probably not worth it. If you're feeling cheep the chili cheese fries are a good value and quite tasty.

I think handlebar might be my favorite place in wicker park.  The first time I came here I didn't realize it was a veggie/vegan restaurant but I  didn't mind at all, I love vegan cuisine.  I had saw a picture of the smoked gouda mac and cheese on yelp and was not disappointed.   It was amazing, and so was my buffalo "chicken" wrap.  I really like the way that they season the seitan, i think it may actually taste better than chicken.  It was so good that I had to get it again the next time I ate here.  The chili cheese fries are also amazing.  Fresh cut fries with homemade bean chili topped with melted mozzarella cheese, amazing.  Everything on the menu sounds so good.  The portions are huge, I can only ever eat half of my food.  They have some good drink specials too,  $5 for a tecate and a shot of tequila. Love this place!

For some reason I always seem to come here with my dad when he visits...I guess that means it's a really great place all around, where anyone can find something they'll enjoy. It's a quiet little restaurant with an indoor dining area, a bar, and an outside dining patio (which is really nice in the warmer months). The staff is very friendly and the food is amazingly delicious. Oh man, the food, it is so so so good and there are always leftovers. I recommend the BBQ "chicken" (it's actually seitan) wrap!  Anyways, good place, it deserves nothing less than 5 stars.

Handlebar is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago.  I have never had a bad meal here; the sandwiches (grilled cheese, Green Meanie) are amazing, the vegan options (buffalo chick'n wrap) to die for, the wine and beer selection outstanding and the sides!  Oh dear lord, the sides; mac 'n' cheese, garlic mashed potatoes, collard greens, fried plantains... I'm suddenly so hungry.  I'd love to go for dinner today and try the blackened tofu fajitas!  One thing to note if you're coming in a group: they won't split checks and you can only use one credit card per table.  This policy is, frankly, a huge pain in the ass, especially if you're unaware in advance, but trust; you'll find the food, the booze, and the upbeat atmosphere well worth it!

This is a very dangerous place! I came over as part of the VSC crew, but I made it a little too early so I grabbed a seat @ the bar next to the organizer of the event. I was hungry and did not feel like waiting so I decided to get the Grilled Cheese with tomato and fries. While I waited on my meal, I decided to give Guiness another try (the first time I tried it felt like I was drinking tar out of a can). I now like Guiness! My food showed up and while it was not the greatest grilled cheese I ever had it served its purpose to soak up the alcohol I was gonna drink. The star of the show was the spicy pickle that came with the meal. They had $3 Jim Beam cocktails, so someone decided that we all should do 5 shots of it (spread out during the time we spent there not back to back), Nice!!!! I had another Guiness along with a Schneider-Weiss. They have a pretty cool beer selection and an even cooler serving team. I want to give a sppecial shout out to the serving team over there Morgan & Katie! You two are as cool as you wanna be...Cheers & Happy Holidays!

I just had the sweet potato and black bean quesadillas that were recommended by the waiter. I just bought the ingredients to try it on my own at home...that's how much I loved the dish! I always forget that there are tons of vegan options on their menu. Such a great and chill restaurant. My boyfriend and I went in our pajamas on Christmas eve...it was the only place open that we could find and no one stared at us for having bed hair:) !

Came here with a large group of people, and although groups larger than say, four people, really can't be seated together, Handlebar did as best they could and never showed pretension or impatience with our loud vegetarian mob! Actually, we weren't that loud, but the music and conversation in Handlebar is! Handlebar has a large all-vegetarian menu, and a nice beer selection as well. The kindly bartender let me sample a beer, and never said anything bad about the beer until I did, and then he let on that he thought this brewery's beers were overrated. Game face! Service was good all night.  I chose the Ground Nut stew, with kale, brown rice, a peanutty sauce...I was expecting a big steaming bowl of a hippie vegetarian miasma, but instead it came out looking like something out of a five-star Thai restaurant. Nice presentation and excellent taste! Since I live nearby I plan on returning to build a meal out of the premium sides like Gouda Mac 'n' cheese and Aged Cheddar Grits. And of course the Seitan Chorizo Nachos have my name on them, literally. I may even ride the bike over and lock it to their bike-friendly pole out front. Here's to many happy returns!

It's 25 degrees out today. My husband comes to pick me up from work and we head over to Handlebar for dinner. Free parking for our car steps from the door. One star. Loud music pumping through the restaurant on a Monday night. Add another star. Warm staff. Star. Random art, birds and posters around us. Estrella! Ground.Nut.Stew. And you have a total of five stars. I loved everything about my first visit to Handlebar. I started my meal with hot chocolate, plantains, then the ground nut stew and ended it with, you guessed it. Another mug of chocolate. I can't wait to go back... preferably on another cold day to repeat my experience.

So I came here with strong high hopes.  However, I was slowly let down as the night went on.  Come along for the story.... The wait is usually fairly decent (we just got lucky and had a table empty right when we walked inside). However, the average is about 20 minutes or longer since it is a pretty small place. The menu is a nice variety, complete with vegan entrees, meat lover cravings, and interesting taste combos. From organic style soups and nice salads, to even just sandwiches.  What's the catch? Handlebar comes with a slightly enlarged price-tag.  We tried out the blackened catfish fillet and the seared tuna sandwich. The catfish was nicely prepared and served with two sides (choices of mashed taters, fries, veggies, soup, and a few others... nice selections). But the price was about $16 with tax.... eh.    The seared tuna sandwich was a different problem altogether.  With appearance, this sandwich was like a golden puppy at a dog show - simply SPLENDID, nicely seared, glistening red color!  BUT..... this "dog" ruined the show and pooped on the judges.... The sandwich tasted and smelled, no reaked, of a fishiness. (Cardinal rule of fish - if the fish smells, it is not fresh).  Further, the tuna had NO seasoning on it to maybe overcome its not-so-fresh-ness. Just bland grilled tuna. For $13.95 menu price (about $16 with tax).  Quite frankly, I expected something far superior than what arrived at our table.  However my fellow yelpers, there is hope at Handlebar.  This is a great place if you simply want a drink.  They offer many great rotating brews on tap that are somewhat hard to find, and at decent prices. Plus, a good bottle list.  The bar-section is small, but hey, its cozy.  So tell ya what,  don't invite me to dinner at Handlebar - But I'll gladly meet you afterwards for some drinks!

this place is awesome.  there are only a few vegan options but they're all good.  The "chiken"ceasar wrap is amazing. good beer selection and bloody marys for when you're having brunch. also vegan fried pies are great
I pretty much love Handlebar.  I don't think it gets much better than the fried "chicken" salad they have.  Super yummy vegan food options and a cool vibe.

The food is decent, but I've had much better vegetarian fare. Everything I've tried seems off (too bland, too spicy, whatever). I've found things in my food that shouldn't be there. Although I received the customary "I'm sorry, this one's on us" before, it's still gross and unforgettable. I get the feeling that the cooks aren't professionals. The service can be very slow. I love the ample bike parking options, cute interior and nice beer selection.

I LOVE Handlebar's menu. They serve mostly vegetarian food with a few fish dishes, which is basically my diet, so it was a perfect fit for me. I have only eaten here once, and the taste of my food was good but not great. However, I will definitely come back and try other dishes when I am in Chicago next.

Excellent place!  We tried going here a couple weeks ago and there was a line out the door, so we left.  Last Saturday around 7pm, we showed up with only a 20 minute wait, and the wait was definitely well worth it.  I didn't know, but the menu is primarily vegetarian, which was great news for my friend and I both being vegetarian.  Everyone's food around us looked really good.  It was difficult to choose one thing.  I ended up ordering one of the specials of the night, the Harvest plate, which had grilled tofu topped with cranberry relish, mashed sweet potatoes, green beans, with a mushroom gravy.  My friend got something with rice and beans and plaintains, and in my opinion, plantains make everything better.  My boyfriend got the shrimp and cheesy grits (YUM).  My only complaint was the lack of good beer specials.  The special of the night was $5 margaritas.  I got a $5 beer.  The cheapest beer on draft was $5, so that made things a bit more expensive for the three of us all drinking beers.  Otherwise, delicious food and fun atmosphere.  Show up earlier than later to get a table.
OMGWTF VEGAN FRIED PICKELS ARE OMN THE MENU!~!! Even better than the New Awwleans floppy ass grease slices. YUM!

I give in, you get 5 stars.  I had a grilled cheese with tomato's and a side of butternut squash soup last night.  Delish!  And Rach had Veggie Maduro.  No idea whats in it,, but that is some serious flavor.  And their beer selection is extraordinarily outstandingly awesome.  I'm not sure why I only gave you 4 stars to begin with?  I was wrong.  You've been gunnin for that number one one veggie spot and i believe you have it.   I'll be braver though and try the fried pickles next time...

Definitely a great nieghborhood joint. It's complete with kitschy decor, strange artwork, sizeable beer selection, good service, and a menu that seeks to please. The black bean nachos were devoured quickly by our table. The beers kept coming and the vegetarian in the group was pleased with her entree. The dark lighting and the homey service will probably makes this place even better as the temps drop. I will be back to try some of the other items on the menu.

Hipsters unite! This place has delicious vegetarian and beer options. I ordered the Buffalo "Chicken" and it was delicious. The mac and cheese was also high on the list. Many unique beer choices you can't just find in any restaurant. The back outdoor dining area is the place to be on a beautiful summer day.

I had the best dinner! Fried pickles and ranch sauce was dead on. The vegan ranch I can eat on just about everything; I dipped the rest of my meal in it as well. BBQ Seitan sandwich was fantastic as usual and I love the switch a more sandwich-type bread (sourdough?). With garlic mashed potatoes. I like my potatoes more buttery and whipped (vs the handlebar version which are chunky, peppery mashed potatoes) but that didn't ruin it for me. Overall very satisfying comfort food, which is very hard to find in the vegan world.

I've had more mediocre meals here than any other place in Wicker Park so I quit going about 3 years ago even though I live right around the corner.  the last straw was a lukewarm catfish sandwich, cold fries and a really gross samosa. The bikers can have this place for themselves.

Really like the Handlebar, good food, the service was very patient and good.  the atmosphere was really nice, I ordered the bbq seitan, huge!!  it provided me with a few meals afterward.  Really want to go back.

My favorite part about Handlebar is the atmosphere.  It is cozy and hip all at once. I almost feel like I am sitting in a hipster's kitchen at a dinner party - and that's a good thing.   A large amount of my close friends are vegetarians, and I feel that most of the places we go to eat when in groups are meat heavy and only have a few basic meatless options (salad, mozzarella sticks, etc). Handlebar is a perfect place to go pay them back for all that patience.  It has options to make vegetarians and meat-eaters alike happy.  I always get a few appetizers - my favorite is the cheddar grits.  The tostadas and samosa are good, although not the best I've ever had.

I've attempted SEVERAL times to go veg but I'm a big foodie and I always go back to eating meat :(  However, I wandered in here by accident b/c my visiting friend was hungry and it is literally the closest bar/restaurant to my apt.  And this place makes me feel like its possible to be a well-fed vegetarian. Its really really good vegetarian food.  the nacho's (with avocado) are delicious and have a little bite to them.  The chili cheese fries (and i hate chili, btw) were delicious as well and my friend ordered the black bean tostatas, which were to my extreme surprise, were very good.  i didn't even miss the meat.  one bit.   My carnivorous BF loved the nachos & chili cheese fries as well when I dragged him here.  My roommate tried the blackened catfish... said the brown rice she ordered with it was weak but the fish was good.  Everyone at our table seemed to enjoy their dishes.  Although the roomie said her omelette at brunch (she went back the next day haha) was greasy.  good, but greasy.  Plus they have Ephemere!  They have a very decent beer selection.  Not huge, but good.   Also, the first time I was there, I left my new phone on the table.  I went back an hour later and our waiter pulled it out from behind the bar.  thank god!  Oh, and they have a great patio in back during the summer.  highly recommended.

I see a lot of mixed reviews on here, but for some reason no one has anything bad to say if got the biscuits and gravy.  Maybe it's because as a vegetarian, I haven't had biscuits and gravy in years, but damn. That shit is good. Nice enough atmosphere, I'd go there again if I'm ever to revisit Chicago. And I'd get the biscuits and gravy again.

Y-U-M. im not currently vegan (although i have stuck to a vegan lifestyle for large chunks of time, so im somewhat familiar with meat replacements and alternative proteins, etc.), but i am absolutely veg-friendly and was excited to try this place.   i was not disappointed -- the flavors and textures were amazing.  i ordered the black beans maduro *its one of the dishes for which you have to request vegan preparation* (it was a tough decision, but if there are plantains on the menu, i will ultimately gravitate toward them :)).  it was phenomenal.  it was crazy-spicy, though (the menu did warn that the sauce was spicy, but damn), and id recommend that if you typically like medium-level heat (as i do), you might want to request a milder sauce (because the kick from the sauce had me tearing and i had to take a long-ish break from eating and then eat around the sauce when i was able to get back to eating again.  sad, cause from my brief moments of non-pain, the sauce was yummy). since ive only ordered this once, i have no idea if its typically this spicy, so i guess id suggest erring on the conservative side if ordering this.  despite all of my whining about the spice, i would absolutely order this dish again. other thoughts: -its a pleasant walk to and from the blue line. -it was surprisingly loud/busy on a wednesday night at 9.  (bear in mind that i dont like crowds, so if you dont particularly care, i wouldnt worry about it.) -i was, by far, the lamest person there.  if youre at all prone to feeling self-conscious in situations where youre, e.g., the lamest-dressed (:P), steel yourself before going in :) will absolutely go back (albeit shooting for an 'off' time).

I probably wouldn't ride my bike out of the way to get here, but I would definitely ride on someone's handlebars there. No need to sweat to get here.  The Tilapia with a Dijon sauce was solid. I loved the Smoked Gouda Mac 'n' Cheese and the Aged Cheddar Grits! The veggie burger was a complete miss for me (all the combinations together on the burger did not make for anything tasty).  Being a casual place, the atmosphere was relaxing and chill. Paintings of figures with lifeless eyes graced the walls (not only did I enjoy the art, I'm looking into buying one).  We went here because I didn't feel like being in a crowded pretentious place, and Handlebar delivered. Although the food is not outstanding (at least what I tried, but I've been told Brunch is good), it's a great place to go to have the taste of home cooked pescatarian/vegetarian food.

This place has some of the best veggie food in Chicago. It's a little bit of a walk from Wicker Park proper, but well worth it. You can always find parking outside, which is another plus. I highly suggest the meal of three sides, with mashed potatoes, veg sausage, and gouda mac and cheese.  On the downside, its way too loud in there sometimes.

I'd give it 4.5 if i could...  I'm not a vegetarian, but this place is legit.  Went with my 99% vegetarian girlfriend, and she was loving every minute of it. I STRONGLY recommend the plantains and the Gouda mac and cheese.  Upgrading to these sides should be a no-brainer.   Service was attentive, asked if we had questions, but didn't really get into a huge special-list presentation, which I'm totally fine with.   They have a daily drink special of $5 for a Tecate and a shot of tequila.  Good way to take the edge off.   Even if my girlfriend wasn't such a veggie, I'd be going back.   Give 'em a shot.

In their defense, I should have read the limited one-page, two-sided menu more carefully. If I had, I wouldn't have ordered the salad with "fried" chicken because what was floating around in the vision inside my head was a salad with grilled chicken. But when the $10 for two cups "fried" chicken salad arrived, I tried to keep an open mind.  With one scan of the plate my mind closed again tighter than a popcorn fart. No salad dressing on the side (the dressing already mixed in), the "fried" (I heard no frying coming from that kitchen) chicken was microwave-baked hard and dry, and the two half-inch slices of rock-hard complimentary bread on the side may be good for cheap dental work but ain't good for mastication in general.  I looked to my companion (he of the equally sad-looking seasoning-slathered "blackened" fish fillet, cup of lumpy garlic mashed potatoes, and unusually large ice cream scoop-sized portion of chalky brown rice for $13) and said, "It's like a meal some kid thought he once saw on a TV show and is trying to duplicate from memory."  We both agreed that although we haven't been to the Handlebar in a while, the food quality seems to have taken a drastic nosedive and the menu appeared to be whittled down to skimpy portions of food that are more constructed than cooked: cheap easy prepped sandwiches and microwaveable ingredient-rich entrees. Even by vegetarian standards, the food is bland and has a commissary quality to it that, like most vegetarian/vegan places in Chicago, just doesn't jibe with the prices and no amount of quaint or quirky atmosphere will cover up.  The consensus is that this is the kind of place that really comes alive in summer with loads of beer foam on one's lip (slightly high) and after a sweaty bike (slightly exhausted). It's the atmosphere, not the food, that probably draws folks and made me a fan in the past. But that being so, it's also in a great location, has a great concept, and seemingly has a loyal clientele that wants to be given reasons to return, yet the menu is poorly planned, the food is subpar at best, and the overall execution of the menu makes it hard to buy their greenie-biker-vegetarian friendly shtick.  BBQ chicken wrap and grilled cheese of the same quality can be picked up at a Jewel deli counter and better seitan can be had at Whole Foods' deli counter. So why spend twice the money to get it at Handlebar for poorer quality? And why no experimentation over the years? I vaguely recall these same menu items from my last visit, but if it's truly greenie food love going on here, why no seasonal foods (soups right now, for instance)? Why no local or organic offers? Why no experimentation on the same level as they seem to enjoy experimenting with the decor?  If hipsterism is just the co-opting of symbols without any intrinsic value or meaning carried through to concept, I'd say Handlebar's menu pretty much sums up that aesthetic.

I'm not a fan.  I'm not a vegetarian but do apprectiate vegetarian fare.  I just don't think the food is worth the high prices and pretensious atmosphere.  And don't think about going in there to just have a couple of beers.  There is hardly any bar seating and they give you weird look if you want a table but no food menu.  This place is not very welcoming at all.   The outdoor area is very nice.  I wish a better restaurant/bar would move in there.

very fun but very loud. Went here on my recent visit to the windy city. The decor and music are your average variety hipster cool feel to it. The food was great but not the best. I had the buffalo chicken wrap which i loved. I tried my GF mac and cheese and in no way though it was worth 4 bucks. They had a decent selection of beers but a pretty small menu. I enjoyed what i ordered but some of my friends admitted that the food was a bit too spicy for them. the waiter seemed to careless that we were there but in his defence they were uber busy.

I really love meat, I just like my protein, I do. So when I went to Handlebar the first time this morning it was me being nice to my Vegan friend, I do love veggies but I like to have meat with it. So the three of us split the samosas which I believe were baked and the flavor inside was really nice. They were a bit hard but I believe its because they were baked. I had the special for the day shrimp, spinach and pesto fritata, the shrimp was so well cooked, not fishy nor salty. Everything was yummy and I will go again for brunch and love it.  Hip hip hooray handlebar!

Five Stars, firm. And there is a lot to love. In Chicago, its normal to go into a restaurant and order a vegetarian sandwich and all you get is a white roll, sprouts, mayo, lettuce and tomatoes. Or at least this was my experience. However, here, they know that it doesn't have to be bland be be veggie.  First thing I liked about this place is that when you ride up(yes, take your bike there), they have bike parking right in front, attached to the face of the building! Its pretty nice to not have to worry about my bike being knicked, since I can see it at all times. Inside, the decor is funky, with stuff taped up everywhere. eclectic, but it has lots of stuff to look at, in case you get bored with your dinner partners. Like the bull horns on the wall(funny bc they don't serve meat!!!) The food is awesome. And not pretentious. I dig the fact that they can make most dishes vegan, and yet still serve fish, all without having to offer gratitude.  They are blending 3 worlds into one! And its good! Real good. I got the Asparagus, Portabello Gemeli, and I ate the whole thing. Just the right mix of cheese, and oil with the veggies. My friend got the grilled Tuna steak with roasted garlic allioli. Seared just right. Their beer/drink selection isn't as extensive, but good. They have Original sin, which is all that I can ask for. They don't have a full bar, but do offer margaritas.  Overall, the staff was friendly(and all dudes, which was really nice) and quick. Food was awesome and ambiance fun. I will be coming back.

The only way to start this review of this hip, little, bike-punk bar and restaurant tucked away in Wicker Park is to explain that every person has a certain meal that is their utmost favorite.  Mine is the Buffalo Chicken Wrap.  I get it everywhere.  It's my thing.   So, when I traveled to the vegan-exclusive Handlebar and spotted a vegetarian version of this classic favorite made with seitan instead of meat, of course, I knew I had to try it.  Imagine my surprise when it turned out to be the best iteration of my most beloved meal.  Hands down.  Absolutely incredible.  And that means a lot coming from somewhere who has eaten variations of this item all around the country.  This one takes the win. The restaurant as a whole doesn't slack anywhere else.  There is plenty of wonderful table space, including some pleasant window seating.  The bar is decorated in the style of what can only be described as how Mad Max would have decorated a TGI Fridays.  The walls are lovingly decorated with posters and paraphernalia that looks authentically hole-in-the-wall without the smell of urine and passed out homeless at the bar. Oh, and the food is priced just right.

I don't say this often - but I wish there was a 2.5 stars! Or wish it was a 1-10 scale so I could give it 5! The place was loud and noisy on a Tuesday night, making it impossible to talk! The food was uber-bland and just not interesting at all - salads, appetizers (tostada) or sandwiches (tofu). I appreciate the effort at vegetarian food, but I wish they didn't make it so boring and bland.

My meal: Blank Bean Maduro The verdict: terrible.  Cheaper, tastier, healthier alternative:  ricearoni.com The salsa was weird and gross, the black beans and rice were the saltiest I've ever tasted, and there was a flavorless brick with the consistency of some cheese/bread/potato amalgamation resting atop this pile of garbage that neither I nor my girlfriend was able to identify.  My girlfriend's meal: BBQ Seitan Sandwich The verdict: wow, even more terrible, somehow. Cheaper alternative:  pupperoni.com Really nasty stuff.  Indistinguishable from pupperoni using all 5 senses.  Enough said.  Bottom line: the food at this place is really overpriced and tastes terrible.  With so many better dining options nearby, there is absolutely no reason to go here unless you are a vegan desperate for options.  Don't buy the hipster hype overrunning this yelp page.
If you're not a cash person like me, then it's a great alternative to Earwax. Great menu & vegan options. The back patio/beer garden is very nice.

I love you, Handlebar.  Why I've taken so long to review you is beyond me. Probably because I have been busy dreaming of your grilled cheese sammiches served by hotties. I'm not vegetarian, but am a pretty picky eater, so I love all the veggie options.  I think I've loved everything I've ever ordered except for some brown rice dish near the bottom of the menu. Plantains as a side are to die for.   Most importantly, the beer selection is awesome.  And, every server I've ever had has been phenomenal.  Bartenders, great!  I have many a great story from this place late night. It can get crowded on weekend nights, so plan on a wait usually.  Not as bad if the patio is open as it doubles the amount of space.

Waaay overpriced for what it is.  The quality of the food has gone down, down, down over the past few years; I used to dream about the BBQ Seitan sammich, but now, it's almost a complete waste of time.  Dry seitan with a  smattering of BBQ sauce lumped on a couple pieces of toast and a handful of onions on top does not a good sammich make.  My real glitch is paying $3 for a samosa - I know what's in there, and nothing they've done has added $2.50 in value.  And a $10 cocktail?  Seriously?   The staff I've never had a problem with.  I don't go there to be entertained or to make friends.  I go there to eat what I assume is good food.  Sadly, that will no longer be the case.

i would eat every meal there if i could. no joke. its that good. its even better after a night of drinking. their bloody marys have revived me countless times. the service is mad friendly and sitting out on the patio, if the weather permits, is a REALLY good idea.   thinking about this place makes me homesick :(

I'm torn about how many stars to give.  This place is somewhere between 3 and 4 stars.  But I should point out that I am not a vegan or a vegetarian, so I'm not particularly impressed by lots of Vegan food. We walked in, and the place was pretty cute inside.  But then we went out to the patio, and it was great out there.  That is the perfect place to spend warm evenings! We ordered the chili cheese fries as an appetizer, and they were delicious.  The chili was good in fact, that I ordered it as my side.  I split a grilled cheese with tomato sandwich, and it was really good.

Handlebar is a fun hipster type place.My gurl Candy pie took myself and another friend mini to get some veggie dinner.She had told me they had great vegetarian/vegan food and she sure was right.I instantly like the place just from walking in. I liked the server we had he was very friendly and gave us the attention we needed. I ordered the a salad with seitan chicken it was really good and I have to admit my first time eating seitan. It was better then I expected and actually crave it since! Oh I almost forgot that all 3 of us got a really good blueberry flavored beer that was a delight!

I had brunch at Handlebar and was extremely impressed with the options.
