Aside from vegan waffles and pancakes and tofu scrambles, they also had a "vegan diablo rancheros" ($8.75) which were excellent---spicy, colorful, crispy corn cakes with seitan, beans and more. The food was fresh and unusually sophisticated. I'm still disappointed that I tend to be the only non-white person in Handlebar whenever I go, but maybe that's part of the game if you're vegan and in Wicker Park. Or Chicago, in general.

Buffalo 'Chicken' Wrap - Nothing else tops this in their everyday menu.  Their Brunch Food is great too, Biscuits and Gravy, mmmm, and their french toast, mmmm... they only have it on weekends though.  Dessert wise the Peanut Butter and Jelly Pie is awesome and I think there's only one other vegan friendly dessert, and it honestly never really appeals to me to get it (I think it's a raspberry chocolate tart?). On the down side, I feel like some of their other vegan dishes, especially side dishes, are a little mediocre... greens, and the chili isn't the best, but you do get a lot of tortilla chips with it. the way to go is the fries with an extra side of vegan ranch. Not too pricey compared to other entree serving restaurants, but it's not cheap either, look to spend at least $10. Overall it's a great vegan friendly restaurant and I eat there all the time (solely for the Buffalo 'Chicken' Wrap).

Great, vegetarian-friendly food. Wonderful beer selection. Amazing art on the walls. Reasonably price. Good music. Tim Kinsella from Make Believe walked in while we were waiting for our food.  I had the buffalo "chicken" wrap w/chili fries and mac'n'cheese.  Everything was delicious, and I usually don't care for fake meat.  Overall excellent experience.  Will return soon.

I'm a pretty big fan. I really like this restaurant but I need to try more things. I had the BBQ seitan sandwich. I think how seitan is made in a restaurant says a lot about it, because it can be complete shit or it can be awesome. This was awesome. It was delicious and the bread was awesomely toasty. The sandwich is huge and I was even cool with paying extra for one of the special sides. So I got the gouda mac and cheese which was fucking delicious. Either way, I like the style of this restaurant and the people I was with both loved their food too. I'll be back!
You've redeemed yourself, Handlebar. Black bean tostadas with avocado and tomatillo salsa and fully tamale-style tostada = win. Extra points for the extra spicy bloody mary, too.

The first time I went hear over a year ago I was not very impressed with the food.  But I just went again last week and it was so delicious!  They do a really great job with their vegan options.  I had this stew that was so good.  And the atmosphere was fun too. I wish I still lived in Chicago so I could go again soon.

I had no idea this place was veggie when I came here, but that did not deter my carnivorous friend and I.  The menu looked appetizing.  The smoked gouda mac and cheese was the bee's knees.  Tried my friend's "chicken wrap" and it was delish.  Good beer specials (but don't take my word for it as I thrive on Miller Lite).  My only complaints were that the collard greens were way too salty, and the music was too loud to carry conversation.  But I am wiling to forgive these mishaps because our server (can't remember his name) was super nice and super cute!

Why is it that whenever you are with 3 or more people someone always insists on going to Handlebar? Seriously this happens all the time, over and over, year after year. I have had so much bland food and tons of tude thrown at me over the years that i can't believe that I fold into going here from time to time. Sweet patio dude!

I really like this restaurant, as do my non-vegan friends. I've had something different every time, I've had the vegan stuffed ravioli (amazing), Vegan Breakfast Burrito (my favorite - and yes I dream about this one ;)), Vegan Mashed Potatoes, and the Vegan Buffalo Chicken Wrap (heaven - as everyone (including the carnivores) agreed). They also have coffee here too. This is in a great location, the employees are VERY nice, and the decor is quite nice as well. ***UPDATE*** Do not get the Vegan BBQ Sandwich, it's actually horrible.  Other than that, everything else it great.

Handlebar is one of those go-to's.  The food is reasonably priced and certainly palatable. I'm all about the BBQ Seitan, which eats more like a pulled pork than not, and the salad with the 'chicken' strips - lovely greens and crisp veggies make for a great salad, pretty sizable too. There are several lovely things on the menu, but this place excels at providing veg-friendly comforts as well as great drink specials.  It's hard to resist a good beer and some eats on the patio on a mild summer day.  "Reminds me of Portland," my friend said. It just reminds me of moments such as those: comfortable, full, and slightly well-beered.

Folks, this is my favorite restaurant/bar in Chicago when I'm interested in a casual, mid-brow, adventurous, beer with brunch/dinner type of experience (which is pretty much my ideal situation).  They always change up the brews, the menu shifts from time to time without straying from favorites, the wait staff is great, and they play a nice variety of indie/classic rock/garage/new wave jams.   Btw, I'm not a vegetarian and neither are my most of my friends that frequent this place- it's one of those rare vegetarian restaurants that works for everyone!  Everything I've tried is delicious but I'd say the brunch menu has a slight edge on the dinner menu.

The food was ok, the service terrible....I don't like it when your server strolls and stops to talk to his friends before he brings you the fork that you so nicely asked for so you can start eating your food. My husband had to give me his and eat with his fingers until the server decided to bring it which was 10 min after we asked I only had one bite of food left. We had to put the tables together ourselves since no one wanted to help us. The worst thing was when we gave them 3 credit cards to pay the bill. there was six people 3 couples and they told us they could not do that not even 2 cards. People this is a lie...they can do it. This is the only time I have heard this from ANY.....restaurant in last 10 years. That, for sure is not service. They should change this right away, I've never heard the word NO so many time in one visit, everything we asked for they said no to. Stop saying no to everything and say yes sometimes with a smile and remember who the customer is handlebar.

5 Stars.  One of my favorite places to eat, ever.  I reccomend the BBQ Seitan, it's to die for.  It's also so big you can bring home seconds to enjoy later on.  The food portions are sooooo reasonable for the price and I love the decor of the place.  The staff is always friendly and the summer patio is is PERFECT.

Second time visiting, this time with the fam (omnivores) for Sunday brunch. Food and service were great (4 stars) but the music was so loud, conversation was difficult. My mom commented at one point that she couln't imagine eating there with a hangover. Good point.  Excellent veggie sandwich with decadent smoked gouda mac and cheese side. Fritatta and scramble specials were had and enjoyed as well.  Food was good enough to appear mismatched with the rough decor, death metal sounds, and cheap $.

My second visit to Handlebar took place last week.  I had the black bean tostados-vegan style.  This was the tastiest lunch I have had in ages!  It was so delicious I wanted to learn how to make it and eat it everyday.   The interior has a casual, rock and roll vibe.  One could imagine the Grateful Dead hanging out here.  During my first visit, I enjoyed the samosas, which were also delectable. Having been a vegetarian for seven years, I recently became a vegan.  Vegetarians, vegans and meat lovers unite!  This place is dynamite!
holy crap. go here on a summer night and sit out back on the patio. drink beers until you can't feel your face. order a grilled cheese sandwich. you can't go wrong.

I'll have to say that I've biked here and didn't even know they had places to lock up in the back! When I got there, I locked it in the front and there was only one bike, which seemed a bit strange since this was a bicyclist loving crowd eatery :-) The food was delicious and I got a upgrade to the gouda mac and cheese next to my Green Meanie (I kept thinking of Oscar from Seseme Street). They had me at Avocado and herbed goat cheese.  The sandwich was good size, it wasn't too small or too big, I was able to finish it and finish my mac and cheese.   I also had some of the Black Bean Maduro (with Plantains) that my friend ordered.  This dish had both the sweet and spicy mixing pleasantly on my tongue.   While we didn't get any beer to drink for that meal, they have pretty good deals specials daily.  Check out their website for each day's special.   I will definitely go there again, and might even do so this weekend as a friend is visiting from out of town. Just remember to bring cash.  They only accept one credit card per table and it has to be more than $10.

This place is a good West side alternative to Chicago Diner and friendlier for your meat inclined buds. Fish tacos great, so is salad. Great vibe, nice backdoor space, plenty of room to park your bike and friendly hipster servers.  Don't overlook this place but make the extra walk a few blocks up North Ave. and you won't be disappointed.

I had high hopes for Handlebar. You see, I'm a southerner. Not politically, or socially. Not regionally, since I'm living here in Chicago. But by birth and in terms of food, I'm a Georgian. I love fried green tomatoes, stewed yellow squash, and cheese grits. So when I saw that Handlebar offered the pinnacle of all southern breakfasts, biscuits and gravy, in a vegetarian version, I was sold and my girlfriend, roomie, and I made plans to hit up Handlebar for brunch. The first thing I noticed about Handlebar is that it is a popular brunch spot. There were no seats left inside when we arrived and they were just opening the back patio. While we waited, another 3 groups came through the door. Before the end of our meal, the entire patio was full, too. That may explain the service, as well.  We sat down and I decided to order the biscuits with seitan sausage gravy with a side of fried plantains. I also asked the server if I could get their loose leaf teas over ice. He said no. This always bothers me because all you have to do is steep the tea and pour it over a glass of ice. In any case, I got the apple juice, which is overpriced at $3.50 a glass. Come ON. We sat out in the heat and waited for our food to arrive. My girlfriend and I got ours first (she had the breakfast burrito) and then, after our server had a leisurely conversation right behind us, he went in and got out roommate's food. To explain the food: The southern biscuit is a delicate, beautiful, and mysterious thing. There are several versions, some flaky, some crisp on the outside, some a little doughy. There are as many recipes as there are grandmothers in the south and none of those recipes are written down. Regardless, this was not a southern biscuit. This was some weird whole wheat, grainy, brown, behemoth mass. It was not soft or flaky or buttery or any of those things. I'm all for health food. I'm a vegetarian, right? But once in a while you want to splurge and eat the bad stuff you miss from before you decided to be a responsible adult. The gravy was brown, like you'd expect chicken gravy to be, not white like real sausage gravy. Sausage gravy should be made with, well, sausage (or fake sausage, in this case), a flour roux, and milk. This was not. This was not what I wanted, not what I ordered, not what I came here for. Not only was I disappointed, but everyone at our table was less than impressed with their food. The potatoes were bland, the food wasn't cooked right, etc. and so we all left with full bellies but empty hearts. Add that to the fact that the place isn't cheap ($7 for a biscuit, $4 for plantains, etc.) and the service was awful and it just wasn't what we'd hope. Maybe someday, veggie-sausage gravy biscuit, I will find you again.

There's not a damn thing here that's not delicious. Yes, even the Mexican dishes. Those tostadas are the real thing. Handlebar's serving up the tastiest tofu, the sauciest seitan, and deep-fried pies. The collard greens are not to be missed. Did you see the beer list? You didn't? I'll be happy to go back with you to check it out.

My experience with Handlebar was great - and it was aided no end by the research I conducted ahead of time.  The various reviews I read summed up Handlebar into these four, neat points: (1) great food; (2) great desserts; (3) great atmosphere; (4) asshat waitstaff. My girlfriend ordered the fajitas and I ordered the "chicken" wrap.  Both were served relatively quickly and both were so sensational that our conversation completely stopped in favor of eating, eating, eating.  The dessert was a blueberry/almond/ice cream crisp thing that, when eaten together, was a fantastic flavor explosion, the words for which quickly eluded me.  We could only communicate our love of the food in wide-eyed wonder at each other.  Seriously, it was that good.    Slathered around and over the food and tables is an ocean of fun music (from unsigned hopefuls to Led Zep) and original art, which, unlike quite a few displays in restaurants across the city, could be described as both "original" and "art"! The staff?  Asshats.  The host guy came up to us, said "Outside's full?  You want inside?  I'll be back" and then went in the back and then behind the bar to drink some water for a while before seating us.  The waiter guy, with his too-tight black T-shirt and undisciplined hair, was feet-draggingly charming and wonderfully apathetic.  "So yeh, uh, whaddya want?"   Taken at face value, it would have been easy to get offended.  However, seeing it as a hipster Ed Debevic's, it was actually more than fine.  It was enjoyable. I would recommend Handlebar heartily as a full-on restaurant, not just a veggie place.  Brilliant.

living five minutes walking from this place where I can order a vegan chicken wrap and still hang around my house for 10 minutes until taking the quick walk up the street to get it? This is not going to be good for me. Not one bit...

One of my favorite places in Chicago.  Great vegetarian food, even better bloody mary's.  The beer garden is cozy.  Added bonus is you can wear your cycling clothes and not look like a fool.  Highly recommended.

this place really doesn't need another four star review, but whatev, i have to gush about how damn good the vegan french toast is. seriously, vegan french toast! and it's good! really good. in fact, i think it inspired me to go back to my vegan ways. let's see, despite the amazing toast, i had a bloody mary, which was ok and pleasantly different because they put just a splash of guiness in it. but wasn't the best one i've ever had. i really digged the inside decor, nice, but a little punk, but not too hipster. then the patio was very nice with brick and trees for shade. i definitely see myself visiting this place every time i'm in chicago.

Handlebar gets  a high-five and then one on the flip-side as well.  I crave the southern plate on a regular basis and really appreciate the focus on fresh food.  The kitchen does a great job of keeping is simple and delicious with the beer list and bloody marys rounding everything out.  Sit on the patio whenever the weather plays nice.

What's not to like? Tasty food with good vegetarian options. I'm not a vegetarian, but I'm a big fan of fake meat and Handlebar's has great flavor and texture. Of course they have plenty of delicious dishes without fake meat, too. They have a serviceable beer selection with local micros on tap, and you can get a Dos Equis and shot of tequila for $5 any night, and they have other drink specials depending on the day. The back patio is nice when weather permits. Local art on the walls. All in all, it's quite pleasant and I can't wait to go back.

I really enjoy the food, and that's not just because they get me drunk.  But it needs to be said that Handlebar's liquor license is a big part of its charm.  They have rotating specials, tasty brews on draft, and a decent bottle selection.  I've discovered a couple good new beers here. On to the food: Almost everything is good.  I'm fake meat-averse (since I can have the real thing), but the seitan chili fries are pretty damned tasty with a beer and Cholula hot sauce.  The Black Beans Maduro, which is more "maduro" and not many "black beans," is probably my favorite dish.  I'd also recommend the fish tacos (the only dead animal on the menu), the Meal of Three Sides with smoked gouda macaroni, and, um, one of the non-fake-meat sandwiches that slips my mind at the moment.  The samosas are tasty, too. I've never had brunch, but they serve that here on weekends. Handlebar will satisfy both your vegetarian friends and out-of-towners looking for local flavor.  It's a biker bar, as in bicycles, so I guess you could also bring any bike-riding friends who feel marginalized and alone.  They won't seat you until your entire party is there, even if the place is fucking empty.  This is a relatively new policy.  For shame.

beware - if you drop your fork, they may charge you a replacement fee... i was thoroughly disappointed tonight.  i mean charging me 50 cents for 2 squirts of bottled honey mustard????  i wouldn't need it if your tofu sandwich actually had flavor aside from the scraped on guac spread.  the sandwich was overloaded with spinach instead of concentrating on taste.  the once-loved chorizo nachos were 99.9% black beans.  jalapeno peppers, please... ya guessed it - 50 cents charge.  lastly, swapping out the pistachios for walnuts (i HATE pistachios) in the everything green salad cost me a whopping $2.00.  more forgiving if it was an add-on but unless the salad was pre-made and someone had to fish around to remove the pistachios, this was the biggest rip-off of the evening.  last i checked pistachios cost a heck of a lot more money so wasn't i saving them a few cents?   what happened to my once beloved handlebar????  i struggle to find vegi places as it is in this bustling city and now i must shun you...

I am a vegetarian and a cyclist and I love this place. The food is great and I've always had good service. The bloody marys are awesome and the beer garden is a great place to hang out.  The only negative I've found is that they sometimes won't seat you until your whole party is there.

Good food.  My dining mate had the mac n cheese but all took a bite and was every bit as good as the hype.  The fish tacos were fresh and flavorful.  The patio seating is great to just sit back and have a beer.

This food rocks my socks off.  Notoriously slow/bad service knocks my review down from 5 stars to 4, but the food is outstanding.  A fantastic vegan/vegetarian menu for dinner; can't wait to try their brunch.

Really delicious food-- and I'm not even a vegetarian.  Smoked Gouda Mac n Cheese-- get it.  I don't even like most mac n cheese, but this is sooooo good.  I also had the breakfast burrito with seitan chorizo and it was very tasty.  Everyone I was with loved their food.  We also enjoyed sitting outside in the beer garden.  The service was a little slow, but otherwise no complaints.

For a vegetarian restaurant, it was completely excellent.  The food was delicious and filling. Good beer selection. Those who believe that the smoked gouda mac 'n cheese is great, however, clearly have never tasted mine.  It would call that dish 'average'.  Beware, this restaurant has a chintzy 'one credit card' rule.

I wanted to go to Handlebar for so long and I finally made it this week!  (This has become a recurring theme in my life)  I was not disappointed.   The menu is great!  They only serve vegan, vegetarian and seafood dishes.  All of the food we ordered was thoughtfully put together and had lots of fresh ingredients.  I had the Blackbeans Maduro and loved it.  The flavors were combined beautifully and it had a great bit to it. I wanted to give it 5 stars, but sadly the service did not provide.  It wasn't horrible but the waitstaff was annoying enough that it definitely affected how much we enjoyed our meal.  They took my beer before I had finished it and then 3 different people asked my friend if she was done eating before she had finished.  They kept prowling around like piranha's and it got to be a little much.  It's usually complacent service that suck...this time was the opposite.  Also they don't split checks which is forever annoying. Overall though, I will be back...and soon.  The food and beer selection is worth the trip to Wicker Park!

This is really a 3.5 rating. 4 stars for the food, 3 stars for the service. As mentioned below nearly everything on their menu is either straight up vegetarian or vegan OR has the option of being veggie/veganized. That's pretty sweet. I always get the fake Buffalo "Chicken" wrap, which is excellent. My friend and I split an appetizer of vegan nachos once though (in additon to our food) and it the hugest plate of delcious garbage I've ever seen. People were staring at us like we were giant fattys (which we are, so whatever). But it was great. I like going in the summer because their outdoor patio is really nice. Inside it kind of smells like dirty dishwater and its dark and very crowded. They have a good beer list and some decent alcohol specials. Service has been spotty for me. I've had perfectly pleasant service and I've had real dicks for waiters. It's hit or miss.

the food is incredible and completely worth any sort of distance you might need to travel to taste it.  my ONLY complaint is that the service isn't that amazing.  it's not horrible, but it seems the wait staff feels really overworked.  they refuse to split checks, which is annoying.  the handlebar omelette is divine!

I can eat at Handle Bar everyday. My boyfriend and I go to Handle Bar about 1-2 times a month. We always order the Black Bean Tostadas appetizer and the Buffalo Chicken Wrap. It's my favorite vegetarian restaurant. If you're looking into becoming vegetarian or vegan, this is the place to go to. There's a variety of meat substitutes entrees on the menu. So try something different each time you go. Everything is great! The service is quick. There's always parking near by and the prices are decent.

Love their plantains! This place has a relaxed, neighborhood feel to it and the people that work there are really nice too. I've gone here for both brunch and dinner and have walked away totally satisfied with both.

The Handlebar is a great option to have, especially when more & more of my friends are going veg/an.  However, I find their food to be overly bland.  I can go either way on cuisine - meat or no meat, but restaurants that serve vegetarian food really need to replace that succulence with spice & I don't think Handlebar does this enough.  It's not offensive, just kind of boring (even my veg pals say this.) On the plus side: good beer selection and perfect patio.

i can't believe i haven't yelped this place yet!  handlebar is a top choice for patio seating and yummy won't break your wallet food scarfing.  great beers on draft - dark horse raspberry ale is delicious! my favorite thing about the handlebar?  the meal of three sides!  genius!  i get the triumvirate of fried plantains, collard greens, and gouda mac n cheese.  yum yum!  i love you handlebar.  and i love that you let me smoke on your patio.

What? Vegetarian bar food? You've gotta be kidding. Amazing sandwiches, good beer selection. The BBQ Seitan proves better than anyone could imagine.  Two negatives: Quite crowded (due in part to the fantastic food, atmosphere, and beer, I'm sure); very loud, but at least it's good music. Still, we'll definitely be back for those amazing sandwiches.

I was really disappointed that I was not greeted by a host with a handlebar moustache. Instead I was greeted by a funky, hipster with a mesh hat and long tube socks....alas. I decided to try out Handlebar after I had heard some great reviews and I had a meat filled week. I've noticed that I can eat a lot of vegetarian food and never feel overly full unlike when I have a Kuma's Corner burger. My girlfriend and I started with the chorizo nachos, faux chorizo of course. The dish was loaded with black beans and wonderful chorizo. The major difference I could taste was in the fact that it was less greasy than a ground beef nachos. Overall they were really good. I then had the tofu fajitas. For some reason, I went with a Mexican theme. The tofu appeared to be lightly fried and accompanied by some wonderful grilled vegetables and soft corn tortillas. They also serve it with a green salsa which is a nice accompaniment. My meal was great, I cleaned the plate and didn't feel overly full at all. They have a great beer selection and a diverse menu. I even had half my grilfriend's buffalo chicken wrap today and it was very good. Although, I could swear that the brown rice is identitical to the bag brown rice you can get at Trader Joe's. My major complaint is that it was awfully loud in the restaurant. Maybe I am getting old and losing my hearing but it was hard to keep a conversation with my girlfriend. On the plus side, we were in and out in 45 minutes and we had to probably wait 10 for a table. The service is good and fast.  I would like to go back and try brunch because I bet it would really hit the spot but if you are looking for an eclectic vegetarian delight, Handlebar is your place.

This review is for brunch only, as I know from the last time I came here YEARS ago the menu is a lot broader. But for brunch?  I'm just underwhelmed.  Maybe it's because I don't really like eggs, which knocks out half the menu. Still: black beans, avacado, seitan chorizo: I love all those things.  But for a vegetarian and vegan focused place, I suppose I expect something....yawn... not so.... yaaaawn...... nyeh.  (gum smack)  I mean really, with a menu like that, why come HERE for brunch? To be fair, I'm not a huge fan of breakfast food.  So I opted for a sandwich, and went for the thing I make less often at home (a BBQ seitan sandwich) over something I make a lot these days (grilled cheese with avocado, tomato, etc).  Wrong move.  The sandwich tasted only like BBQ sauce, was way too big to manage, and just bored me. Don't get me wrong.  We sat outside on a lovely sunny day.  We had a party of six and were happily accommodated.  Our server was super friendly.  Good beer on tap.    Great samosas and nachos for an appetizer.  I'd come back for the seitan chorizo and black bean nachos alone. I know from experience their African ground nut stew and other entrees are worth the trip out here.  But the brunch menu which hangs around like a clueless guest until 3pm on weekends?  No thanks.

Ok, I LOOOOVE Vegetarian/Vegan food...and everyone seems to love this place, so maybe my problem is...I don't really like American food as much? No, that can't be it.... After a morning of biking around in Wicker Park, my brother and I decided to eat here. My brother ordered a grilled cheese sandwich with fries and I ordered buffalo "chicken" wrap with soup. The soup was GREAT. The chicken wrap wasn't horrible. It was actually the buffalo sauce that I didn't like. I had a chai tea, as well, which was good...but my whole thing is, if you can easily have access to a whole box of it for cheaper and it isn't made in some special way, then...no awesome points. But that's just me. The really good thing was it wasn't too busy since it was early afternoon and the waitress was really nice, never kept us waiting too long. The bathroom and establishment was clean. And I really want to go again and order something different because it might've been that not-so-great feeling of buffalo sauce to my tastebuds. Damn it all.

ok people this is were i walk away with my tail between my legs and admit i was slightly wrong here. this is a big step for my stubborn self so bare with me. handlebar i apologize..after another visit i deem you worthy of 5 stars. your service really is awsome. very attentive staff and quick with the food for my growling belly. and let me tell you about my new found favorite : bbq seitan you have my heart and then some. so with that said i hope you can forgive me

I've only been once (thus far) but I have been thinking about the green meanie sandwich ever since.  I think that says something since it was a few weeks ago.  The mac n cheese is good too...but definitely smokey, so if you aren't a fan of smoked gouda, it won't be for you.

You'd think a city as big as Chicago would have a better selection of vegetarian and vegetarian friendly restaurants.  I guess this place seemed a little better than Earwax.  I feel like both of them could stand to decrease prices five to ten per cent and cut down a little on hipster posturing and/or redirect all that energy spent standing and posing and hipstering into revving up the food. Anyway, the food was fine.    The service wasn't as bad as it is as Earwax, though it was kind of tacky to be told they can't split a check on two cards when it is quite clear that they CAN do such a thing but DON'T do it because they don't want to pay the extra dollar processing charge or whatever.  This tacky bit brought the server very close to getting a ten per cent tip but my friend is such a pussycat that he gave what worked out to be 18.5 percent for service that could best be described as adequate. It's just funny that in a city like Chicago the assortment of vegetarian restaurants is so unremarkable and limited.  Thank heaven for Victory's Banner and Alice & Friends.  And the more i think about this place the more I think I might rather go to Pick Me Up, although those mashed potatoes were pretty good, so I might be inclined to check it out again if I'm in the neighborhood.

3.75 stars as a restaurant but 4.75 stars as a vegan/veggie/seafood restaurant.  Really, there should be different scales. I just got back from dinner here with my two lovely lady friends and had a pretty damn good time. We got the darkhorse raspberry beer- I loved it! Not sweet and not dark- perfect! I was quite impressed with their unique beer selection none of that mgd and bud crap. They also have drink specials every day- veddy nize (Borat voice).  We got the nachos as an appetizers and I wasn't a huge fan on the topping ratio... LOTS of beans, one 2 oz cup partially filled with sour cream, no salsa unless requested, and not much (portion wise) of anything else. Still good but I would defo get the chili cheese fries next time.  For dinner I got the green meanie with the smoked gouda mac and cheese. The meanie was veddy nize and veddy big. The smoked gouda mac and cheese was DELISH and huge as far as a "side" goes. Next time I'm getting the grilled cheese though... just crazing one on this cloudy day... maybe with avocado for a nominal extra $1.50. Both of my friends got the fried "chicken" salad... I tried it and thought it was fabu as well.  For dessert we got the apple crisp... I thought it was good but not fab. Next time I'll get the PB&J pies or the plantains foster.  So maybe my first time there was more a learning experience. I now know what kind of direction to take the next time I go and order and I defo plan on going back on a sunny day so I can enjoy their beer garden.  PS- parking is a breeze here- SaWeet!

I went there on a Wednesday evening which of course is oh so busy a day in the restaurant biz. (I'm being sarcastic here.) We were in a party of four plus a 3 year old. We ordered our food. Then we got our drinks and soup. An hour passed... and NOTHING! The waiter said the food would be out quick and asked us fir the FIRST TIME for drink refills. Did I mention an HOUR passed by now? THEN its like 1 hour 20 minutes since our order and I have to go find our waiter and then tell him that this is ridiculous and we have to leave. He then informs me that they lost the order ticket. GOOD JOB! Worthy of 5 Stars, but I guess I am a jerk and d!@k and will only give 1 star. CUSTOMER SERVICE LESSON for Handlebar: You should have OFFERED to make our meal immediately and comped the whole thing. That is the only way out of negative word of mouth. If you don't understand this, refer to Newton's Third Law: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. It was nice out and they opened up the outdoor dining area. BIG MISTAKE Handlepeople! You know there is this thing called STAFFING??? You take customers based on your staff and make sure you can REASONABLY accommodate them. Your staff was scampering around trying to serve all the tables. This is a fault of management and greed to milk the workers and customers. The food definitely SOUNDED interesting. I guess I will never know. My recommendation? Make sure you go when the weather is crap (so they don't use the outdoor dining),  they don't have more than 2 tables of customers. Any more and they might lose your order, and not talk to you after they take your order. OK, I'm being sarcastic here, but you get my point.

This is one of my favorite veggie restaurants in Chicago. The wait staff is always good and the food is always yummy. If you like avocados, try the Green Meanie. I often find myself craving this sandwich. Also a good mock meat dish to try is the Buffalo 'Chicken' Wrap. Somewhat spicy w/a tasty sauce. My friend who loves his meat tried this and thought it was really good. I'm impressed that he was impressed. Good job handlebar! Fries are really good here too. I've only been here a handful of times and still have a ton of other dishes to try. Not once have I not liked what I ordered. Luck? I think not! The decor is interesting and always changing. Some of the tables are a little too close together. Regardless, Handlebar is definitely a great place to eat, drink, and be merry!

WHAT THE EFFF!!! I can't believe I haven't written a review about this place... SO I'm not a vegetarian but i love eating fake meat sometimes...sue me. I've been here plenty of times, they have amazing butternut squash tortellini. I didn't see it on the menu a few weeks ago so I wonder if it's a seasonal thing.   Well last week I got the buffalo 'chicken' wrap. Holy jeebus, I can't get enough of the stuff now! It was really on point to me.  And let's not even get into the Gouda mac & cheese, let's not. They have a nice beer selection and any bar that has Gumballhead on Tap has my heart and soul.
I try and get to this place when im back in town, i love the food there!  Great vegetarian food!

Handlebar has been on my radar for a while (like, a year) and I finally had lunch there the other day. As it was an amazing warm day, the outdoor seeting was open and everyone was enjoying the tables under the lazily spinning wheels of several old bikes (now art pieces of sorts).  I'd hoped to get a peaceful cheesy feeling from the items I ordered: the grilled cheese (muenster on multigrain bread) and the infamous smoked gouda mac & cheese that I had seen hailed so much in reviews. The grilled cheese was very good: melty muenster crusted up nicely around the edges, and the multigrain bread added a nice textural dimension. The macaroni, though providing a wonderful flavor from the smoked gouda, was disappointingly cold. Had we not been on a schedule, I would have sent it back. Service was leisurely, with two waiters tag teaming our table (though then at times it seemed as though no one was serving us).  Overall, Handlebar was a decent spot for casual drinking and dining with a no-rush vibe.

Sometimes I wonder if I moved here to be closer to Handlebar, a bike-enthusiast beer drinker's paradise. Its pescatarian food leaves me feeling fresh even after consuming 3 bottles of Mighty Arrow. I go so often that the bartenders and servers raise their eyebrows, Weren't u here last night? And I seem to have a special table (the one in the corner near the windows). Lightly breaded and seasoned, theirs is the best tofu I've tasted during my 6 months in 60647.  The Buffalo "Chicken" Wrap easily wows all my meat-eating friends, and the Everything Green Salad (edamame, avocado, spinach, green goddess dressing) is my mom's favorite. Every day of the week they offer shots of tequila with Tecate for five dollars. Noted for their extensive beer collection, Handlebar has been listed in the Reader's top 30 Chicago Restaurants.

I've been to Handlebar a bunch of times and I've never had to wait for a table. My servers have been great, the food has consistently been good and the prices are reasonable. They have outdoor seating and play good music, they even have yummy vegan options on the menu as well. I love supporting Handlebar and can't wait to dine al fresco this summer.

Having only drank here in the past, I recently had their fish tacos and wow were they good! I ate at the bar and the bartender did a good job serving me along with even offering a few different beer selections based on what I was drinking, even giving me a few tasting samples.  My experiences with the place keep getting better and I look forward to the next time eating and drinking at Handlebar.

Had a pretty good brunch here and was able to sit outside. The biscuits and gravy are very different but also tasty. Instead of two normal sized biscuits, they give you what appears to be one super-sized biscuit with "sausage" gravy draping the entire beast of wheat. There was no way I could finish the whole thing, so probably wouldn't order it on a regular basis. Their bloody mary is really good too (they supposedly add a splash of guinness but I wasn't able to detect it due to the spiciness)...

I hadn't been to the Handlebar in ages--years, actually--so I was thrilled when my friend Ruthie suggested it for a girls' night. Yeah, I know, a majority vegetarian cyclist bar doesn't scream "Girls Night Out!" but we're not your average girls.  It was one of the first super warm days of the season, so we wanted to sit on the patio. We were told it would be a 20 minute wait, so we took a seat at the bar. The bartenders were friendly and helpful with the beer selection. I really wanted there to be Three Floyd's Gumball Head, but I settled for the Three Floyd's Pride and Joy, which was a Friday night special for $4. Not too shabby. For those of you who love your "shandies" and "panaches," Handlebar is one of the few non-German bars in the city that stocks Stiegl Radler, which is this delicious mix of lemon soda and beer. It wasn't quite hot enough for it the night we were there, but man, when it's over 80 and you're on the patio, go for it!  So we sat and drank for awhile, and, after inquiring why the 20 minutes was taking so long, learned that it had started to rain. Why they didn't inform us of this is beyond me, but we kind of shrugged and chose a table by the window.  While the menu is small, it is mighty for veggies looking for some interesting options. I dallied between the Black Beans Maduro and the Ground Nut Stew, and thought for a moment of just ordering a plate of seitan Chorizo and black bean nachos, but then finally made up my mind and ordered the Fish Tacos. My three dinner companions all ordered the Black Beans Maduro, and it had pleasing presentation and just the right amount of spice. My fish tacos were pretty good; I still think that Goose Islands are the best in the city though. The fish was meaty, the avocado generous, and the rice and chili side delicious, but the tacos overall were on the dry side. They begged for the creamy, tangy sauce that is drizzled over the ones at Goose Island. Probably should have gone for the nachos.  Now for the completely unexpected bizarre part that is completely a product of my flight of fancy: well, let me give you background first, dear Readers. As we were sitting at the bar, I overheard my friend Ruthie say, "they only accept one card per table." I immediately pulled out my Chicago Public Radio card and said, "Great! We can use mine!" So when the meal came to a close, I handed my card over to our server about whom we later wondered--was he stoned? One diner at our table noticed that he tried to swipe it on the credit card reader several times, and he soon returned, saying, "This doesn't work." I explained to him that the card is good for two-for-one meals. He went off again, and then returned again, this time saying, "Our chef says that we didn't sign up for this, but I gave you 15% off your meal anyway." After some discussion, I learned that the "card" Ruthie had been referring to ealier was a CREDIT CARD! Ooops.  Now, don't you all go running to the Handlebar with your Chicago Public Radio cards expecting a discount, but do take note that they only accept one credit card per table, and they do not split checks.  Next time I come here, I want to sit outside with a plate of nachos and a hoppier beer or a Radler. Then I will be able to add another star.
Brunch is great. I absolutely love the vegan breakfast burrito. Entire brunch menu is delicious!  Dinner is good. Mac and cheese is tasty. Like the nacho's. Everything else is pretty hit or miss.

Love Handlebar. Everything I have ever eaten and drank there is great. Great coffee. Salads are amazing. The vegan options are tasty. And the side of mac n cheese...not to be skipped. Oh, and ask for a desert menu, because the apple crisp? Amazing. Don't come here in a hurry. Not that the service is slow--it's a place to chill. Service is attentive, but relaxed. Take your time.
Overrated and overpriced are no way to stay in business.  However, somehow it's working for these guys.  For the quality/quantity received you can do better, vegetarian or not.

You will enjoy the Handlebar if you: * don't require meat-meat at every meal   - (meat-meat used to have legs) * have ever thought about celebrating dark lord day * ride a bike or know people who ride bikes * can tell the difference between motorhead and judas priest * want to support local artists by critiquing their work that hangs on the walls * like exposed brick because it reminds you of free masonry * have ever gotten a temporary tattoo and thought about keeping it My new favorite dish is the Ground Nut Stew, something I never would have imagined myself ordering but did so on a whim and have now had it the last three times I've gone.  Past favorites have been the catfish and the fish tacos. The servers are probably cooler than you, but they don't call attention to it.   I'd give it 5 stars but I'm saving that for when someone takes me to some schmancy place like Alinea or something.

A few weeks back I was dabbling in veganism, and Handlebar was the highlight of the experiment. Most of the dishes are vegetarian rather than vegan, but their vegan offerings are excellent. The buffalo 'chicken' wrap was delicious and surprisingly satisfying. The pleasant service and inviting decor only enhanced my dining experience. I would recommend Handlebar to any of my friends, vegetarian or otherwise.

I was really disappointed with my entree, my girlfriend's entree, and our appetizers.  For appetizers, our group of four ordered the chips and salsa and the samosas.  The chips came with a green salsa that was too watery and a pico de gallo which was nice.  The samosas had a good flavor, but they where so hard I found them impossible to cut.  The outside crusty-part was too mealy in texture and lacked anything special.  I ordered the fish tacos, which came with a side of chili and rice.  My favorite part of the meal was that the rice that accompanied the meal was brown rice, which I love.  The fish on the tacos was scarce, and they came in hard little nuggets.  It reminded me of leftover fish that I would put to use at home.  While I understand and appreciate using leftovers and less than desirable cuts of meat and fish at home, I expect more when I dine out, especially for an entree that cost over $11.  My girlfriend ordered the catfish.  Her sides were cold, but she said she was happy with the fish.  I had it and thought it was only ok.  I will not return to this restaurant.

I love this place. I've tried a couple of different things here, but 90% of the time I get the buffalo 'chicken'  wrap because it is AMAZING. Seriously. I could eat it every day. Same thing with the gouda mac 'n cheese. I always go in there thinking I will try something new, but then I panic and order the same thing because it is too good to pass up. Plus they have an awesome patio and great beer selections.

Another place that I actually have lots of food choices. YAHOO!!  I have been a vegetarian for almost 25 years and back in the "old days" was it ever hard to find a place that had vegetarian food on the menu. I coined myself "the Queen of sides" because all I could ever order was a side of this or a side of that. I always made due but in the last ten years, things have really changed. Handlebar did not disappoint.  So the Libra in me was in quite the quandary. I am used to having 2 or maybe 3 choices.  (Fellow Libras, you understand me, right?)   Aside from the fish on the menu, I could order ANYTHING!! My mind was in choice overload. Should I order the Nut stew? Should I order the Maduros? Or maybe the Green Meanie, which sounded delightful. I had read the reviews about the mac and cheese but I am not a fan of "smoked" anything as it has a meaty taste to it that turns me off. My dining companion did order the mac and cheese and I did have a taste, and yes that smokey taste was present so I am glad that I did not order that. I decided on the nachos. Yummy, cheesy, black beanie goodness. And I had the Two Hearted something or other beer on tap that was damn good. Ended up having more than my share of the beer, it was really good.  Yay! Handlebar, I love you. Yea, I did feel like an old dork in that crowd but I don't care. I will definitely go back and try some more good beer and awesome vegetarian food.

Handlebar is an amazing go-to and I can't wait til the patio is open this spring/summer.  Smoked gouda mac & cheese haunts me, the everything green salad is the best salad I've ever had and the green meanie sandwich dressing is delicious.  The margarita is the best ever (they put a splash of OJ in it which makes it less acid and more citrus) and the seitan fools even meat eaters.  Loss of a point because we've been on more than one occasion for weekday lunch and had key elements missing from our plates (sauce on a buffalo "chicken" wrap," black beans from the nachos) - but that's not the norm.  Delish option for veggies and non and my parents loved it, which is a minor miracle in the veggie realm.

If I had to pick a way to die, it would probably be engorge myself on Handlebar's Nachos until A) my heart explodes B) I overdose on my brain's own endorphins C) I slip into a food coma or D) Drown in delicious Nacho Cheese and black beans. Last time I came here I burned my face because I smashed it into the searing-hot pile of corn chips. 2nd and 3rd degree burns. And I'm still giving it 5 goddamn stars. Seriously did they enchant this stuff with fairy dust or unicorns hair? This stuff is friggin' ridiculous. Gandalf must have made this shit... Jesus.

Oh Handlebar, how I love thee... So since my last review several things have changed. The grilled tofu sandwich is BACK on the regular menu (woohoo!) and service has never been better. Food is still yummy as ever. Can't wait until summer when I can ride my bike here for drinks/dinner.

This place never disappoints. The last time I went here I went with two straight-edge vegans. It was a good experience from the start because they had my favorite beer on tap, Great Lakes Conway's Irish Ale, extremely hard to find. I ordered a pint of that and checked out the menu. I decided on one of the specials, homemade pierogi with sweet and sour cabbage and a homemade horseradish sauce. I, also, had to get a side order of their smoked Gouda mac and cheese, it is ridiculous. The food was awesome. The only disappointing thing of the night was when I wanted to re-up on my beer the waitress said they just ran out. Oh well. Granted this place can get crowded, and loud, and is a hipsters paradise, but that is part of its atmosphere and I happen to like it.
Very tasty veg food!! Great flavors, not boring at all! I think it's great they support bicycling, too! Ambiance was very casual, deli-like with funky art. Reminded me of the Buzz Cafe in Oak Park.
My husband and I considered a move to Chicago, based strictly on our meals at this place. Even the side salad was phenomenal. Biscuits and gravy, seitan sandwich, vegan heaven. HEAVEN.

Delicious food paired with delicious beers. Yum! The Gouda mac and cheese totally hits the spot, even though it's a side dish, and the buffalo seitan wrap hardly seems vegetarian. Definitely going back, even though I'm not vegetarian.

I stumbled into this place having just left Cheetah and beging ravenous. I had no idea that it was a vegeterian joing. I sat at bthe bar and had the poached eggs with fried rissotto, spinach, basil and pinenuts. Wow was that good. So siple and amazingly tasty. I was svery happy.

Whenever I treat a friend to breakfast in Chicago, I recommend Handlebar.  Of course, the biscuits and gravy are to die for, but other options are yum. The breakfast burrito, which you can order vegan, comes off ultra-fresh but a bit bland if you don't like salsa and sour cream. Handlebar serves it with condiments on the side, so you can choose how much flavor you want. The Huevos Diablo is a bit too spicy for me. I mean, I can eat it, but I'd prefer it with a bit less kick. As always, the Metropolis coffee is absolutely fabulous - smooth, hot and served with your choice of cream or soy. My only complaint is the price. Biscuits and gravy shouldn't cost $7.

They had me at Om playing through the speakers when we first sat down. They could have stopped there, but they had a special that involved tequila shots and Tecate.  I don't remember much more after that. Hooray!

Lots of late-night vegan options; yay! I had the "Savory Seitan Stuffed Tortellini" this past time. It was quite filling, though almost a little sweet. I've had the "Green Meanie" sandwich before (without the cheese); it's a big sandwich, but the veggie filling is light enough that it doesn't leave me feeling like I ate a brick. Handlebar is great for brunch. I've had the "Vegan Diablos" and "Vegan Breakfast Burrito" before, but I can barely finish cuz it's so much delicious food. The beermosas are excellent as well. They have a great beer selection (including my Unibroue favourites) and drink specials every day of the week. I like the flexibility between bar and restaurant; I've gone here just for drinks or just for food. Be prepared to wait during prime times. You'll have the best luck if you come as a party of two. Service can be spotty when it gets busy.

"Is seitan some kind of pork?" When one of my lovely book/brunch club ladies exclaimed this after perusing the menu I feared that my restaurant choice might turn into a disaster. I was so excited about to try Handlebar that I didn't consider the possibility that meat eaters might be less than enthused about it, especially when nursing their post-St. Patty's Day hangovers.  Crisis averted, no one was disappointed by their meal choices. The friend who asked about seitan even exclaimed that it was the best breakfast burrito she's ever had. In fact, everyone at our table (all meat eaters btw) had nothing, but praise for their meals. One even said it was the best brunch we'd met for in a really long time, yay! I couldn't decide what to get, so many things looked good. Since this place is vegetarian/vegan friendly I didn't have to eliminate a lot of menu items like I normally do, which was nice. I settled on the grilled cheese and a side of smoked gouda mac & cheese. I usually eat one item before moving on to the next, but both dishes looked so tasty I couldn't decide which one to eat first. I broke with habit and alternated between the two. Service was friendly, but slow. Since we were chatting about the book and catching up anyway it didn't hinder our dining experience much. Bottom line: Really good food, I can't wait to come back. TIP: If you're going with a larger group (5+) for brunch get there early, the place fills up fast. TIP: They only take one credit card per table and don't split checks

This place rules, lots of vegan options, rad sides and beer. totally rad. Most of my non vegan/veggie friends like this place too. I love the wrap and the BBQ seitan sandwich. they used to have this wasabi tofu dish that I loved but unfortunately it is no longer there.   In the nice months there is a large patio, great for drinking beer and enjoying the food. I dont really like sitting inside the place because it is kind of crowded.  I think on mondays they have a deal on PBR from the tap, so go there get some sides and enjoy a frosty brew in the back. yeah man I like the place.

This place was pretty awesome.  They offer 95% of the items on their menu in vegan "form" and serve huge delicious portions of them for a decent price.  The only downside was that the place is fairly small and was jam packed the night I went but it's well worth the food.  Can't wait to come back here again.

before we moved here, my fiance (a chicago native) always talked about how there was so much good bar food in chicago. well, handlebar is a prime example of this. i love that it's kind of a hole-in-the-wall but they serve primarily vegetarian food. when i went, i was in the mood for something healthy (i think it was on a sunday night after a weekend of binge eating), and got the everything green salad. it was great and really substantial - even though the name may sound otherwise. the ingredients were fresh, and i enjoyed it with a framboise from the tap.  this is a great place if you're looking for something casual, relatively cheap and tasty.  good to eat: everything green salad
Handlebar is the shiznit. I'm in love.Best place to get wasted at anytime of day especially on their sick ass patio. Hevous diablos is simply the best.

Awesome!  I don't really know what a "hipster" is, as referred to in other reviews... and so I don't think I am one, but I loved this place.  Unique dishes with great vegetarian selection, but you could still bring a meat-eater here and they would be happy.  The beer selection was great, the service was good.
I haven't had the pleasure in a while but I love your corn cakes and the patio when it's not 20 degrees.

I have found Handlebar to be very hit-or-miss. I usually love their buffalo "chicken" wrap. I used to get the bar-b-q seitan, but sometimes it was terrible. They seemed to switch ingredients/sauce often. I never knew what I was getting. Overall, the food is better than decent even on a bad day. I love the gouda mac n' cheese and fried plantains. The place is relatively small and has a back patio for use during the warmer seasons.  While those are the things I like about Handlebar here are the things I don't:  1. They won't split bills.  2. If you come in a group of two they will always seat you at a small two person table, even if the place is empty. Even if you ask to be moved to a larger table it's a no go. They always save the bigger tables for larger parties.  3. As Handlebar is small some of the small tables are really small and awkwardly located. For example, in a dark corner or up against a wall you will be jamming your elbow into every time you move.  4. Service is spotty. Sometimes good, sometimes eh.

Friendly Wait Staff - Check Good Music - Check Hopping Atmosphere - Check Good Food - Double Check! I consider myself a sort of "french fry connoisseur" if you must, and Handlebar topped my list as some of the best. Fresh cut and scrumptious! Along with my french fries I got the "Green Meanie," which couldn't have been any better. Fresh avocado, spinach, and a goat cheese spread. MMM MMM MMM... I already can't wait to go back. Next time though I am going to give that Smoked Gouda Mac and Cheese a try. It looked orgasmic!

This is a great place for some offbeat veggie comfort food. Every entree is solid (red beans an rice with plantains, fake meat BBQ, etc.). They've got a great selection of beers (incl. spicy non-alcoholic ginger beer). During the summer, it's the perfect brunch spot. As you can imagine, the crowd is very bike-y. I'm talkin' about Chrome bags, beards, one pant leg up, large framed glasses, etc.) with a few beer geeks thrown in for good measure. The difference between the two? Beer geeks are bit chunky.  One star off for a few times (out of many) where the food was "off." Not bad, mind you. Just not as good as it usually is.  It can get crowded on weekends, so arrive a bit early.  And forget about the last Friday of the month from March to October- that's Critical Mass time.

I love their beer selection, I love their food, I love their atmosphere, I love their service, and I love their desserts (vegan peanut butter and jelly fried pies for the win). I once had seitan ravioli in a butternut squash sauce drizzled with white truffle oil... vegan, and divine.  My one complaint - the state smoking law allows establishments to declare their entire patio area as non-smoking if they so choose, instead of just the area close to the door. Handlebar should really do this, as I was rather unpleasantly surprised last fall to find out I had to sit in the shaded area to avoid the smoke of others on the patio.

I specifically signed up for Yelp just to write this review.  Yes, I like Handlebar that much.  My boyfriend and I made a habit of hanging out at the bar on Saturday nights most of 2007/2008, because we liked the music, atmosphere, and people.  Saturday nights can be slow, but it works out because this place is almost intolerable when it's packed.  As for the atmosphere, well, there is definitely something to be said for a place where the servers talk to you and sing along to old heavy metal all night long.   We spent my most recent birthday here and drank impossible amounts of alcohol while one of the employees (off the clock, obviously) sat next to us and made a pyramid of Tecate cans (dubbed the "beeramid").   However, we were EXTREMELY bummed a while ago to discover that our favorite bartender was fired (YES!! grrr) due to some bad Yelp reviews.  What the hell, guys?  We still go here on occasion for dinner, but we don't hang out at the bar like we used to.  They lost a star for that.   I'm not vegan, but I love the fake chicken salad .  My boyfriend usually goes for the daily vegan specials, which sometimes miss the mark and sometimes are quite splendid.  I could happily eat the vegan peanut butter and jelly fried pies every day of the week.  The beer selection is excellent.  PleasepleasepleasePLEASE bring Dave back, though!

After not seeing one of my favorite Yelpers in a long time--it was time that we got together for lunch. Rob L suggested that we come to Handlebar simply because it is well...10 minutes from my house. Lucky me.  With only eating here so long ago, I barely remember what I ate-- I was glad I was heading back here for lunch. It was a very chill environment for lunch, with only four tables being used I was so happy--I love chill. We ordered. It was great. Enough said.  I had the "Everything Green Salad"--it was piled high with fresh spinach, sprouts, avocado, pistachios, green beans, and edamme beans. It is normally served with creamy green goddess dressing but I opted out that for just balsamic vinaigrette. It was very good! Perfect size to get filled up for.  Rob went with the breakfast burrito. Normally I would have ordered it--but because of my new diet plan I couldn't. It looked great though. Eggs, cheese, chunky potato pieces, avocados, sour cream & salsa verde. It was also served with a side of black beans. How delicious.  This place is great. I want to come here for dinner again--maybe in the late spring/summer so I can sit in their patio area when it is nice outside. I can't wait!

I've been going to Handlebar since before I could drink and that's saying something.  I do have a bone to pick with most of the earlier reviews posted though.  I don't get how people think it's hipster centric there.  I walk in with a collared shirt and slacks and day or night of the week and am always warmly greeted.  The waitstaff and some of the cooks know me by name and most make a point to greet me AND drink with me.  Yeah carbombs! Speaking of which, there Friday night $5 Carbomb special is not only the cheapest in the city, it's also the tastiest in the city.  You don't want to bet me on this. Food is always prompt; even when crazy busy.  This place is fairly popular and has managed to maintain open thru several neighborhood renovations.  As the neighborhood has transitioned to its more current upscale YUP-ish persona, rents have gone up - ergo the price of food goes up.  Stop complaining and use math folks... The food has been constantly good.  I have yet to have a bad meal here.  When I first started eating here I was a vegetarian cyclist.  Now I'm a steak eating kinda guy with hairy legs.  Yet I still find this pescotarian place to be my favorite in the city, no matter Brunch, Lunch, Dinner or just drinks till close. When I was in the military I had several last night of debauchery drinking events here and several first night home craziness to boot and I've never regretted a night of it - minus my self induced hangovers...  Again; $5 carbombs...

A few friends and I came here during the summer after hearing that their backyard patio was arguably the best in the city.  While it might not be that, it was definitely good enough to remember fondly on a frigid February afternoon. The three stars are for the vegetarian quesadilla - so gooey and spicy, it was big and filling enough for a meal even without any meat. The service, on the other hand, was pretty odd.  One guy brought us to our seats and told us our waiter would be right around to get drink orders...but no one ever came, so we went to the bar to order.  The bartender told us he'd send out a waiter, and eventually a third guy came out and asked what we wanted to drink.  I ordered an Arnold Palmer with vodka, and he audibly scoffed.  I've got a good sense of humor about the things I ingest, but this guy wasn't joking - he actually thought it was ridiculous that I wanted vodka in my drink and refused to let me order it with anything but whiskey.  I told him I wasn't a whiskey drinker, but he left before I was sure what I would be receiving and before even asking us if we'd like something to eat.  The drinks came out and lo and behold my drink was made with whiskey, but since it had taken so long to get even that I decided to cut my losses.  We were about to order some food, but the second our waiter dropped off our drinks he walked away.  We figured he'd come back to see how things were (especially since he'd made me a drink I was almost certain not to like), but nope - we had to go ask the guy who seated us if we could order some food (which, as I mentioned above, was delicious).  This all might have been easily explained had the place been super-busy, but there was no one in the bar and one other table on the patio, and they didn't order anything the entire time we were there. Despite the awkward service, I'd go back.  The attitude comes with the hipster territory, and as long as you sit at the bar you're at least guaranteed drinks.

A Wicker Park staple, and excellent place to go after a long bike ride around town. I had the benefit of visiting this place several times over the summer, and it was so excellent. Smoked gouda mac n cheese is just excellent, and I would suggest to get it your first time.  It's hard to say what makes this restaurant so great, but I really like the fact that it has a chic, independent look that makes you feel at home. The servers are really cool, as is everyone in this neighborhood. Wicker park is full of hipster/ yuppies that want to be really cool. Although this neighborhood is not nearly as counter culture as it used to be, it is still very fun. I went to handlebar with my co-worker over the summer, and we had a lot of fun. I think there's also a bar here too, but I'm not too sure. Check it out.

My past experiences with vegan friendly food places have in general left me pretty unimpressed.  I went in with no expectations except trying something new, but was left sorely disappointed each and every time. So when I won $30 in gift certificates to this place from the Chicago Anarchist Film Festival (100% true) I was a bit hesitant to trek out of my way to try it out.  So they sat unused for a good nine months, floating from various folder to folder between the office, the bedroom at my old apartment and my current apartment.  I thought I lost them in the move but then they magically reappeared three months afterward.  Cool. So I finally convince the lady to join me in a meal here.  I get the BBQ Seitan (spell check is telling me to change it to Satan.  LOL FIREFOX HATES VEGANS!!11!1!11!!) sandwich with some fries and a nice Three Floyds.  The lady gets a wrap, fries and some other nice beer.  We're both shocked and amazed by how big the meals happened to be and by how filling they managed to be.  We loitered for awhile, sipping our beers and picking slowly at our remaining food.  No one seemed to care.  When actually did get out, both of us left plenty gruntled by what we'd shoved into the stomachs and by how much we left with.   Since we ordered fancy beers instead of the customary water the tab was kind of high but there was enough on the certificates to cover the meal and a generous tip for our more than above average waitress.   During our time in there we heard Fugazi, Hot Water Music and Lifetime albums.  It was like walking into a real world, living and breathing version of  punknews.org .

I don't really think this is a four star place.  I'd say it's more like a 3. However, it is here that I ate the first fake chicken that did not taste like play-doh.  Most fake chicken doesn't even taste like brand name Play-doh.  The generic kind that would dry out after 15 minutes of playing with it, and ended up being thrown out the same day it was bought. But, the buffalo 'chicken' wrap actually tasted 'good.'  I didn't 'hate' it, and am curious to 'go' back to Handlebar to get more 'chicken.' The Key Lime Pie was also pretty delicious. The reason I don't care for it more was the weird looks from the people who were way more hipster than us.  I'm sorry I wear Khaki Pants and North Face.  That doesn't mean I'm a bad person.  :( :(

Another great spot just up from my office, so when a collards and mac and cheese craving comes on I am there to order those sides while I do some paperwork. The collards are recognizable bright green not the southern overdone style, and the mac and cheese is amped up with smoked gouda.

Pretty decent fish tacos (with catfish, which I found odd and unique).  The rice and beans that accompanied it did not run parallel to the good taste of the tacos, but with three decent sized tacos on the plate I had plenty to eat.  Service was okay, no refill on the coke offered, but otherwise friendly.  I'd try it again if I were in the area.  Atmosphere is kind of loud, cramped, and hipster... but it's got character.

I've been to handlebar multiple times because their food is great! During the summertime they have indoor and outdoor seating. The menu is very creative so take a risk and order something off their specials menu! I loooove their samosas. Unfortunately I had their blackened catfish once and that was more than enough times. It did not taste good! Maybe they were having an off day? Everything else I've had here has been really delicious. Staff is very friendly and attentive. One thing that bothered me was that the last time I went there was a couple of party of 2's (including me) and plenty of seats for party of 4's. Instead of breaking up the tables to seat 2 party of 2's they made us wait at least 10 minutes. I guess they wanted to maximize the amount of space but come on, the starving cant wait!

Best restaurant in the city, IMO.  I am vegetarian and love beer so this place is a natural.  In the summer the patio is freakin' huge too, "come look at the size of that head, its a gigantic cranium!" - I digress. But honestly, the Buffalo Chicken Wrap is phenom and also the fried chicken salad, the BBQ Seitan sand, oh and their AM biscuits and gravy, mmmmm, I am so hungry just thinking about it. I would agree that they could use a larger menu but that's what the beer is for!  Of which they are also awesome. Lastly the music selections are always rockin and this is the first place I have ever heard Suicide that wasn't my car!  and right after they played Yo La Tengo....did I say it rocks?

droooooooooooooooool. This place is YUM! So, this place presents a pleasant problem: What do I get?! There are so many things that sound delicious. I myself am a pescatarian (while I refuse to take that label seriously, I'm putting it out there for clarity). The blackened catfish looked good, the fish tacos looked good (a personal favorite at any place that serves them), but i decided at a declared vegetarian restaurant, I needed to try something really vegetarian. And since rarely is tofu or seitan made, and made well in restaurants, I headed in that direction. I settled on the Grilled Tofu Sandwich with a side of Mac & Cheese. The sandwich was good and spicy, but a bit big to fit in your mouth cleanly. IT was still awesome. The smoked gouda mac & cheese was the most awesome, original take on the dish i've had. Nothing too fancy, just a good old cheese change-up that makes it pretty freaking awesome and more complex than your average mac & cheese. Everything else that my companions got looked awesome, such as the black beans maduro, black bean tostadas, and the special for the evening, shepard's pie. I HAVE to go back just to try more of the menu! And they were also pretty accommodating to our large group, so that was nice. Plus, they have a decent beer list, and any place that caters to bikers, makes me happy. GO HERE!

I saw it was Vegan - that's a bad sign, Usually means "creative horrible and overpriced" Then I saw the alarming number of hipsters and all their bike stuff. I loathe hipsters. And that's usually a sign of overpriced and trying too hard to be kitschy food. But it was the only thing that was open on that block and we were cold and hungry and didnt want to re-park LOVED IT! The food was outrageously good. I got the Groundnut stew that was spicy and tasty and well-balanced. The fella had the Green Meanie sandwich and being a carnivore was delightfully satisfied. It was yum. We shared a side of smoked gouda mac and cheese which was good and some collard greens which were fresh tasting and nicely spiced. Went great with my stew too. We didnt order drinks b/c we had been out drinking the night before and needed recovery but the bartender looked competent and the beer selection was pretty awesome. I have since gone back and had the Southern breakfast - two eggs on top of cheese grits, kale and succotash. The French toast is great, and the "Chicken " salad which is fried seitan is surprisingly tasty! The service surprised me the most. Generally, if the boy is wearing girl pants or the girl is wearing boys shoes and both genders look like they tried hard to make their hair appear unwashed, they are too cool for you. Our hipstery server was fantastic. Prompt, friendly, and I never felt rushed. I think it's a little expensive on some dishes ($14 for a tuna steak sandwich and $9 veggie samosas?) but the quality and atmosphere is good. This is a good place to go if you are a vegan or better yet if your friends are vegans and they keep dragging you to crappy vegetarian joints. I was pretty much not interested in going here, but now even though it's a bit out of the way for me, but I'll be back. Can't wait to try the breakfasts.

Handlebar can take me for a ride anytime! I am so picky when it comes to food, yet I had a rough time choosing what to get, so many options sounded good.  I chose the black beans maduro, and they were excellent (albeit more spicy than I expected).  I also tasted a friend's Ground Nut Stew, which was tasty, and another friend's Root Vegetable Shepherd's Pie, which was awesome and I would order it next time.  The best part of the menu, however, was her flourless cake which I took a bite of and promptly had a flavorgasm so extreme I had to ask them where they got the cake from (A Matter of Course, they said). I can't wait for the next ride, I definitely want to go back!

Parsnips, along with turnips and rutabagas, are usually my least favorite members of the vegetable kingdom. However I decided to get the Shepard's Pie on the specials menu and I'm glad I did. The parsnips were roasted beautifully and provided many mouthfuls of enjoyment along with the carrots, potatoes, chickpeas, and tomatoes potaged together (why not use it as a verb?) and topped with a mountain of whippetty whipped mashed potatoes garnished with slivers of scallion.  Mmmmm, potatoes....I love thee.  I also ordered a side salad, which was servicable, the kind of thing I'd make myself  (chopped lettuce, carrots, tomato, and red onion thrown in a bowl). At $4 its worth it only if you want some crispy vegetablyness, but not something to salivate about. I like the fact that the menu is compact and not overly reliant on meat subsitutes (although they do offer some items with tofu and seitan...which I always say like "satan" like the church lady). All in all the Handlebar is a great place to get a cheap to moderately priced meal and/or have some beers amidst cute bike riding (or wannabe bike riding) youngins with sophisticated and vegetarian-leaning tastes.

Strong enough for a meat eater but made for a vegetarian (well, technically a pescetarian but that's a bone of contention that shouldn't be played with). There was a reason that Handlebar was chosen as the place to revive Yelp Chicago's vegetarian events (in the form of the first monthly Vegetarian Supper Club).  Many meat eaters that I talked to before deciding on a venue raved about this place to the point where they could put aside consuming flesh for a night and join the festivities (extra credit and thank you to Handlebar for accomidating our large group - this place doesn't usually take reservations but made an exception for us). And it was pretty easy to see why.  While Handlebar doesn't seem to try to approximate meat like some vegetarian restaurants, the food is good enough that no meat eater in our group seemed to notice their loss.  But with Handlebar's fine beer selection, it's possible to get any omnivore who did notice a loss drunk enough not to care. There is a big problem for vegetarians at this restaurant though.  Too many choices.  I solved this dilemma by ordering three sides as a meal.  The collard greens were not sauteed enough but the vegetarian chili had a nice kick and a good consistency (though, again, not really fake meaty) and the gouda macaroni and cheese...oh my...I want it again right now. Yeah, just go here and get the gouda macaroni and cheese.  Trust me. If you're a meat eater that has thusfar avoided Handlebar due to it being a pescetarian restaurant, shame on you.  You're an elitist carnivore who doesn't know what you're missing. :)  But seriously, fake herbimilitancy aside, borrow your vegetarian friend's (or just some person on Yelp whose review you're randomly reading's) deoderant slogan parody and go!

I always thought it was a good thing when restaurants had small menus, you know, easy to make a decision, kitchen has most likely mastered the plates, etc.   Except here, at Handlebar, I stared at the menu for like 20 minutes on line and then another 15 in the place and STILL couldnt make up my mind.  Just when you thought one thing looked good, you saw two others that were almost better, and then not only is there a specials menu, but you have a fellow diner saying "oh gosh THIS dish is what I always order - its the best!"   aaah...!! I finally take the plunge and order the first thing that had caught my eye initially, which was the Ground Nut Stew.  A fabulous concoction of sweet potato, coconut, zucchini, and kale over brown rice, peanuts and toasted coconut.  Truly divine!  I was so impressed.   Now I am hooked and cant wait to go back and try more stuff off the menu.  Things are a tad on the pricey side, but hey, the food is pretty darn good so its worth it!

So hearty, so tasty, so vegetarian friendly! I've been here several times in one week and I've taken meateaters who loved the joint. I even ventured here on the coldest Chicago night in ten years (-30 wind chill).   Was I warm and satisfied?   Hell yeah! Please sample their fried "chicken" salad, their homemade soups or their gouda mac n cheese and let me know if you're not converted to the Veggie side immediately.

We ended up at this hipster scene after a few other places in the neighborhood were 2 hour waits.  The food as a whole was pretty good. The fish tacos are recommended along with the chorizo nachos.  Certainly not the best I've had in the city but pretty decent. I would certainly be persuaded to go again, but by and by its not on my list as a destination for dinner.  They did have a fairly decent vegetarian selection on the menu. I do hear amazing things about their brunch and more than likely will return to check it out.  I will give four stars to their bar and beer menu.  Worth a try if you haven't been.

For as long as Handlebar has been in existence and the many times I've passed it, I've never gone in, until a few weeks back when a friend and I stepped out into the cold to get a bite. The fact that Handlebar has vegetarian options is a plus, so for those bitching, find something better to do. As far as I'm concerned, the food that I ate was damn good and perfect for the freezing ass Chicago temps. If you want a hearty, delicious, vegetarian meal, look no further than the 'Ground Nut Stew,' consisting of sweet potato, coconut, zucchini, kale with brown rice, peanuts and toasted coconut. I don't see kale nearly enough on menus, so I was thrilled to see it within this dish. The portion was served in a large bowl at a fair price of $8.75.  Though I am not a coconut lover, I hardly noticed it amidst the dish. There was some heat, which got the blood flowin. Absolutely tasty, filling. I'll be back for the 'Ground Nut stew' again.

Love this place!  It's a great little bar and brunch spot.  It's small, but I've never waited more than 5 minutes to be seated. I'm not a vegetarian or a vegan, but it's nice that they have so many vegetarian and vegan-friendly choices.  My favorites from the menu include the Huevos Diablos, the Handlebar Omlette (smoked gouda, walnuts & pears), the Chili Quesadillas (veggie chili), the Green Meanie sandwich (spinach, herb goat cheese, avocado, tomato, honey mustard and sunflower sprouts - not alfalfa sprouts), and the Smoked Gouda Mac n' Cheese.  Good coffee, and consistently good service. They have several interesting beer choices.  I also love the beer garden out back. It's perfect for a nice warm afternoon or a Sunday morning brunch. Love the always changing artwork display too!

Saturday night...there is a line down the street for Piece. So we decide to go to the handlebar.
